        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nSteve_Hickey \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nFebruary 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \nBattlecry 2017, Auckland

        I ran a successful playtest of my multi-author version of Left Coast (my game of science-fiction authors and their friends dealing with mundane problems and weird conspiracies).

        We created a terrible sad story about a writer of near-future military conspiracies slowly realised he was trapped in his flat by a combination of mind-control drugs and very friendly secret agents inserting themselves into his life.

        Most usefully: I've been forced to 'debug' the character and setting creation process. It took far too long, and I've been figuring out how to strip it back. There's a Metatopia-like meet-up in Auckland next weekend: I'll run a playtest of just that (revised) process there.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nNovanIV \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nFebruary 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Resolved a combat in my SMT inspired Sorcerer game, dice went crazy resulting in either really big hits or really small hits. Even aside from that running Sorcerer combat as a GM felt really weird, both in allocating bonus dice, and in running demons on both sides. I think the players had fun.

        The PCs were fighting against 2 low power (A Pixie and a Jack Frost) demons, but we got a good taste of what that special damage ability can do as a result. One demon got destroyed/banished by one of the PCs with a random pipe they grabbed, while the other got just barely taken out and so tried surrendering. The second half of the session was just them interrogating the Pixie before letting it go.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nLisa Padol \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nFebruary 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Monsterhearts with Sneak Peek pack. I seem to have a routine:
        Pretend I'm going to do any prep.
        Realize it's about an hour before game, and I'm not going to do any prep.
        Folks arrive.
        As they chatter, find the email where someone summarized last session.

        And, oh right, they finally had the history test they'd been getting the teacher to put off.
        Also, the Witch's parents may be getting a divorce.
        The Werewolf has been trying to convince people not to shoot the wolves that have been attacking humans (one human, specifically, and the Werewolf kinda killed him). Of course, her tactic is to run up to them in the woods and shout "Don't shoot wolves! Don't shoot wolves!"
        The Queen -- who now considers the Fae and the Werewolf part of her gang -- has a plan to convince the town to have a nature preserve.

        Q: How much space do your wolves need?

        WW: A hundred thousand trees! Oh, and rabbits. A thousand rabbits!

        The Queen is trying to get the Werewolf to read up on animals to understand how to explain the truth about animals to humans. The Fae is trying to teach the Werewolf how to shake hands and give friendly, rather than overly intimate, hugs.
        The Werewolf, you understand, is the raised-by-wolves variant.

        The Fae is also trying to get the Witch to a) study with the Fae and b) tell the Fae what the Witch knows about the weird stuff. The Queen now has the papers the Witch wanted, and wants to try to read them before the Witch gets them.

        Oh dear. I need to decide what's in them.
        Right, and why the whole fae courts in the woods thing is exploding now.
        Or, y'know, get the players to figure it out for me. That would also work. But, it's useful to have an "if everyone flounders" answer on the shelf, in case I need to dust it off. I've a vague sense of what's going on, which has been enough thus far. The less I'm the one inventing stuff, the better.

        Oh, and I've named the man in the woods whom the Werewolf killed -- Old Steve. He probably has a relative who's going to show up to mourn and urge on the wolf hunt.

        Hm... the Werewolf's player said she figured the Werewolf and the school nurse were on a first name basis by now. Hm.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nkelmscott_press \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nFebruary 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n I went to Sheffield's Revelation convention!

        Blades in the Dark: John Harper's game of steampunk scoundrels pulling off heists. We got to do fun cultist stuff, the setting is cool, the rules are interesting and worked okay... but I'm still not convinced that the rules work that much *better* for fast-paced heists than any arbitrarily chosen traditionalist rules set.

        Masks: The game of stroppy teen superheroes. This worked really great, we got into trouble with the headmaster at the prom and then saved our dimension from my evil space-Roman brother. Keen to run/play again soon.

        Ghost Lines: John Harper's nano-game set in the world of Blades in the Dark where you play ghostbusters on a train. This was really well run, but precisely because it was well-run I'm confident in saying I don't really like it as a game due to the very constrained situation and grindingly deadly mechanics.

        Impulse Drive: space opera PbtA game in development. We had lots of fun Firefly-esque space squabbles. Mixed feelings about the rules, but the bits I don't like on paper didn't get in our way here.

        I ran The Warren. It was good: we had aristocratic rabbit politics, menacing owls and badgers, a daring raid on a National Trust cafe (aided by dormice) and a climactic formal race around the lake against a rabbit from the other warren.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n

        \n
        \n
        \n\nrgrassi \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nFebruary 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n A wonderful weekend of play, indeed.
        First, we supported two historian teachers by learning them how to explain history through roleplaying. The argument was "The Unwinnable Armada".
        Then, we had a very nice session of "Levity" my generic framework for role-playing.
        Bye, Rob
        \n

      What did you play this week? (2017)

      \n
      \xab1234567\u202612\xbb

      Comments

        \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nAviatrix \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nFebruary 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        I played in Aviatrix's Unanswered Question and was assured that I managed to be plenty disturbing despite trying to play my character as desperately attempting normality.
        \nIt's the combination of relentless cheerfulness and lack of affect that does it, I think.

        The Unanswered Question, my Tatters of the King in 1950s America for Trail of Cthulhu. The Investigators had been transported to the alternate world of Tellus, where the "Repairer of Reputations" was historical, America was an authoritarian one-party state and the other superpower was the Union of Syndicalist Socialist Republics, aka Communist France. Jimmy Wright was a dead superhero, they found an auto-abattoir of his parallel timeline versions he had killed, and China started World War...er, One; unfortunately, it was nuclear, so also World War Last--all a part of the plan for the King in Yellow to claim the world. Nice work with a smaller ensemble and the return of Lisa playing Millicent.

        Masks of Nyarlathotep, in Trail and for the Tuesday night meetup. I soft-pedaled the infamous Ju-Ju House battle; my reward for being so nice was the players deciding to do Shanghai first. So now I have to figure out how to revamp my Big Bad structure. Nice character play all around, and a fun fight with the two least combat-able characters facing off some cultists. Fortunately they kept the shotgun in the study loaded.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nLisa Padol \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nFebruary 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n I thought it was Charleston who was relentlessly cheerful. Millicent was trying to fade into the background and be helpful, and sometimes forgot that these two things could clash.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nMike_Sands \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nFebruary 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Started a new Apocalypse World (2nd ed) game. We have a battlebabe, brainer, faceless, gunlugger, and savvyhead in a drowned tropical jungle area complete with pirates, overgrown temples, and smart mutant saltwater crocodiles. It was a lot of fun!
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nRafu \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nFebruary 2017 \n edited February 2017
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n More Everway GM-less mash-up on Saturday afternoon. First tested a method of "prepping for" the session (or, rather, basic lonely fun) - that's making up Usurper cards, for those familiar with Everway - and it worked.
        Another awesome session overall, and my character Ink is definitely at the end of his own Fate arc, having productively used magic to the benefit of all while resisting multiple temptations to just seize moar power. Meanwhile, Free got even more badass (he's now capable of demolishing magical barriers, seals and restrictions by hitting them with his fists) and Merry's growing genuinely scary and fucked-up. Like, his "other self" kicked in, walked several miles to the only resident wizard of the realm and straight up murdered him, just like that. I almost freaked out.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nJason_Morningstar \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nMarch 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \nDraug and Dungeon World
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nMarch 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Finished my ongoing mini-campaign based on the Eowyn game. (Discussion was here.)

        The rules contributed nicely to developing play, and I'm very happy with the dynamics that took place.

        The game ended in a dramatic and bloody Tarantino-esque finale, with a messy conflict blossoming into near-carnage, one character losing their life, and two others losing their minds. They likely all ended up in jail or worse. And yet it was incredibly satisfying.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nLisa Padol \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nMarch 2017 \n edited March 2017
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n In Kerberos II: Machinery of Life, Our Heroes took down a giant clockwork contraption that spat fire. This involved a Vine Bomb!

        I also moved to the point in the timeline where Queen Victoria goes all Fisher King with stigmata, and had her call in the two madboys --er, I mean, the esteemed Dr. Alexander and the totally respectable Mr. Green to assist her in regaining enough health to make the speech in Parliament, because big events, if they're to be on stage, should be kicked off, preferably caused by PCs. The two gentlemen were definitely under Her sway -- but not so much so that they neglected to keep samples of her blood. For Science!

        Oh right. Felicity, the clockwork lady, has a flesh and blood dog she named Limehouse for where she acquired him. And Dorian Gray is having to deal with several shocks, ranging from the power of Her Majesty to realizing he might actually care about some individuals other than himself and might perhaps have put their lives at risk by gleefully urging the mob to attack the clockwork contraption, not caring whether, and perhaps even hoping that, the mob might be slaughtered. (Amazingly, it wasn't, due to quick thinking and excellent rolls.)
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nmneme \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nMarch 2017 \n edited March 2017
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        In Kerberos II: Machinery of Life, Our Heroes took down a giant clockwork contraption that spat fire. This involved a Vine Bomb!
        \nFelicity:"What do you mean, you made a an anti-metal bomb?!"\n
        Oh right. Felicity, the clockwork lady, has a flesh and blood dog she named Limehouse for where she acquired him.
        \nAnd because I decided that the Jones family's way of naming dogs was entirely correct, so I (well, Felicity) should name the dog after a place.\n

        clockwork contraption, not caring whether, and perhaps even hoping that, the mob might be slaughtered. (Amazingly, it wasn't, due to quick thinking and excellent rolls.)
        \nWe didn't really have time to play through the well-earned blowback for Dorian urging a mob forward to their presumed deaths, however an effective tactic it ended up being. But there will be time; there will be time.

        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nCaroline_Hobbs \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nMarch 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n At Emerald City Comicon last weekend I ran Follow and Fiasco!
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nRafu \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nMarch 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Oh, last Saturday in our ongoing Everway-hack campaign we got to decide all three main characters had changed enough for their respective Fates to count as resolved, and created new Fates for them all. This took a while, but was very interesting. I hadn't anticipated all character arcs climaxing simultaneously, but that's what happened.
        We had a shorter than usual session, though - logistic constraints - thus, for the first time, we only played half of a "two-parts episode", that is, we didn't go all the way to resolving the Fate of the current Realm within one session. To be continued in two Saturdays.
        \n
        \n
        \n

        \n\nJason_Morningstar \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nMarch 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n More Draug and then, tonight, instead of playing our Dungeon World campaign we just talked and laughed and ate pie.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nMarch 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n An online game of Follow, featuring a dystopian 1950's America where only the young are "pure", for the elderly have been corrupted, contaminated, ruined by a failed government attempt at controlling the masses. We were a group of elderly MKULTRA subjects trying to rebel against the young, strong, rebellious new government.

        Ultimately we succeeded by exposing them to the same chemical.

        Then a playtest of an old game of mine designed to create something like the Princess Bride. It's called "Inconceivable!" I thought it was too flawed to play, but my friend demanded we play it, and, despite some problems, we had some pretty intense gaming and an amazing scene where a witch gave birth to a giant worm (who is prophesied to bring about the end of the world). She believes he is a normal, healthy human child, however.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nLisa Padol \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nMarch 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n 2 character and timeline sessions with 2 different playtest groups for Fall of Cthulhu. In broad strokes, things went roughly the way I thought they would. All the details were utterly unpredictable, but I was correct about what the groups would focus on.

        Now, to find a couple of days where we can get to playing in the timeline...
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nCaesar Slaad \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nMarch 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n It was a "trifecta" week again, where my schedules line up to play 3 games.

        Thursday Night's Black Agents saw the PCs finally investigate the contact they had that was acting strangely. Having rescued him from a Lamia that killed and replaced his wife, the NPC gave them a big info dump that revealed the location of a major base "misguided government secret vampire-tech force". They decided to go after it with no clear reason for doing so. We'll see how that plays out, but I am hoping to get them playing more subtly and less epic fantasy.

        Friday's Mutants & Masterminds game was oddly satisfying. I just dreamed up an evil plot and threw some supervillains together. Some stuff I did that proved oddly effective:
        1) Though I'm not one for lots of NPC banter, I decided to have the PCs get involved in a series of legal hearings regarding the fate of a number of "stormers", superhumans whose powers were recently activated and many of whom performed villainous activities while mind controlled. I did this mainly to introduce some NPCs from the Emerald City setting and establish the fate of several supers (including a subtle clue to upcoming evil plot), but it also got the players invested in the fate of a number of the stormers, like one who really didn't do anything violent, just disruptive, but who was about to become the shared victim of public furor.
        2) Against my normal modus operandi, I totally played one encounter for comedic effect. I don't like making the game seem farcical, but in terms of managing the emotional flow of the game, the encounter was a nice mood lightener leading into the heavier investigation and finale. In addition, one of the players opted not to fight, but make the over-the-top self-parodying villain reconsider his antisocial ways.

        Saturday's Pathfinder was for the most part a straight up dungeon crawl. However, to access the site, they did have to convince two elders of the island's three clans to approve their expedition to the taboo island, which had some interesting lead-up roleplaying.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nAsIf \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nMarch 2017 \n edited March 2017
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n On March 12th I ran a game of DayTrippers for the Legends of Tabletop crew. It was also a playtest for my latest RunSheet* - a diagrammatic method of narrative control - which ensured that Narrative Arc and Story Beats were nicely paced without railroading, Psychic Content was integrated and consistent with cinematic expectations, and the whole thing came in at exactly the allotted time.

        In this session, characters played by John Haremza, Vincent LaRosa and Jesse Pyne entered one of my strangest scenarios yet: an unstable Dream World that reaches into your head and toys with your emotions. Talking book people, sexy flowers, and a giant baby were found. Much freaking out and a little bit of involuntary urination was involved.

        Here's the AP video...
        http://www.legendsoftabletop.com/?p=2520

        * More info on my Patreon: https://www.patreon.com/asif

        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nAviatrix \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nMarch 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \nMasks of Nyarlathotep in Trail of Cthulhu: After finding the elusive Jack Brady, the intrepid quartet visited a downtown warehouse of the mysterious businessman Ho Fong; Marty the railway brakeman made a good impression on a fellow laborer who is probably a member of the Communist party. That evening they dined at Ho Fong's house; he invited them to stay over. The archaeologist and his psychiatrist wife discovered an obscene shrine; the professor was drugged; and Marty attacked Ho Fong himself. A nice serial-style cliffhanger!

        Fate of Cthulhu chargen session: Dr. Kate Octavian invented time travel in 2060, using technology leftover from humanity's triumph over the rising of the Old Ones. She sent a team back in time to try and prevent the rising anyway; when she stepped out of the nulltime sphere, she found herself in her darkest timeline, with humanity destroyed and the Old Ones ruling the world. It took ten years, but she sent her consciousness back to this timeline's 2035-version of herself and got a spot on one of the teams being sent back to stop the rising. Now (2018) she'll have to contend with her precocious 18-year old PhD self, a goth slacker who calls herself "Eight". Riotous good fun and I can't wait to see how the dynamics of my PC and Josh's "Eight" play out.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n

      • \n
        \n

        \n\nMike_Sands \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nMarch 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n More Apocalypse World for me! We finished the big end-of-first-session battle, and then spent the rest of the session in recovery, exploring the world and meeting new people, and looking into the fallout of the battle.

        \n
        \n
        \n\nLisa Padol \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nMarch 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Carmilla Sanction, where one of the players noted that it was the perfect moment for me to call for a Heat roll, as the group was dragging around a one-handed (cuz one of them had shot it off) would-be assassin, whom they'd gagged (because I'd decided to bring Alraune back, with a grudge).

        Heat was 8 at that point. One agent used 7 points of Medic to make it look like they were taking the poor injured woman to a hospital. One more point was used to bandage her up, whereupon the group realized their captive was bleeding a greenish sort of red...
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nBen_Robbins \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nMarch 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \nFollow, Fiasco and two games of Microscope at our story games area at Emerald City Comicon. All fantastic. One Microscope game particularly was a textbook example of building on each other's contributions to make an unexpected whole. We're making the palette for our story of alien civilizations in collision:

        player 1: "I want a race of robots."
        player 2: "I want genocide."
        player 3: "I want mysticism, like spiritual beliefs."
        player 4: "I want a god-like race of aliens."

        As our history unfolds, the robots, who we learn were created by humans after we discover remnants of mysterious Ancient technology, make contact with the not-as-dead-as-we-thought Ancients and achieve enlightenment. The rival alien races promptly unite to eradicate them: enlightened robot genocide.

        Later in play we find out that the Ancients had previously tried bringing enlightenment to the other races -- including us humans, which explained our first contact -- but had failed or been rejected. Only the poor robots were young and innocent enough as a race to achieve enlightenment\u2026

        And in our Follow game we played cowboys trying to save our town from Godzilla (ahem, "the Great Horned Devil") in the Wild West. Best Dragon quest ever, at least until the next one.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nRafu \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nMarch 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n I was at a local indie role-playing meetup last weekend, for the best part of two days. I hosted four games there:\n
          \n
        • Marc Hobbs's Eden. I was very excited about this game and looking forward to playing it, but it turned out quite disappointing. The setup part was, in my opinion, really good, but then the scenes we played turned out very bland - almost like we were missing something from our setup, actually. Most of the time, we were feeling around almost blandly for events and conflicts without actually finding any. We wrapped up our story after three rounds of scenes due to time constraints, but it didn't feel finished at all.
          • \n
        • Eppy Ravachol's Sorceress Bloody Sorceress, which I'd selected mostly because I needed a really quick game to squeeze into a 120' fraction of a longer slot due to, uhm, reasons. We had a large-ish group who weren't especially focused, but apparently fun was had. We rolled the bear sorceress: what a lovely character! Would definitely play again, if I could do so with a group of focused swords & sorcery aficionados.
          • \n
        • Ashley Griffiths's What You Wish For was definitely the highlight of the convention. Barbara had already played this game twice, but I hadn't. It was an intense, affecting experience. It did poke at a few sore points, that's almost by design, but I enjoyed it immensely nonetheless. Even the fact it was late in the evening when we started playing and everybody was tired and sleepy couldn't make the game fall flat. I strongly recommend giving it a try if you haven't.
          • \n
        \nThe fourth game was an early playtest of a new design I'm working on - something I've named "RAD", now with the subtitle "Social Justice Science Fiction". It was both fun to play and a useful test, confirming what I hoped it would confirm and yielding a wealth of useful notes and suggestions.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n

        \n\nSteve_Hickey \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nMarch 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Rapture: End of Days. We're running a 1-on-1 game via skype, pitching it as an X-Com meets The Expanse meets Event Horizon full-on invasion scenario.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nLisa Padol \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nMarch 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Yesterday, Kerberos Club, where I wasn't quite sure where the plot was going longer term, so I did the short term thing that always works. "Who's holding the ball tonight?" It worked. Various dialogue bits:

        Ladon: My family tends to do that.
        Dorian: What, blackmail pretty boys to protect you?
        Ladon: No, cause me agita. I have to keep moving, or I'll probably take root.
        Dorian: I didn't know that was a threat.

        Ladon: Our elders are making plans without our knowledge.
        Dr. Alexander: Good for them.
        Felicity: Well, _that's_ a surprise. (yep, sarcasm)
        Dorian: _Who_ are our elders? (as he is likely older than most of them)

        Ladon: I believe I have gotten us both a little wound up.
        Felicity (a clockwork heiress): Excuse me!
        He apologized at once.

        Ladon (who has earlier gotten Dorian to agree to explain to a pushy noble why Ladon won't let his (Ladon's) noble father (not the same as the pushy noble) formally acknowledge him: I may have to let my father acknowledge me.
        Felicity: That's a good idea.
        Ladon: People like me aren't allowed to be that stupid.

        Today: Monsterhearts with sneak peek pack preceded by enough brainstorming to know a) what the papers the PCs retrieved said, at least broadly and b) why the fae war started when the game did.

        Somehow, we had a mirroring of themes or something that I'd honestly not planned. I wound up falling back on a fae war to push things when they needed a push (which is likely lazy of me, but likely something I fell back on because it's an easy thing to push and then step back from) a session or four in. First session, we had the running "how long can we put off the pop quiz about the (American) Civil War?"

        So, the werewolf (actually, raised-by-wolves, not shapeshifter) got a See Me on the test, cuz she wrote "Brothers fought and that was bad." Her adoptive father spent some time trying to explain the deeper levels of the Civil War. The next day, the teacher moved on to Reconstruction, and... we had this warped sequence of everyone trying to translate into their own idiom, and this out of character realization that all of this paralleled the fae war.

        Various dialogue bits:

        Werewolf: I still don't money.

        Witch (who's just inadvertently convinced his mother that the Queen is not merely having an affair with his father (which is not the case), but also that she's dealing drugs (true, sort of) and that either he or his father are taking them (false): You need to work on your image.
        Queen: You're helping SO much!

        Fae: I'm just worried [the fae as a whole, or at least one side of them] will defenestrate me.
        Queen: That's a human thing.
        Fae: That's bigoted!
        Queen: No, it's glass -- I'm pretty sure glass is a human thing.
        Fae: I don't think you need glass to defenestrate someone. You just need a window.

        Werewolf: The rabbits are way scarier than the woods

        Veridian's player: I will note this has been the most class and the most acadamic I have seen in any Monsterhearts session ever.

        Witch: But why did she promise the entire line?
        Me: Well, demons.
        Werewolf's Player: "Well, demons" is a pretty good answer to almost anything.

        NPC: I just asked [Werewolf] if [Another NPC] was also raised by wolves, and she punched me in the nose!
        Fae: If you say that again, I'M gonna hit you in the nose!

        Fae: He might not be all bad sides even if he's pure evil.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nAviatrix \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nMarch 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \nThe Unanswered Question (1950s Tatters of the King in ToC): After returning from the alternate world of Tellus, the Investigators travelled to Kansas. Jimmy discovered that helpful NPC Beth was actually the new timeline version of Betty Auckland, his violent and helpful gal Friday whose history had been wiped out by messing with time; a phantom shift allowed them to meet Cassilda of Carcosa during her time as singer for a Manhattan, Kansas speakeasy in 1931; Temperance debuted her nun/vigilante outfit; and Charleston's literal shadow side escaped and began causing havoc. A bit uneven but I was happier with my prep this time.

        Can I note we live in a golden age of fast research? I wanted to get a feel for what Manhattan, Kansas looked like in 1956: so of course on Youtube there was a film made by the Manhattan Chamber of Commerce ("Manhattan: Our Town") dating from 1955!

        Masks of Nyarlathotep: We picked up after the cliffhanger from last session, with the sinister and vedddy cultured Mr. Ho Fong locked in mystical combat with the Investigators. Professor Chamberlain's soul ventured far in time and space and picked up a stalking Nyarlathotep; playboy archaeologist Winston went to extreme levels to protect his wife; and Marty's connection with Zhou Enlai and the Shanghai Communist Party proved useful. And things were going so well until Ho Fong reincarnated into the body of his daughter, murdered everyone in their pension, and nearly killed Professor Chamberlain...fortunately the Green Gang had a reasonable (exorbitant) fee for getting them a hideout...
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nCaesar Slaad \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nMarch 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Went to DC Gameday last weekend:
        - Played Tales of the Loop (From the Loop?) The GM Americanized the setting. It was pretty fun and worked okay, though I get the sense that the GM really needs to take charge of regulating the failures, because it seems like a dice pool/success system THAT LOOKS FOR SIXES is fraught with failure.
        - Ran Traveller. I created a little sandbox subsector that I can take to run at game days or when regular scheduled games collapsed. One of my friends got a copy of the old starter Traveller and wanted me to run a session, so I did. Bog standard proto-Firefly "merchants get desperate to make ends meet and things go sideways" sort of scenario.

        Weekly games:
        - Ran Night's Black Agents. The players plan an assault of the secret oil platform base with no clear tactical objective. I had nothing specific for them to do, so I decided while they were gathering resources to hit them with blowback from the Conspiracy and Edom that was way overdue.
        - Ran Mutants & Masterminds:
        1) One of my players accidentally created the rough equivalent of "Angel Summoner", having never seen the skits. (If you don't know what I am talking about, look here.)
        2) I really love it when my players and dice rolls cooperate to make the adventure climax better than I envisioned. In short, the rough equivalent to the "Ultron ending" in an Avengers comic that I never envisioned happening in a game, happened.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nMike_Sands \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nMarch 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        - Played Tales of the Loop (From the Loop?) The GM Americanized the setting. It was pretty fun and worked okay, though I get the sense that the GM really needs to take charge of regulating the failures, because it seems like a dice pool/success system THAT LOOKS FOR SIXES is fraught with failure.
        \nI found, running it, that it worked well. Mostly a failed roll is a complication in the mystery, rather than "you failed what you tried to do".

        Also the GM may not have Americanised it - there's an alternate US setting in the book.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nLisa Padol \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nMarch 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        Can I note we live in a golden age of fast research? I wanted to get a feel for what Manhattan, Kansas looked like in 1956: so of course on Youtube there was a film made by the Manhattan Chamber of Commerce ("Manhattan: Our Town") dating from 1955!
        \nI found stuff like that about Malta. I found this... thing that claimed to be about Tibet, but... Let's just say that I Am Skeptical.\n
        Masks of Nyarlathotep: We picked up after the cliffhanger from last session, with the sinister and vedddy cultured Mr. Ho Fong locked in mystical combat with the Investigators. Professor Chamberlain's soul ventured far in time and space and picked up a stalking Nyarlathotep; playboy archaeologist Winston went to extreme levels to protect his wife; and Marty's connection with Zhou Enlai and the Shanghai Communist Party proved useful. And things were going so well until Ho Fong reincarnated into the body of his daughter, murdered everyone in their pension, and nearly killed Professor Chamberlain...fortunately the Green Gang had a reasonable (exorbitant) fee for getting them a hideout...
        \nMystical combat? How does that work? Folks were sent into time? Or out of body?
        \n

        \n\nAviatrix \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nMarch 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Mostly it was by summoning a fire vampire :-)

        When I ran the Tibet section of Eternal Lies, I found two useful things: one was a picture book I got in epub form about Mt. K----, the other was finding some really crackpot websites about the aforementioned mountains; I did in fact use some of them. (Crackpot websites are the gold of the Cthulhu/supernatural GM; I have a ton bookmarked about the various places I've put in games. Plus a couple of "Weird USA" books.)

        \n I'm playing in my sixth game of play by post OKULT.

        It is a bit slow moving, but it hasn't ground to a halt yet. I give it a 30% chance of being completed before it is abandoned. All things considered that is not so bad.

        \n\nRafu \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nMarch 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Last weekend, we played more of my Everway-hack-thing, getting to complete an episode we'd started two weeks before. It was our first interrupted episode - everything worked OK. Playing it over two sessions means it felt like a loooong episode... Being positioned right after all three main characters resolved and updated their Fates (worked out some of their issues, basically) it felt like a huge two-part episode bridging two seasons of some TV show. We can't wait to play again (which won't happen in a while, though).
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nWarriorMonk \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nMarch 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n I really enjoyed our last D&D 5e session, where a PC got a ring of 3 wishes... with only two of them and wasted one to ask for a sandwich... which had been the exact same wish the previous owner of the ring had asked.

        Then the party opened a sealed place where about a hundred inmortal wizard tieflings were sealed 350 years ago along with a sphere of infinite power that they couldn't use and two aspects of a deity, one positive and one negative. Most of them had eaten themselves or others due to hunger and were basically insane and/or suicidal. The most functional were four of them that had multiclassed to monks.

        The party found out that all the major threats to the setting were caused by them trying to escape unsuccessfully. On the ensuing fight, the party liberates the negative aspect of the god, darkness covers the world, the tieflings rush in masse to the exit... and the player with the ring of wishes says "I want to go back in time!". As awesomely fun as it sounded I couldn't resist and so she goes back... right before they get into the sealed place.

        She manages to convince them to do things different this time. They choose right and liberate the positive aspect of the deity, they defeat the tieflings, slice the orb of infinite power in two... and then a baby tarrasque ate half of it.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n

        \n\nMike_Sands \n\n\n

        \n More Apocalypse World. They found the source of a plague, and I don't think it was at all what they expected.

        Also Pity made an enemy of Roark and let him live, so I guess that's gonna end well.

        \n
        \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nMarch 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Playtesting continues on my Princess Bride-inspired GMless adventure game, Inconceivable. Some things are working wonderfully and others are confusing. The best part is that dealing with the confusing things is making is discover new techniques and approaches to roleplaying we haven't tried before. It's been a really interesting ride! (And really, really fun gaming, despite the hitches.)
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nJonathan Nicol \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nMarch 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Had a wonderful time playing Blades in the Dark. We're playing a group of arms dealers with links to the Skovlander refugees. The PC who got our group together is a former Skovlander guerilla fighter. I am playing a former imperial sniper and street rat from Crow's Foot.

        This was my first session, but the other players third. We started the session with a meetcute with my character and two other PCs at a bar in Charhallow. My character got connected with the group through Hoxley, the group's contact and source of weapons, an Imperial Army Quartermaster of Skovland descent who my character served with. There was this great moment where my character eyes the others down tactically and realizes he had once shot the guerilla fighter.

        We were rudely interrupted in our staredown by a group of anti-Skov hooligans who started making trouble in the bar. Runa, the guerilla fighter, talked the group down with an assist by me. They were right pissed off by it thanks to a devil's bargain I suggested. I pushed my luck, Surveying them as they left and found out there was divided leadership.

        We decided we needed to know more about this group of hooligans and so we went to another bar and asked around. We found out they were part of a larger True Duskvol gang, financed by some noble with family issues.

        Khara, our group's Iruvian Spider went to some high society functions and uncovered some twisted stuff about the financier I can get into if there's any interest. Meanwhile Candros Slane, my former imperial sniper, Casta, his bounty hunter friend, and Runa hunted down where the group meets. I rolled really well on my Hunt roll and was able to find the bar the True Duskvol types conduct their meetings at and when they were meeting next.

        After a little bit of debate we decided we were going to take out this gang's leadership before they could come for us and take their bar for ourselves. The plan was relatively simple. Candros would sneak in the back. Runa, Khara, and our gang would show up front loaded to bear. Candros managed to sneak in, but was discovered by a member of the waitstaff. Candros is not a very nice man so he tossed a throwing knife in that fool's throat. Good thing he did because trouble could have been coming our way if he didn't.

        We critted our engagement roll so Runa, Khara and the gang were able to catch the leadership of these True Duskvol types unaware. Candros laid down a bunch of suppressive fire, requiring the enemy to bring up tables to use for cover while Runa did her thing, and Khara helped. One massive firefight later we have a bar which counts as Local Graft, a bunch of Heat and Rep, and a decimated gang with -2 faction status. Candros also almost stressed out. I was one stress away from gaining a trauma in the first session.

        Enter downtime. Candros and Casta meet at his house and make plans to search for Candros' wife and reflect on how Candros wants to make a better life for his kids. They also canvas the neighborhood for signs of where she might have gone. Candros does the insensitive not noticing a possible love interest thing.

        Runa and Khara spend time researching ancient Skovland old ways and rituals.

        That was an immense amount of fun. There's a bunch of cool interplays between the PCs, including a shared enemy of Veleris, the spy between our two hounds. Lots of neat racial tension. Also we killed a lot of people. That's a lot of angry ghosts.

        Right now we're at the point where we have a lot of Rep and not much Coin. We need to make some money if we're going to go up in Tier. We also might want to reconsider our fast and loud ethos.

        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nLisa Padol \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nMarch 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Played in Princess: the Hopeful, discovering that yes, really and truly, too much heat will make me zone out in the middle of serious drama. This sucks. We'll try a cooler apartment next time, and hopefully, both logical venues will be sufficiently air conditioned for the summer. (Some NYC apartments have central heating that can't be lowered. It's a thing.)

        (Running through the variables -- I had sufficient sleep, sufficient but not excessive food, was sitting in the coolest spot in the room, but moving to the point of just sitting back meant it suddenly got a Whole Lot Warmer. Being outside the apartment cleared my head in a minute. This was way, way worse than the EL game where a hardback chair and a seat by the open window fixed the problem.)

        Ran Kereberos II: Machinery of Life, where folks teased about whether there'd be actual actiony plot. I had prepared a few things, but one of the minor ones didn't happen for at least an hour, which was Not My Doing, as I mentioned it a few times. This is fine -- I'm quite used to the Kerbereans going off on tangents, but for the record, this was Not My Doing.

        I also had maps to show folks likely routes to get from point A to point B, resulting in:

        1. One player expressing bogglement at this laminated paper that was not a touch screen. (Yes, he was joking. He knows I used to work at Hagstrom.)

        2. Looking up when the Suez Canal was constructed. In game time, it's still under construction.

        3. Wondering at the state of railroads in various countries.

        4. Reminding me that it's not just my sense of scale that's off when it comes to India, but also that the map I was using had some extra countries that did not exist in the mid-19th century.

        We also had terrible jokes based on previous silliness. In the first Kerberos game, we established that there were living daguerreotypes, known as fleople. There had been one for each of the PCs, causing some confusion as the doubles -- naturally -- committed crimes. That was all cleared up, and the fleople were now integrated into Paris society. One of them had a cat who was still around.

        PC: So, Flartin is fline?

        Me: Yes, Flartin is fline. He has flittens!

        The doctor was fascinated by how the fleople worked, and explained that a) they are two dimensional, sure, but still have mass, and b) one basically operates by reaching into another dimension.

        PC: Wait, do the fleople have flillnesses?

        Another PC: Of course -- they have the flu!

        Folks still did shopping and tourism, and visited various cathedrals and Restaurant Laperouse (and the player introducing it sent a link that mentioned the fascinating French laws about adultery, and told us about ortolans), of course.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n

        \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nMarch 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n@Adam_Dray: is that related to City of Brass?
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nSteve_Hickey \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nMarch 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n I came back to our Masks game after a few weeks' absence. Fantastic interpersonal drama. And I think we're going to deal with our long-running frustrations about how to handle investigations in Masks by adapting the Investigate a Mystery move from Monster of the Week. Now our group just needs to decide if it's a basic move or a move that individuals can buy as an advance.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nAdam_Dray \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nMarch 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        @Adam_Dray: is that related to City of Brass?
        \nNo no. It's a hack of David Black's The Black Hack, which is a super-lean and awesomely elegant OSR interpretation of D&D. The entire text is OGLed so it's easy to reskin it for other things. I reskinned it for urban fantasy, in the "modern Earth people encounter weird stuff in their city and ultimately end up in a dungeon adventure."

        I ran a playtest of my new ruleset. Eventually, I'll put that up for sale on DriveThruRPG.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n

        \n\nJeff_B_Slater \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nApril 2017 \n edited April 2017
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n We played Montsegur 1244 last week (I think it would've worked better if everyone attempted a more somber tone). This week we played Shock: Social Science Fiction (I was so tired I just played an audience member and still couldn't really follow the game). I want to play both these games again, so I can get a better handle on what they can do. Tomorrow I'll probably be playing Fiasco (with the London Gangster playset) or maybe Fall of Magic, and on Thursday I'll be playing Fiasco with the Game of Thrones playset.
        \n
        \n
        \n

      What did you play this week? (2017)

      \n
      \xab1234567\u202612\xbb

      Comments

        \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nrgrassi \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nApril 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n This weekend there's been a wonderful convention in Italy.
        I've run a lot of demonstration of my games.
        I'm completely exhausted but happy.
        Rob
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nLisa Padol \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nApril 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Kerberos Club, Machinery of Life, saw our Kerbereans reach India.

        Dorian Grey: Will you be our elephant?
        Felicity, clockwork fairy and shapeshifter: No.
        Dorian: Well, that puts a damper on that plan.

        Ladon, gardener extraordinaire, winced at a dinner party, where the British served Good British Food, even if they had to do it out of tins, and decided that he would at least plant a seed in folks' mind that they really should try some of the local cuisine.

        The others pointed out to him that for that seed to germinate, he'd need to be staying in Mumbai (which, of course, they were calling Bombay) for at least six months, and the group had Missions to Perform for Queen and Country. So, he would have to use scale to make up for not having time. Fortunately, Felicity had the resources and the title to provide Scale, even without turning into an elephant.

        Dorian: You do your father proud.
        Ladon (a noble's byblow): I hate you. Thank you very much.

        The players did a credible job of walking the line one has in any game where one doesn't want to ignore the historical context or the fact that the PCs were not egalitarians -- and three of the four of them were very much under the mystical sway of Queen Victoria, who, at this point in the Kerberos Timeline as adapted for this group, is well on her way to Goddesshood, for better and worse.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nJason_Morningstar \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nApril 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n The Cold Ruins of Last Life
        Make Haste!
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nMike_Sands \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nApril 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n The first three games (prologue + game 1 & 2) of Seafall, the latest legacy boardgame. I'm really enjoying it so far - you're still following along a programmed story like Pandemic Legacy, but the fact that everything is triggered directly by in-game player actions makes it feel more like you're driving things.

        Each game is pretty long, though! Even our game 2, which ended very quick in "turns played" was a little over two hours.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nLisa Padol \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nApril 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Monsterhearts, where we wondered how long hexes are supposed to last, and if indefinitely, what one does if the Witch's player nerfs someone who's all about the hitting.

        This didn't happen, but the Witch's player brought it up because he came this close to doing it to the Werewolf. She'd punched the school nurse, and if she'd continued, he would have bound her to be incapable of causing physical harm.

        All reasonable in this group, but I am wondering whether it's come up before and how it's been handled.

        Mind, the nurse and Werewolf are likely on a collision course, for Reasons, but that's another matter.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nSteve_Hickey \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nApril 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Masks (where we had the third of our original five characters retire).
        Manic Pixie Dream Girl (a socially brutal 200 Word RPG).
        An unnamed status game from Keith Johnstone's 'Impro'.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nApril 2017 \n edited April 2017
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Started a short-term campaign of Monsterhearts.

        We used my Fiasco playset to start the game, which was extremely successful (link here: It All Ends in Tears). We've got two kids who are bonding because they were both witness to a murder, a pool that can give you visions of the past, and a creepy janitor who, in his youth, made a seminal indie film. On top of that, it turns out our Werewolf has a copy of the master key, opening any room in the school. That's surely not good to lead anywhere good...

        Two of the PCs are former flames, who promised to each other they'd be together forever. However, it turns out that one of them meant it when he said it. The other... only said it because she didn't think she'd ever actually see him again. Now, a few years later, they unexpectedly find themselves at the same school. Tragic!

        The only drawback is that we ended up with two characters who are social outcasts, and then third player decided his character was "the new kid in town"... which makes giving them a stake in school affairs difficult. We will see how that turns out!

        We'll be testing my new harm rules (Descriptive harm), as well as - if they come up - perhaps the Death Moves floating around on G+ (pretty intense!).

        Also, wondering how many rules changes from the 2nd Ed Preview to use, or whether to stick to the 1ed rules for now.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nLisa Padol \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nApril 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        Also, wondering how many rules changes from the 2nd Ed Preview to use, or whether to stick to the 1ed rules for now.
        \nAn interesting question, especially as I've been informed that there have been some changes since the sneak peek pack.

        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nCaroline_Hobbs \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nApril 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n I played an absolutely stellar 4-player game of Shock: Social Science Fiction yesterday at Story Games Seattle. Our issues were misinformation, biological pre-determinism, breeding control, and giving up control of your own decisions, so our shock was obviously a meditation technique that allowed you to influence the baby's biology during the pregnancy. Lots of messed up family situations. *so good*
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nApril 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Sounds amazing!

        Lisa, I wanted to stick to the 1ed rules (for the sake of clarity), but even in the first two scenes we ran into an issue which was better solved in the sneak peek... so now I'm reconsidering.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nBen_Robbins \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nApril 2017 \n edited April 2017
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        I played an absolutely stellar 4-player game of Shock: Social Science Fiction yesterday at Story Games Seattle. Our issues were misinformation, biological pre-determinism, breeding control, and giving up control of your own decisions, so our shock was obviously a meditation technique that allowed you to influence the baby's biology during the pregnancy. Lots of messed up family situations. *so good*
        \nSo good! Caroline is politely avoiding mentioning that her character's story goal was to use "gestation meditation" to hack his teenage daughter's pregnancy, whether she likes it or not. Yep, that's right: it's not just the mother that can do it. Little circles of people can hover around a pregnant woman and alter the baby's genetic makeup. And everybody's doing it.

        I also played a Kingdom game where our community was a remote, 19th century Nordic whaling town. We were caught between our old traditions and superstitions and the modern influences of the Company that built a monstrous new flensing building smack in the middle of the docks. Everyone else was new to Kingdom and most were total strangers, but as the pot started to simmer the conflicts and interpersonal drama got wonderfully intense. We played until the store kicked us out and then stood around shaking hands and congratulating each other.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nLisa Padol \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nApril 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Playtested Fate of Cthulhu and hit the bumps we expected to hit, so we now have data to send Evil Hat. This is a successful playtest. Bumps aside, this was a fun game, with a ton of banter. Oh, and a rail gun. And Successes at Costs like "ice cream -- with hot fudge" and "you got the job!"
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nFelan \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nApril 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \nDungeon World: My enlightenment rationalist plague doctor who refuses to believe in the supernatural is not handling exposure to the supernatural very well.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nRafu \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nApril 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \nEverway-hack-mashup, whence our Spherewalkers finally encountered a justly-governed, almost idyllic city, but Alessio's character managed to start yet another revolution nonetheless and topple the government - with the usual bloodbath - based on a slight misunderstanding. Thus, he brought ruin upon the realm.
        Sure, the council-members were actually monsters in disguise, and quite tortured about their duplicitous nature, but they were doing a great job of governing the city and everybody but them was indeed happy! Barbara's PC and mine were quite sympathetic with these monster-people, you see, out of similarity. But it turned out the vision of a ruined, ancient city they were trying to rebuild anew was actually a vision of the future: the ruination our actions precipitated. Everything was very psycho-trippy swords 'n sorcery, and very sad.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nLisa Padol \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nApril 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n "The Carmilla Sanction", where the PCs killed Carmilla. My favorite exchange:

        Player: Unless I have a telleuric net.

        Me: I would call for a REALLY Large Preparedness Spend.

        Player: Right, so I have a telleuric net.

        Me: ...?

        Player: MOS Preparedness!

        Which, as Kenneth Hite can tell you, is only fair, because I did something like that to him.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nmiedvied \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nApril 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Started a pretty great Sprawl game "PbP," on google via ... well, more via google drive than google hangouts.

        There's a constant side-talk via a google hangouts chat; individual player actions for legwork phases each happen in their own google doc (with back-and-forth between GM and relevant PC's IC on the doc, and OOC/rolls happening in the comments sidebar); and we created a separate doc formatted and coloured to look like an IRC window, where we enter an ongoing IC chat between the team as they coordinate legwork.

        I haven't seen yet how this will play out for the Action phase, but so far, it's been pretty great.

        Also my first attempt at playing a cerebral, non-combative PC in Sprawl (a Soldier), and it's working out pretty damn well. I'll have to see how he holds up in Action, though.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nHopeless_Wanderer \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nApril 2017 \n edited April 2017
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Played a session of my Shenmo, \u795e\u9b54, "Gods and Demons" play-set for Pocket Danger Patrol. Threats included: a village cursed to age rapidly, an ancient tree spirit in the nearby forest who was wronged by the villagers, the tree's guardian bear-demon, his children, some flower fairies living in an abandoned temple on a hill in the woods, a magical fountain with sleeping waters in the temple; and mural of fairy-land that acts as a gate/trap on one of the temple walls, and some children kidnapped by the fairies.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nLisa Padol \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nApril 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Helped co-gm the larp The Last Seder, which everyone knows going in is on certain rails.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\n2097 \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nApril 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        Spherewalkers
        \nReally makes me happy to see Everway hit the table\u2665

        For me, if prep is play then al-Qadim & doing "same-page"-convos with players.
        If not, it's been 43 days since my last RPG session.

        Board games: But, I played two sessions of Shadow Hunters and one of Imperial yesterday! Shadow Hunters was amazing but it outstayed its welcome pretty close to the end of the second session. Imperial, I don't like it. I even suggested it because I had forgotten how much I dislike it. For my taste, extremely kingmaker:y and political games can't be long or brainburn:y/calculate:y, and Imperial is both. In my group the slang term for such games are "Unos", because the card game Uno is kingmakery and political game that is very breezy and mindless and something I don't really get worked up about and thus don't mind playing. And once I said about some big political thinky AT game "Ugh, four hours and that much brain usage is a bit much for an Uno" and it stuck. So ironically "Uno"-games now in our extremely local jargon are long and brainburny games with more than two teams. (So, \u624b\u8c08 is not an "Uno" because it has only two teams and thus the long hours spent thinking isn't effed up by a third party.)

        Don't worry I don't plan on writing about every board game I play (Pandemic Legacy was an exception because it's also a story game). I was just feeling kind of sad & lonely today and wanted to write about this + was already answering Rafu + mentioning my "prep is play" thoughts. Even though... yeah... perhaps we could start a "What did you prep this week?" thread?
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n

        \n\nBen_Robbins \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nApril 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Yes, let's keep this thread to just reporting what we played.

        I played some Microscope Chronicle at Story Games Seattle, following the owners and implantees of a single cybernetic eye, and got into big, serious issues of humanity and futurism. A very "Ghost in the Shell" vibe.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nLisa Padol \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nApril 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Kerberos II: Machinery of Life, where I took a plot seed from Victoriana's Jewel of Empire. During the Indian Rebellion (which I think is the current correct term? My apologies if it is not.), one leader who's worked with the governor of Bombay in the past sent an embassy through proposing an alliance for similar situations (fighting off undead hordes), but only one person got through, and he was mortally wounded -- well, it would've been mortal if Dr. Alexander hadn't been there.

        Anyway, the governor sent the PCs to escort the survivor and his own man to the leader, as he's not certain this is a legitimate offer, but would like to build bridges. En route, a British colonel intercepted them, gave them quarters for the evening, and offered to escort them.

        Naturally, this was a trap, as he'd made a horrible mistake attacking the embassy, assuming that these folks were obviously making trouble, and so he came up with the kind of plan that the Jaegermonsters in Girl Genius deconstructed (http://www.girlgeniusonline.com/comic.php?date=20031017#.WPbntme1ty0): "Dis is turnink into one of DOSE plans... de kind vere ve kill everyone dot notices dot ve's killin' people?"

        Obviously, he had to kill the PCs and the folks they were traveling with to keep this from getting out.

        So, obviously, the PCs made short work of this plan.
        Ladon, the quiet middle class plant mage, made stairs explode with roots as there was no way anyone was murdering his wife and kids, thank you.
        Felicity turned into a clockwork angel again, getting the vast majority of the soldiers to surrender as she was an agent of Queen Victoria (and this is the point in Kerberos where folks stop praying for her and start praying to her...)
        Dorian tried to convince soldiers inside the building that orders had changed, and although deceit is his specialty, I rolled a +4 on Fudge / Fate dice, so obviously, these were the most trusted of the colonel's men. So, Dorian stabbed one, got dragged off to the colonel, made the colonel think that Dorian was offering to disguise himself as the colonel so the colonel would get away, slit the colonel's throat from behind, managed to not get shot by the soldiers, and looked at the tableaux of the dead thinking, "Blast it, I should have tried to get the colonel to shoot himself first. That would have been more artistic, and I could always have slit his throat later if that didn't work!"
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nApril 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Playing my own stuff this week, due to Monsterhearts getting postponed.

        Continuing playtesting on Inconceivable, the Princess Bride-inspired collaborative RPG, and had a really unusually "hot" session of Musette with random non-gamers, which I wrote up here:

        The Best Things in Gaming: a Real-Life Illustrator

        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nPatrickRBG \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nApril 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n I am running the pathfinder adventure path called Strange Aeons. It is an Eldritch Horror/Call of Cthulhu inspired campaign. I have four players who are all pretty new to the system but two are also fairly new to rpgs in general. They have however all really bought in to the setting, which has made it spooky and allowed for some amazing roleplay. We are nearly done the first of six books and everyone is really enjoying it so far.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nCaesar Slaad \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nApril 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n I'm playing Strange Aeons in a odd-Saturday group.

        My monthly Pathfinder group has exploded! There were three players with sketchy attendance I wasn't expecting to show up, so I invited a new player... then everyone showed up! If everyone shows up next time, that will be 9 players! I recruited a rules-archivist and an initiative tracker to help keep things moving.

        Still in the supers groove. I made a "simple" Mutants & Masterminds scenario to run at an upcoming game day, and premiered it with my home group. It felt like a mess when I was running it because there was lots of missing connective tissue I had to make up on the fly, but when it was over, I felt like the game was pretty good and we had lots of fun!
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nJason_Morningstar \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nApril 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \nPerseverant and something we don't have rules for yet called The Tower; here's the pitch:

        Kittyhawk Tower (known by residents as \u201cthe Tower\u201d) is a residential extended care facility in Xenia, Ohio. It is owned and operated by the United States Department of Veterans Affairs and serves as both a veteran\u2019s home and gerontology research facility. Due to its location near Dayton and Wright-Patterson Air Force Base, it primarily serves senior Air Force veterans.

        The first floor contains reception, intake, visitation, recreation and administrative areas.

        Floors two through four are general population two-resident suites.

        Floor five is a secure research floor; all the residents served in the 2750th Air Base Wing as firefighters or the 97th Fighter-Interceptor Squadron as mechanics at Wright-Patterson Air Force Base between 1951 and 1954. During active service they were exposed to high concentrations of perfluorooctane sulfonate (PFOS) in firefighting foam and aircraft hydraulic fluid. Numerous longitudinal studies are underway documenting the effects of PFOS exposure over the resident\u2019s lifetimes. Because of the nature of environmental PFOS contamination, access to floor five residents is limited by agreement and they have their own visitation and recreation facilities.

        Floor six and seven contain laboratory and research-administration space.

        * * *

        So make up a man roughly 85 years old who was an Air Force firefighter or mechanic. Probably enlisted but not necessarily. Your guy agreed to join the study in exchange for a comfortable place to live among friends for the rest of his life. He has between zero and one people who care about him and he is either divorced, unmarried or widowed. Also pick two or more from this list:

        Arthritis / osteoporosis
        Heart disease
        Cancer
        Depression
        Respiratory disease
        Diabetes / obesity
        Substance abuse
        Thyroid / Liver / Kidney problems (PFOS related)
        Interesting problem of your choice
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nJeff_B_Slater \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nApril 2017 \n edited April 2017
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        Yes, let's keep this thread to just reporting what we played.

        I played some Microscope Chronicle at Story Games Seattle, following the owners and implantees of a single cybernetic eye, and got into big, serious issues of humanity and futurism. A very "Ghost in the Shell" vibe.
        \nThis sounds really amazing! Do you ever record your sessions, Ben? I would love to listen to this :-)
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nJeff_B_Slater \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nApril 2017 \n edited April 2017
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n We played a simplified form of Polaris for one-shots; it didn't go great. I think that some of our players just didn't appreciate the "but, only if" mechanic...but I think the real issue was unfamiliarity with the mechanic and not knowing how to use it well. With the variant rules we played with, I think it was important to use some restraint when employing the mechanic. In one story the mechanic was basically used to demolish another's character in every scene...their was no real tension and no real conflict, and it just made for a bad frustrating story. In the other story the players lost interest in the mechanic; I think it was due to a learning curve issue and some misunderstanding of the rules...we just weren't able to use it, in a consistent enough way, to improve the story.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nFelan \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nApril 2017 \n edited April 2017
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Ran the conclusion - the denouement/epilogue, really - to a seven-year continuous campaign that began in D&D 3.5 and was immediately switched to Pathfinder. After running two D&D modules (A Dark and Stormy Knight, The Sunless Citadel), we played through the Pathfinder Adventure Path The Council of Thieves. After that, we went off book to continue the story, along the way switching first temporarily, then permanently, to Dungeon World. The previous session was the epic climax, in which they finally unseated the oppressive House Thrune, effectively liberating Cheliax.

        It's tough to wrap up such a convoluted story, but I prepared a non-linear set of free-form vignettes (no dice rolling) wrapping up loose ends and projecting character arcs into the future (and the past), framing most of them around questions like "Does Tash ever retire from adventuring? If so, what does he do after?" and it worked really well. We closed on the last time the whole party was together, at a impromptu reunion ten years later, fading to black as they shared news, rehashed old arguments, and told tall tales about the old days.

        This was by far the longest campaign I've ever been a part of, and an important part of my life, so I was really pleased that we gave it a proper send-off. (Luckily, the real-life party of friends isn't going anywhere - I think we'll be playing Blades in the Dark next.)
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n

        \n
        This sounds really amazing! Do you ever record your sessions, Ben? I would love to listen to this :-)
        \nI never do. The magic stays at the table! I'm also very curious about your Polaris game, so I started a new thread to dig into that if you're willing.

        I played another game of Kingdom at Story Games Seattle with a totally different group. Our community: the small town fan club of a K-pop boy band. I think we expected it to be light and funny but it got wonderfully dramatic and intense. Some much tiny intensity, so many broken teen hearts.

        Are we going to let the national chapter of the club take over the appearance of our beloved band in *our* home town, after we won the "send in your own video" contest?!?! Oh helllllllll no!
        \n

        \n
        \n The Final Girl, just yesterday.
        Nice ... but it felt much more a merit of our group that of the game helping us achieve that it offered :P
        Very rough rules with lots of grey areas and missing pieces.
        Still, a nice idea.
        \n
        \n

        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nFelan \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nApril 2017 \n edited April 2017
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        Omg those system changes really interest me, are they chronicled, Felan? Either 3.5->PF and PF->DW.
        \n3.5 to PF happened after only one session, so there wasn't much to it other than mechanically re-creating the characters. PF to DW was obviously more drastic. At first it was temporary, just for fun, so we used the pre-existing DW classes, but when we switched permanently, I did more granular re-creations of each character using Class Warfare. By the time we switched, we had been playing for years, and we knew the characters very well, so it was pretty organic. The biggest change was the Sorcerer who became the (slightly broken) Mage class, meaning he wasn't limited to a predetermined list of spells, which created all kinds of wild situations.

        I didn't chronicle my own switch, but this thread was very helpful as I wrapped my head around the process!

        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\n2097 \n\n\n

        \n\nApril 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \nThanks, great thread

        \n
        \n\nRafu \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nApril 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n More Everway-mashup. This time, the Realm we encountered had a sketchy authority system, but by dismantling it we definitely made things worse. I liked how the spread of cards we were using restricted our options, so that we believed we'd done well until the very last minute, when we double-checked the meaning(s) of the Fate hanging over the Realm and realized we'd fucked it over.
        \n
        \n
        \n
