        \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nApril 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Joined in on an "open table" game of Fallen Empires (a fantasy reskin of Apocalypse World). I played a Mystic who discovered that someone's camel is, in fact, his former sister. He is now searching for a way to recover her identity before the camel-self subsumes all her memories.
        \n
        \n

        \n\nAdam_Dray \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nApril 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n That sounds fun, Paul!
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nApril 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n It was fun! It felt a little bit like In a Wicked Age..., because it happens every week and different players show up each time.

        However, the downside is that character creation takes up about half the session.

        On the upside, all the various reading moves and other question prompts did a great job fleshing out the fiction and giving depth to the world and the characters in it.

        My Mystic's seemingly bumbling acolyte appears to have turned out to be a villain, behind a lot of the bad shit which went down. He escaped, in the end, due to a 7-9 on a harm roll which led the MC to say his pursuer (a Sword Master) lost track of him altogether. (Boy, was he pissed! He chopped the guy he felt was responsible in half on the spot.)

        Sadly, I'll have to miss the sequel session, and return to the next one two weeks later.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nLisa Padol \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nApril 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Playtest of Fate of Cthulhu, where, somehow, saving the future became all tangled up with the relationships between the PCs. (This isn't a requirement, but it's a whole lot o'fun!) This session took place, we decided, two years after the last. Eight / Kate-Present loves her job -- which is working for a company that will contribute to the destruction of humanity -- and her boyfriend, who got her that job, is now cheerfully making bombs in the basement, explaining that he couldn't handle his iPhone and now we have AIs running for president? As they flew to Switzerland:

        Sydney: I don't understand what you're doing any more Eight -- I almost wish you still worked in the Hot Topic!

        Eight / Kate-Present: You used to be so stable -- an island of Sanity!

        Meanwhile, Jule, the androgynous child of the future whose programming was tweaked by Kate-future was angsting and oh yes, was enjoying childhood so much that they hadn't aged in the last two years.

        Jule: Can we save the world now so I can go back to playing Pokemon?

        Kate-Future poked her head into the room in the resort where Kate-Present and Sydney were actually working out their relationship.

        Kate-Present: What are you doing here?

        Sydney: We're going to be getting relationship counseling and see about having a baby -- what about you?

        Kate-Future to Samson, the rebellious Deep One Hybrid: They are completely insane and must be stopped. Also, we must destroy the artificial womb.

        Sydney's Player: That's an addendum.

        Kate-Present's player decided that one of her Aspects was "I have more Artificial Friends than real ones", one of whom was Triple 8. Kate-Future had created 9. Nope, no rivalry, why would you think that, and anyway go away while I beat her score at MindQuake!

        Jule: I hate Nine!

        Kate-Future: What? Why?

        Jule: You like Nine more than you like me!

        Kate-Future: What? Nine can't replace you!

        Jule (not mollified): Fine!

        Jule had met Jule's... er, future future self, and was conflicted because, sure, Kate-Future hadn't killed Jule and had tweaked Jule's programming, but what about the other kids from the artificial wombs?

        Kate-Future: No I only reprogram you -- I love you so much.

        Jule: But what about the railgun?

        Kate-Future: I could never love a railgun as much as I love you!

        Samson: This is doing nothing to un-disillusion me about the nature of familial relationships!

        Alas, Samson had been taking advantage of the fact that folks believed Dr. Kate Octavian (future) was Kate McKinnon (and we figured Kate McKinnon plays her in the movie, so is impersonating herself) and that Samson was her sperm donor and tried to get close to him as sort of, um, proxy getting close to her, so as the final conflict played out -- PCs fighting each other about whether to destroy the AI in charge of the Artificial Womb Project -- his son showed up from the future. He just needs to make his dad BELIEVE in the power of Dagon!

        Yeah, Sydney decked him because he was bothering Samson, and he has a relationship aspect with Samson: Samson is my tenant and a good tenant is hard to find. (He was mortified to discover that this kid was Samson's son.)

        Actually, Kate-Future and Jule are also Samson's tenants, and Kate's relationship aspect is: We're not pretty, but we're family!

        Jule took a moderate consequence: The AI Dr. Miller IS my mother!

        Kate-Future's player: So you've entered the You're Not My Mom! phase!

        Yeah, basically. Eventually, a compromise was worked out. Kate-Present was allowed to back up her friend, the AI Dr. Miller (Hey, she's in the same book club as Kate-Present) to a zetabyte drive, while Kate-Future overwrote the original with Nine and insisted to Jule that everyone was synthetic, not just Jule.

        Samson: Oh, in the Hegelian sense.

        And that is the last scheduled session during playtest time, but we're likely to continue the game. Next session, we figure, should take place five to seven years later, and Kate-Present and Sydney and their child will go to Lemuria -- the original version of, well, it's like Jurassic Park, but a franchise, and... I didn't know tyrannosauruses had tentacles...

        My entire prep work for this session:
        Rereading a few of the playtest rules
        Rereading the NPC rules from Fate Core
        And:

        Dr. Miller's Resort
        Aspect: Overlooking a lake
        Aspect: 2 hours drive from Zurich

        \n
        \n
        \n

        I didn't know tyrannosauruses had tentacles...

        \n Last night at Story Games Seattle we played Fiasco, Follow, Fall of Magic and Firebrands. Brought to you by the letter F\u2026

        I facilitated Fiasco. I remain convinced that you could play Main Street or Suburbia forever and never repeat yourself.

        \n
        \n Last night at Story Games SLC (we changed the name to shorten it and because it fits more)\u2014sorry Ben, we're basically stealing all your ideas, I'll change the name if you want me to\u2014we played Fiasco. We ended up playing the Touring Rock Band playset...it was a very funny and witty season\u2014comedy gold! I'm often completely blown away at how talented our players are...I will likely do a detailed play report if and when I have time. Thanks all :-)

        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nBen_Robbins \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nApril 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        Last night at Story Games SLC (we changed the name to shorten it and because it fits more\u2014sorry Ben, we're basically stealing all your ideas, I'll change the name if you want me too
        \nNot at all! There are lots of "Story Games (city name)" groups. I think it's great.

        Now back to your regularly scheduled game reports\u2026
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nLisa Padol \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nApril 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        Lisa, you have some talented players!
        \nOh yes.
        And everything just sort of clicked.
        It's all so wrong in all the right ways...

        Now, I need to prep for the other playtest group, where the dynamics are different, more Leverage-y, but still with a web of relationships with interesting angst potential. The key is to have Enough Stuff that if folks want direction, I'm not umming, but if they know what they want to do, a can drop everything. And I need to keep remembering that the more I prep, the easier it is to improvise...
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\njoela \n\n\n
        \n

        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n A space opera game using the Cypher System by MCG.

        \n
        \n

        \n\n2097 \n\n\n

        \n We did The Ice since too few players showed up for Corsail Council T_T
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\n2097 \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nApril 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Yeah, they didn't find tyrannosaurids with arms until 1989. I remember reading (this was before) something about the difference between tyrannosaurs and tarbosaurs being the number of fingers, thinking that was bullshit. And, I was vindicated\u2665
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nWilhelm \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nApril 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n I played The Daughters of Verona, it ended with a feast and marriages for the lovers.

        We had session zero for a VtM 2e game set in Atlanta in 1993, its raining. I play a Tremere.

        I have spent the day playing an Arkham Horror themed card game.

        My gaming podcast has been resurrected.

        Probably my best week gaming wise in over ten years.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nPatrickRBG \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nApril 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Played Deadpuncher by Kyle Weems last night. We had a blast. The combat system creates this fog of war feeling, the players constant attack the same target and have to find a way to divide up the fight before other targets overwhelm them. It took a bit of time to get used to the terminology of the game, but we got there in the end.

        We spent about an hour building characters, half an hour working out all the backstory and interpersonal stuff, and got a solid three hours of play. We had a fantastic moment where our mild mannered, semi-famous trivia master(also a werewolf) decided to transform and risk the normal humans on the train putting it up on youtube. Going toe to toe with the bad guy, they\u200b were able to get into\u200b a sweet momentum of countering moves and set up their teammate, a scared warrior type character, to finish the baddie off with enough damage to cause instant death.

        Would Recommend!
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n

      What did you play this week? (2017)

        \n\nJason_Morningstar \n\n\n

        \n
        \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nApril 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n How does that "fog of war" work? Sounds interesting.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nFelan \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nApril 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Fun three-player session of Follow using The Dragon, set in an underground society in which dwarves, lizardfolk, kobolds, ratfolk, deep ones, and other traditionally subterranean creatures have been forced into uneasy integration by an undefined ecological disaster on the surface. The dragon was some kind of Tremors-esque giant burrowing worm that turned out to be a gnomish mechanical mining machine run amok. We defeated it by trapping it in a large cavern and causing it to collide with itself, just like in Snake. Both my characters died ignominious deaths along the way, it was great. Having played with five players before, I found the two-characters-per-player mechanic much more manageable with three players, allowing for a more focused session.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nPatrickRBG \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nApril 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n It isn't a named mechanic within the system, but in each round of combat the players choose maneuvers and who they are targeting in secret and then everyone reveals at once. Then we resolve everything based on what maneuvers trump other maneuvers and the speed of said maneuvers.

        It really came into effect for us when the party was ambushed on a train by quite a few bad guys. In the first round of combat, before the characters could talk to each other, they all targeted the lead guy and thus got piled on by the rest. But as the combat went on, the players got into a good rhythm and found ways to compliment each other.

        Also it didn't feel like you were punished for not attacking, but instead were given a benefit for guarding or defending.

        I hope I'm explain this well...
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nMay 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        Felan said:

        We defeated it by trapping it in a large cavern and causing it to collide with itself, just like in Snake.

        \nHa! Hilarious.

        (I'm pretty sure that when we played Follow, we just had a group and one main character each; if and when our people died, we'd "grab" one of the others and make them into our new character, instead of playing two characters each all along. But I could be misremembering!)

        @PatrickRBG,

        Ah! Secret declaration of actions; that explains it. I like that in games! Often brings about various exciting and unexpected outcomes.

        Does the game present any handy way of doing this at the table? Do you write down your moves, or indicate them some other way?

        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nJeff_B_Slater \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nMay 2017 \n edited May 2017
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        Paul_T said:


        (I'm pretty sure that when we played Follow, we just had a group and one main character each; if and when our people died, we'd "grab" one of the others and make them into our new character, instead of playing two characters each all along. But I could be misremembering!)

        \nYeah Paul, your misremembering, we each had 2 players; we just ignored the minor ones for the most part. I think I had like 2, maybe 3, characters die\u2014the characters that replaced them were our minor characters

        @Felan
        Your Follow session sounds really fun
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nPatrickRBG \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nMay 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n@Paul_T There are printable cards to write your maneuvers on(pick one, put face down, reveal!) but targeting we did on paper as most fights were very fluid, no one stayed in one place for long. But the players didn't really change their focus that much, so writing was kept to a minimum.
        \n
        \n

        \n\nBen_Robbins \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nMay 2017 \n edited May 2017
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Discussion is great, but the game reports are getting buried.

        Let's keep this thread to just reporting what we played. If you want to reply, discuss, or dig into the details, start a new thread so you can go to town.

        Okay?
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nAviatrix \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nMay 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \nFate of Cthulhu as Future Dr. Kate Octavian. Lisa caught most of the madness of that session; I fear poor Dr. Kate's aspects about her relationship with past-Kate/Eight are only going to get darker...

        On Mighty Thews We had some absences at the Meetup so I didn't run Masks and got a chance to translate my favorite based-on-Julie Aubigny character into this system. I buckled swashes with abandon.

        Trail of Cthulhu Session X of The Unanswered Question, my Tatters of the King in the 1950s hack. We returned to the orphanage in Mexico Temperance spent the first six years of her life in, only to discover it had become a tony girls school; queue everyone taking jobs at the school. The Carcosan(?) Camilla was creepy, Charleston's shadow form set about making sure that Temperance had a proper comic book origin story, the horrifying secret of how the drug The Yellow is made was revealed, and Candace made an actual Flirting spend on the King in Yellow, assuring him that she was his. Fun times; scenario was loosely based on "The Dying of St. Margaret's."

        Montsegur 1244 The first time I've played Montsegur, although I've played Rachel ES Walton's Mars hack. My main was Philippa; she was pregnant by her sister Esclarmonde's beau Garnier; the Holy Grail and the treasure of the Cathars were given to the harlot Arsende and she escaped over the mountains. Philippa repented just as fast as she could learn the words; Esclarmonde went to the flames proclaiming her faithfulness. Good times! Well, not for the Cathars; but we had a great time.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nJonathan Nicol \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nMay 2017 \n edited May 2017
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n An episodic Dungeons and Dragons 5th Edition game where I play Solace Dravos, a Tiefling Bard and Storyteller who delights in cutting deeply with his sharp tongue and rapier even when spurring his fellow adventures on. I used Vicious Mockery to force the boss of this week's dungeon to give up on life.

        An ongoing online game of Blades in the Dark focused on the efforts of a crew of gun runners selling, conniving, and committing brazen acts of violence to keep Charhallow safe from other criminals and to raise in power. We ended with a cliffhanger involving a 3 way confrontation that will most likely result in our crew going to war with at least one other faction if we survive. We might just pull a rabbit out of our collective hats if we do not all stress out first.

        I play Candros Slane, The Little Sparrow - A Former Imperial Sniper and Master Manipulator. A family man, veteran, and career criminal with a missing wife who is prone to random fits of elaborate orchestrated violence as well as moving all the pieces on the chess board when it suits him. He is a mix of Hound and Slide.

        This week I will play Blades in the Dark and an in person V20 Dark Ages game (Giovanni Chronicles) where I play Ignacio Valdez, a 300+ year old Brujah political dissident, duelist, and Archon of the Camarilla for now.

        Hopefully soon I can start running some Apocalypse World, Masks, Exalted 3e, or Chronicles of Darkness. I am feeling the need to run a game deep in my bones.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nRafu \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nMay 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n The Everway-hack campaign goes on and on! This week's Realm featured some excessive bureaucracy which a player jokingly likened to a certain portion of the Don't Rest Your Head setting, and a system of prevention of violent crime by the preemptive suppression of individuals possessing the physical strength to become dangerous criminals. Little gods who inhabit underground water springs really are sneaky, dangerous bastards, apparently, and our favorite such little bastard, Acheron, managed to break free. Stuff happened which tested the limits of my current character growth subsystems, demonstrating they're flexible enough: one spherewalker recruited armed followers (a bunch of them, but quite inept), one was forced to drastically re-skin an existing power (I'm not traveling with Acheron any more, but it looks like I got another little goddess to carry around), and one fell ill (that's quite a character development, trust me).

        Also, Fiasco, with Giulia Barbano & Renato Ramonda's De' Medici playset. I suppose actually living in Florence gives you a special relationship of a sort with that playset... Once more, it was all-out, vulgar comedy with murderous implications. Surprisingly, none of the main characters died.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nkelmscott_press \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nMay 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n I facilitated Lovecraftesque at our local bookstore's big Tabletop Day event. Our 1920s archaeologist in Orkney unearthed a strange ivory artefact only to discover it had been used (later) to murder his favourite tobacconist. Then he teleported between stone circles, before ultimately finding himself possessed by an ancient entity. It was a bit more coherent than I've made it sound, though not much. That's probably okay, though; horror is often a bit incoherent.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nAdam_Dray \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nMay 2017 \n edited May 2017
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Wrote 16,000 words (72+ page formatted PDF) of a Player's Guide for Mirrorrim, the City of Brass, and I ran a 2-hour Roll20 session for four players. I'm running another 2-hour session tomorrow night. Twice weekly, I hope.

        It's a megadungeon campaign for D&D 5e, not the destitute squatters campaign. Normal power levels, but set in my City of Brass setting, now primarily called Mirrorrim.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n

        \n
        \n\nLisa Padol \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nMay 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Fate of Cthulhu, 2nd group, where I started in medias res, in the Dreamlands, not worrying about the whys... and it was awesome as folks picked up the ball and ran with it. We abbreviated a fair bit on account of it was a playtest, we were getting tired, two of us were getting sick... but I have enough data to finish my report in the next couple of days.

        Kerberos II, Machinery of Life, where I was sorta running the last bit of Flashman in the Great Game, except that, this being Kerberos II, it was more comedy of manners, with one PC and her NPC brother talking about why she was annoyed he'd slept with Dorian Gray before she did, and her making up for lost time, brilliant doctors being brilliantly stubborn, and a cache of weapons we established existed two sessions ago becoming a useful bargaining chip.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nJeff_B_Slater \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nMay 2017 \n edited May 2017
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Just played Fall of Magic. I played with 1 regular; a person who had played 1 other story game; and 2 people who had never played an RPG in their life. It was an okay session but a bit flippant and silly for a FoM game. It was nice to have a couple of new people show up, hopefully they'll come next week. Love the game but not our best session :-)
        \n
        \n
        \n

        \n\nHasimir \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nMay 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Played the first session of a new Urban Shadows campaign set in the city we are all living in now: Hamburg (Germany).
        For the first time ever I managed to play a character named Juza of the Clouds* that makes sense within the context of the ongoing game. A Fae from a minor branch of the Sky Court, named Jurgen Zahn, aka JuZa.
        I'm almost moved T_T

        *any Ken Shiro fan worth its salt should applaud my efforts u_u
        \n
        \n
        \n

      • \n
        \n

        \n\nRafu \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nMay 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        Ben_Robbins said:

        Mind of Margaret

        \nWhat game is that? Never heard of it.\n
        Hasimir said:

        Juza of the Clouds*

        \nLOL! I think that series is known as Fist of the North Star in English.

        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nJason_Lutes \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nMay 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Session 7 of our current Freebooters on the Frontier campaign, which we're using to playtest the 2nd edition as I develop it. Experimenting with different approaches to handling dungeons, from old school map-as-you-go to node-based diagram to pure theater of the mind. My main focus right now is trying to find a structure for improvising dungeons on the fly that is easy to use and integrates well with the "Venture Forth" move we're using to handle overland and underground exploration. Players are enjoying the game, especially exploring the world that they established in the first session, but all of the necessary experimentation on my end has resulted in me not really being able to get in a groove.

        The other issue is that after a few side-sessions of GenLab Alpha, my sense is that they're hankering to play characters motivated by more than loot acquisition. The GenLab setup is that the PCs are post-apoc human/animal hybrid members of a resistance seeking to overthrow their robot overseers, which makes the players instantly more invested in the proceedings.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nhorn_head_o \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nMay 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n I played Firebrands, Session 3. We had a very long Dance. I got kicked in the face during it, then broke ranks with my landowner unit and family to follow my heart, freeing our captured revolutionary leader.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nPatRowdy \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nMay 2017 \n edited May 2017
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n I'm feeling content but a bit mentally exhausted after running three different games in the last five days! GMing takes a lot out of me and I want to start working on minimizing the time I spend talking and controlling the narration duties.

        First was the penultimate session of the first season of our very first Burning Wheel game! It's sort of an Iron Age Celtic high fantasy vibe and the characters are in the midst of their first large scale battle, which is racking up quite the death toll. I'm using a simple, hacked-together " tides of war" resolution system that the players can push into their favor by taking actions that have a significant impact on the flow of battle.

        We played a bit slowly and timidly as we were learning the game and the players had been unusually successful up to this point, so the deaths of a lot of significant characters hit pretty hard. It felt like our own version of the Red Wedding. It was awesome

        Next was the first session of the new game of Apocalypse World and boy, is it going to get weird! We've got a brainer, a savvy head, a child thing and a hard holder named Ol' Dirty, who pilots a Howl's Moving Castle-esque land train across the wasteland, chasing massive psychic storms called Whalestroms that frequently leave imprints on the world from another time or place, altering landscapes or producing strange artifacts. And yep, you guessed it, sky whales.

        The players are fairly new and extremely creative so it's possible that I should have reined them in a bit, but I'm excited to see where this goes! At the very least, I'll get a lot of practice writing custom moves!

        And lastly, just finished up with the second episode of Tales of the Four Nations, a Legends of the Elements campaign within the Avatar: the Last Airbender universe, set about 20 years before the events of the show.

        Things have been moving a little slow, two of the players are brand new to RPGs and we're still getting the hang of pacing, as well as applying and taking advantage of Tags, narrative descriptors that mechanically incentivize players to think about fictional positioning and the effectiveness of teamwork. But it's one of the most fun groups have ever played with and we're having a blast. There's been a lot of laughter and the moves are definitely pushing us towards interesting and thematically appropriate situations. Plus I'm getting to geek out in one of my favorite fictional universes... no complaints here

        EDIT: haha! just noticed that @horn_head_o posted right before me! hey Max! killer game man, we're really enjoying it
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nRafu \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nMay 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n More Everway-hack. A cult of warrior women celebrated the summer solstice with a tournament: Free-of-Chains showed off in an informal, out-of-schedule duel and ended up married to his opponent. The forest the villagers were afraid of going to was home to dual-spirited individuals (some of them villagers turning into animals, some of them... other things) who welcomed Merry as one of their own, but Merry was scared - afraid of becoming Brother entirely, his own consciousness vanishing forever. Ink and Free-of-Chains tracked down Merry and dragged him away by force, hurting Brother in the process. Thus, Merry fulfilled his fate of Striking at the Dragon's Tail: he came to realize he had, over the last several sessions, seriously underestimated the danger Brother posed to him.
        Next week we're probably going to try out a new rule that, upon fulfilling your fate, you can choose the next Realm to be visited (instead of randomly creating it): Barbara's plan is to head to Free-of-Chains's homeland so that he can have a second attempt at a revolution, which seems to be what is needed to fulfill his fate (War: great effort vs. effort misspent).
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nLisa Padol \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nMay 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n We ran the larp Jamais Vue, with mixed success -- several people did not enjoy themselves, and several really enjoyed themselves. For the first group, there were several factors:

        1. This is a larp written 15 years ago, with a somewhat different aesthetic, and we failed to communicate that. I am told "heavy on goals and mechanics" is a phrase that will help.
        2. We needed another GM. Running successfully with 4 in the past, I'd forgotten that at least 3 were always very familiar with the game, and one, not present for this run, was the person who had all the stuff that isn't clear on paper in his head.
        3. Yeah, that stuff needs to be made clearer.
        4. We didn't spend enough time with the GMs newer to this larp discussing flow and expectations. Understandable, as we all had Things coming up that needed dealing with, but very unfortunate.
        5. The next time I say, "Nah, two copies of the GM bible will suffice for [X where X>2] GMs", Josh is under instructions to say, "No, they won't."
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nPatrickRBG \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nMay 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n I got to play a hilarious Ghostbusters one shot last night. After only GM:ing for what feels like years, it was odd to be on the other side of the table.

        The failing Hamilton franchise of Ghostbusters, run by the hapless Gene Yorke, had laid off most of their staff, leaving only three busters to manage the business.

        After a rather depressing conference call with the other franchises in the region, we learn that Gene's rival in Toronto is once again leading the region in profitability and captures. Gene then informed us he is heading out of town for a ' family obligation' and would be back a week, leaving the operation was in our hands.

        Our first call came early in the day and sent us to a high school. A ghost had an office administrator trapped in the washroom. Trapped in the sense that they didn't want to walk through the shin deep foamy ooze covering the floor. Slip and slide hilarity ensued, but the ghost was successfully trapped.

        On our way back from the call, we came across more and more instances of the same ghosty behaviour and after following the trail of destruction(disruption at best) we came upon the source, a coffee shop unknowingly serving haunted coffee.

        The GM really did a great job of keeping it fun and light, while being just challenging enough to keep us guessing. And the system was super lean, but very enjoyable.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n

        PatrickRBG said:

        After only GM:ing for what feels like years, it was odd to be on the other side of the table.

        \nI sure know that feeling! Kinda funny, isn't it?

        This week I continued a Monsterhearts campaign, with some alternate rules, and we're having a great time. Things are building and developing nicely, with each session better than the last (as the players familiarize themselves with the rules and start to feel more comfortable in the skin of their characters, they are being more proactive and it's great).

        I'm also sitting in on an ongoing Fallen Empires game. It happens every week, but different players show up each time, so there's a bit of a In a Wicked Age... vibe to the proceedings.

        Finally, tonight I continue playtesting my Princess Bride-inspired GMless game, Inconceivable. It's been a fun experiment so far!

        \n\nJason_Morningstar \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nMay 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n@Caroline_Hobbs the Earl never comes to a good end. Everybody, feel sorry for the poor Earl.

        I played The Shindig Machine and playtested a new game I'm working on called A Green and Narrow Bed.

        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nLisa Padol \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nMay 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n In Monsterhearts with the 2nd edition Sneak Peek Pack, we're still in season one, as the experience rules we have are short on ways to get experience, and folks seemed to think that, merely because they ended a fae war, there wasn't much to do. Silly folks.

        I figured that the winning side (won on account of the PC who technically ruled the other side abdicated in exchange for a promise that kept all the fae out of town) would start executing their enemies, one of whom, obviously, would run to the PCs for help, which... threatens to make the bargain that keeps the fae out of town and not at war null and void.

        So, the Queen figured that the obvious way to fix this was not to hand the fugitive over but to take over the fae realm herself. The Werewolf agreed to help, and it was obvious they'd have to talk to the Witch, as he's a random factor. Logically, they should NOT talk to the Fae, who wants to be left out of it, but we didn't want to leave a player out of it.

        Fortunately, the Fae and the Queen have had sex, which means the Fae counts as part of the Queen's gang, which means that the Streaming move can work both ways -- I treated this as Roll +Dark, you get the information regardless, but the roll's result tells us if something else goes horribly wrong. So, everyone's on board with this horrible, horrible, delightful plan.

        Some of the negotiations came about from the Queen dragging the Werewolf into the girls' bathroom.

        Queen: You're a girl, sort of. I'm a girl, sort of.

        The Witch's father thinks the Witch is utterly evil and powerhungry. The Witch's mother thinks the Witch's father is psychotic and dangerous. The Witch has finally managed to undo one of his hexes, the one damaging his father for lying, and has not yet tried to undo the hex that keeps his father from speaking (creating a new hex, the Vampire's hypnosis, but with +Dark).

        The Fae was astonished that their girlfriend continued to stay angry even after they got her flowers, so arranged for her to take magic ice cream that would make her more forgiving. They are now wondering if that was a bad idea, as the girlfriend is taking this forgiving thing pretty far.

        And, out of character at least, possibly in character for one or two of the PCs, they're remembering a little detail... So, the reason the Witch's grandmother made a generational deal with the fae, a deal which might be or become null and void? To protect the town from demons...
        \n

        \n\nBen_Robbins \n\n\n

        \n\nMay 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Big myth Microscope at Story Games Seattle.

        All the gods and animals come together to carve the All-Rune into the golden sun that lights our hollow earth, but later in the game we find out that wasn't their first attempt. Sun 1.0 is a diamond orb floating on the waves, but when they try to rune it up, ka-blooey. Shards spray across the ocean, and that's what gave the waves and sea their silvery foam.

        We also had an idyllic city magically bound so that only beautiful things could enter, but which beauty could not leave. What could go wrong?!?

        \n\nJeff_B_Slater \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nMay 2017 \n edited May 2017
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n We played P&Q: Schism at Story Games Salt Lake City. It's a story game by Brandon Nelson, who is one of the players at Story Games SLC. It's a pretty decent game and has only been played three times. I think it could be improved and I wish Brandon was more willing to take the time to playtest it and refine it. I think it has a lot of potential but Brandon is just not into being more methodical when it comes to analyzing the game or being super open to feedback during playtesting. I guess every one takes a different approach to game creation; I just want to see it become the best game it can be. But I guess I'll just have to analyze and playtest my own games designs to death instead of worrying about his
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nCaesar Slaad \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nMay 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n We did a "pitch session" for Shadows of the Century. It's an 80s action/adventure game based on the pulpy premises set forth in Spirit of the Century. Essentially, heroes embodying great attributes of mankind are born at the dawn of every century, but towards the end, the power of the shadows take hold, and it's up to scrappy 80s action heroes to fight back.

        I signed up for the gamma playtest. Concurrently, two of my Thursday Night's Black Agents players announced they could only make it every other week. So I decided to run the gamma playtest of the weeks where they were absent.

        The pitch session is where the players define the setting/adventure and make their characters. They decided that they wanted to fight Nazi/KGB Vampires called "the Red Menace", and that the Red Menace is ultimately an outgrowth of the Kroll'x alien invaders. Now one thing about having the players having such a heavy hand in the creation of the adventure is that it wiped away some of the surprise, so I decided to see if I could create some surprises.

        The game was to be set in Florida. I decided a way to tie Nazis, the KGB, and Vampires together is by having Nazis fleeing to South America stumble upon Kroll'x outposts that existed in mesoamerica (and thus Meso-American blood cult themed vampires); this in turn gets stumbled upon by KGB agents assisting communist uprisings in the region, which ultimately spreads to Florida. The final piece that ties this together is that there is rumor that a Nazi war criminal named Klaus Barbie was used by the CIA to help hunt down Che Guevara, a Marxist revolutionary active in Latin America. So you know where I am going with this: the main villain is Vampire Che.

        Anyways, part of the pitch session is collaboratively making a bunch of NPCs, Each player makes 3 names, and then the cards get passed left twice, and each player adds one element to each NPC. This has the effect of creating a lot of flavorful NPCs the GM can pull into the game, full of interesting quirks and story hooks. They had this element in the beta and it astonished me how useful this was to the GM.

        The gamma adds to this process. After each NPC has two elements, you pile them in the middle of the table, then each player gets the chance to add an element to one of the NPCs and promote it to a villain. We'll see how this works out. It promises to take me different directions than I might have gone if I was making the villains from scratch.

        Finally the PCs. They made:
        Rex Power, a Cyborg Assassin, escaped from a secret government program (the same player played the character in the Beta playtest and remade him here.)
        William Ashford III, member of a secret cabal of wizards being hunted by an order called the Knights Templar.
        Johnny Pickle, garbage-man from a secret order of garbage-men who hunt cultists they discover by remnants they leave behind.

        This promises to be interesting.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n

      • \n
        \n

        \n\nIchthyarch \n\n\n

        \n Not this week but the week before, I played Microscope at Boise Public Library. We discovered the history of Earth's dinosaur empire, and the ages of the enslavement of the squirrel people, the war against the long-arms of Mars (due to the heresy of the Deniers of D.B. Snodgrass, the great tool innovator of the paleolithic), and the end of the age of dinosaur super-science brought about by that fateful meteor.

        In case any Boise Public Library users are reading, we're doing Kingdom on June 5th. Sign up on the BPL online calendar.

        \n
        \n I got to run Infinite Galaxies. Three players plus me, with everyone being pretty new to PbtA games. Set a few hundred years in the future, humankind has met some aliens who are pretty nice if stand-odd-ish. The players were part of a survey team seeking habitable worlds and alien technology. A Psi human, an alien Scientist with personal property issues, and an empathic humanoid Robot along with their terse NPC pilot. Laughs were had.

        We also ran our huge Pathfinder game(Kingmaker Adventure Path), they are nearing the end of book one(of six) and are about to go up against the Big Bad called the Stag Lord. It is a madhouse but always a lot of fun.

        \n\nLisa Padol \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nMay 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n In Kerberos Fate: Machinery of Life, the Rani of Jhansi is getting enough help from the PCs that she may prevail.

        Meanwhile, plant mage Ladon got ticked enough at Dorian Grey to make a tiny plant sprout from the end of Dorian's cigarette and grow enough to poke him inside a nostril. Dorian wondered if the plant could, theoretically, of course, as it had broken off by now, continue growing and, you know, move around inside.

        This, naturally, got Dr. Alexander's attention, and he asked Ladon if that were to happen, would Ladon be able to get images of the inside of the body via the plant. Ladon, naturally, found this a fascinating question.

        Player: I think we just invented laproscopic surgery.

        \n\nAviatrix \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nMay 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \nMasks of Nyarlathotep: Two sessions in Cairo. Faraz Najir told his sad tale; Dr. Khafour explained the history of the Black Pharaoh. Winston grew even closer to his shotgun (at the expense of his relationship with his wife, Susan) and managed to join the cult of the Black Pharaoh at the booster level. Meanwhile, Professor Chamberlain ponders if his soul is too much or too little to pay for magical power; Marty met Yaleesha's family; and the priestess of the goddess Bast lent them an irascible one-eyed tabby cat named Caesar to help them on their quest. Next week: dinner at Omar Shakhti's!

        Microscope: We traced the epic conspiracy of the Ishtarites from their origin in Ur to the eventual ascension of humanity to a singularity. Along the way we learned that the Involved species of the galaxy are pretty much uniformly composite entities with a single personality, and that the Templars were descended from the Ishtarites. Of course they were--they're the Harlem Globetrotters of conspiracy theory.
        \n

        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nJason_Morningstar \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nMay 2017 \n edited May 2017
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \nFiasco, playtesting a new playset called Half a Million Dollars in a Grocery Bag. Also:

        Last night we finished our paranoid old men in a nursing home where bad things are happening game, using Archipelago chance cards coupled with a tuned Itras By deck for every pull.

        There was some uncertainty around the visiting pastor, Pastor Van Dyck ("Can we persuade her to get us out of the sealed ward and to a church service outside?"), and the Itras By draw was "gossip". It told us to go around the table and start some gossip, and then amplify and twist it, and when it got back to the guy who drew it, the result was true. It went:

        "Pastor Van Dyck isn't what she seems"

        "Pastor Van Dyck isn't a pastor at all"

        "Lieutenant Commander Van Dyck is authorized to carry a weapon on site"

        "Lieutenant Commander Van Dyck is chief of security for the whole project"

        Which became true and was awesome. She went from being a good-natured local Methodist in Xenia, Ohio to a stone cold government operative responsible for keeping [REDACTED] [REDACTED].

        Also, the Archipelago draw for this was "No, but..." so she turned them down but accidentally showed them who she really worked for.\ufeff
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nMay 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Jason, when you're playtesting a new playset, what do you look for? (I'll start a new thread, if that's worthwhile!)
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nRafu \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nMay 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Last Sunday afternoon on Everway-hack, we played the first of a two-part episode (this time we planned for it, as closing the threads from previous week + playstorming the modified setup took a while) in which we finally traveled back to Free-of-Chains's home-world.

        Well, that came after celebrating Free's wedding, anyway. Which didn't stop him from walking the spheres, but gave him a home to head back to. The bride, already carrying a child, has stayed back... but the bridesmaids, warrior women all of them, have joined us. And, as it happens, we found our way back to the realm the groom is from...

        A slave population toils endlessly in a post-apocalyptic desert, under the inhumanly cruel, exceedingly decadent rule of the "Angels" - a race of magical bird-women inhabiting impossibly opulent flying citadels, and served by dragons. Not much has changed since the failed revolt Free led years ago.
        The twist is, Angels appear to be scheming against each other for more power. This might explain how the Fool, reversed ("lack of connection") can occupy the Virtue slot in the oracle of the realm: that's the weak spot of the evil rulers. Or maybe it refers to how there are no Gates in the realm, except for the one Free left through - possibly formed or opened by the very blood of the dragon he slew in his escape - and we've now used to come back... A Gate the Angels are intrigued by, and extremely interested in. So much, in fact, that because of our expertise with the Gates they've been treating us as their guests, so far...
        Their hospitality is much creepier than their hostility, believe me. Also, as we'd very wisely split the party, we're now separated and the guests of two different Angel citadels, each ruled by a self-styled Goddess-Empress of the Whole Universe.
        Finally, Free has been haunted by visions of his long-presumed-dead former lover, appearing to him as a live woman, though only from a distance. At least one of the Angels, apparently scheming behind the back of her own queen, knows, and is using this leverage to manipulate Free-of-Chains into helping her...

        And that's our cliffhanger.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nJeff_B_Slater \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nMay 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n I played Fiasco (Game of Thrones playset) the day before last. Second time I played with this playset, both times create a great stories that were serious and didn't need humor to sustain them. My friends were drunk this time, so the story wasn't as good, and the drunkenness was a bit annoying since I don't drink; but everything considered, it went pretty well. Yesterday, Story Games Salt Lake City play Follow. We play the Colony quest. We were basically trying to set up a colony on a hostile planet with other creatures that were somewhat comical and hostile. The game was silly and I don't think the tone served the story well. I think in order to get the best out of Follow, groups should discuss what kind of tone to get everyone on the same page. Of course, this is important with any story game, but I feel it helps especially in Follow. I also think it's best to stick closely to the archetypal story (in terms of structure) of the quest your playing because the game tends to go in interesting directions on its own and if you push too hard you can get into a space that loses its verisimilitude
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nBen_Robbins \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nMay 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n We played Something to Hide at Story Games Seattle, which I've been wanting to try for a while. It's a murder mystery where any of our characters might be the killer, so you establish clues that incriminate you, but also play knowing you might turn out to be innocent. We had trouble figuring out the rules (some critical points are not stated clearly and I'm still not sure about them) but the design basically works.

        Also started playing Blades in the Dark. Smuggling people is easier when you drug their tea. Or was it the biscuits..?
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n

      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nMay 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Good observations, Jeff. I also dislike playing with people when they drink - it usually isn't a positive contributing factor to a good game!
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nMay 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Today I ran a sci-fi/horror one-shot based on Monsterhearts. I hacked the game to bits and came up with this:

        The setting was Depression-era Arkansas, and the characters were entirely mundane, human, people. (Not teenage monsters, in other words.)

        But as the game progressed, they experienced otherworldly forces and gradually were transformed into something rather alien and/or monstrous. In the end, it seems, alien forces were trying to make their way onto the Earth, slowly infesting humans with inexorable purpose.

        In our playthrough, it's pretty clear that they succeeded.

        I should write this up sometime to share the mechanics bits and pieces - they are a lot of fun. The only regret was that we didn't have longer to stretch out the game and explore the ramifications piece by piece. (Particularly the character transformations which took place.)
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nCaesar Slaad \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nMay 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Confession: I am much more of an action/adventure/espionage GM than a horror GM. But the way my players are littering the landscape with the corpses of conspiracy goons in my Nights Black Agents game was wearing a little thin. The Coldfall House nugget seemed moody, and I wanted to set the PCs on the course for a big confrontation with the Satanic Cult of Dracula. So I set the Coldfall House hook and played it up for all the eerie horror effects I could mustered, and eventually set the steely-eyed agents running. It was beautiful.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      \n

      What did you play this week? (2017)

      \n
      \xab1\u20263456789\u202612\xbb

      Comments

        \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nLisa Padol \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nMay 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        Caesar Slaad said:

        So I set the Coldfall House hook and played it up for all the eerie horror effects I could mustered, and eventually set the steely-eyed agents running. It was beautiful.

        \nDetails? Feel free to PM me with those.


        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nLisa Padol \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nMay 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n I ran the first part of a Call of Cthulhu adventure I translated into Trail. The PCs know it's a huge trap that cannot end well, but one can't let go of the possibility it might help, one doesn't have anything else worth doing, and one is following along hoping to either minimize the damage or talk the others into turning back -- which, I stressed, is a viable option.

        My main concern is whether I can calibrate the opposition correctly, given there's one decent fighter among the three PCs. Gut instinct says not to pull punches as, aesthetics aside, Players are Clever, and at least one player knows the Trail rules way better than I do, and I don't mean in the rules lawyer sense, but more in the precision strike sense.

        That said, I think I will check my conversion math, just in case.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nJason_Morningstar \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nMay 2017 \n edited May 2017
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n At Camp Nerdly I played:

        Pitch, Please (A women's barbershop quartet larp in playtest by Rachael Storey)
        A Pirate's Life (Piratical family drama from Jay Treat, also in playtest, also a larp)
        The Changeover (Sad space opera by me, in playtest)
        A Green and Narrow Bed (Sad widows out for revenge, by me, in playtest)
        Witch: The Road to Lindesfarne, in live action mode at night, ending at .. a massive fire pit for some reason

        Lots of playtesting!
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nAviatrix \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nMay 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \nThe Unanswered Question, aka Tatters of the King in 1950s (mostly) America. The PCs had their armored RV attacked with an anti-tank gun by drug cartel soldiers and a KGB team on the way to Mexico City; Temperance debated theology with the NPC most committed to the messianic reading of the Yellow Mythos; a couple of CIA frat boys tried to extricate them from a slippery situation with the Russians; Thomas Villiers proved to be alive and well and painting in the style of Andre Masson; somebody from Jimmy's past came back to haunt him; and the King pulled Candace further into his worship. Now they move on to Bolivia on the trail of a Soviet "trade mission" that wants to bring the King to Earth. Fun times and a great show by Candace's player, who has been beyond a good sport about becoming the turncoat in the party.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nCaesar Slaad \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nMay 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        Lisa Padol said:

        Caesar Slaad said:

        So I set the Coldfall House hook and played it up for all the eerie horror effects I could mustered, and eventually set the steely-eyed agents running. It was beautiful.

        \nDetails? Feel free to PM me with those.


        \nWell, I'm not sure if you are angling for a PM because I might be afraid of revealing stuff to my players or to keep from spamming the thread. But I'll PM you and if anyone else is interested I can echo it here. My players aren't the sort who go lurking around forums for adventure secrets, so I'm not concerned about that.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nRafu \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nMay 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        Rafu said:

        Last Sunday afternoon on Everway-hack, we played the first of a two-part episode (this time we planned for it, as closing the threads from previous week + playstorming the modified setup took a while) in which we finally traveled back to Free-of-Chains's home-world.
        [...]
        A slave population toils endlessly in a post-apocalyptic desert, under the inhumanly cruel, exceedingly decadent rule of the "Angels" - a race of magical bird-women inhabiting impossibly opulent flying citadels, and served by dragons. Not much has changed since the failed revolt Free led years ago.
        The twist is, Angels appear to be scheming against each other for more power. This might explain how the Fool, reversed ("lack of connection") can occupy the Virtue slot in the oracle of the realm: that's the weak spot of the evil rulers. Or maybe it refers to how there are no Gates in the realm, except for the one Free left through - possibly formed or opened by the very blood of the dragon he slew in his escape - and we've now used to come back... A Gate the Angels are intrigued by, and extremely interested in. So much, in fact, that because of our expertise with the Gates they've been treating us as their guests, so far...
        Their hospitality is much creepier than their hostility, believe me. Also, as we'd very wisely split the party, we're now separated and the guests of two different Angel citadels, each ruled by a self-styled Goddess-Empress of the Whole Universe.
        Finally, Free has been haunted by visions of his long-presumed-dead former lover, appearing to him as a live woman, though only from a distance. At least one of the Angels, apparently scheming behind the back of her own queen, knows, and is using this leverage to manipulate Free-of-Chains into helping her...

        And that's our cliffhanger.

        \nMaybe we didn't save the world, but we managed to kick quite a lot of Angel-ass at least! My character All-Reading Ink and Free-from-Chains each, separately, managed to release a powerful dragon from indenture to the Angels: they went spread havoc and wrecked a couple flying citadels. Then Free released a third dragon, basically starting a draconic uprise...

        Oh, yeah: the mystery woman from the past... Turns out she was actually the ghost of Free's lover of old, animated by dragon blood spilled on her fresh corpse. As Free lied severely wounded, near death in a falling sky-citadel (this was after physically wrestling the first dragon into freedom) the ghost bound with him, healing his bodily wounds in the process, to forever haunt his mind with memories hereafter.

        Meanwhile, it was demonstrated that Merry's demonic double Brother isn't willing to manifest anymore. Can this mean Merry is dying? He sure feels his time's running short.

        Anyway, war broke out between various Angel queens (we counted fourteen of those) for ownership of the gate, and we had to hold it for days and weeks against all comers - Free riding dragons and kicking ass - while Merry basically ferried away a whole village's population through the gate to some sphere on the other side. I personally enjoyed the pleasure of beheading one of the Angel queens with my axe. Can you imagine more effective a way to counter a mind-control spell? Meanwhile, human rebels stole dragon eggs from the crashed citadels... Thus, the seeds of a rebellion that might have a shot at succeeding have been planted.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nMay 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Lots of PbtA lately:

        MCing Monsterhearts, third session of a new campaign. Having lots of good results from my Fiasco-style playset and my new harm rules. A messy situation gets worse when the Witch hexes a group of bullies from the football near a run-down drug den... and then takes off in the Werewolf's mother's car.

        The final moment: as they're driving away, the Mortal switches *true loves*... from one PC to the other. Oh no! The drama.

        Sat in on another game of Fallen Empires, an ongoing drop-in campaign with different players each week. It's really weird to be playing a game and having 9 different PCs listed in the "history" section of my character sheet!

        A great moment:

        The Hocus misses his Frenzy roll while trying to rally his followers, while another PC - whom the Hocus has named the Chosen One - discovers a better way to banish shadows. The Chosen One scores an advance and takes the option to "gain a gang"... just like that, the Hocus's followers are now his!
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nLisa Padol \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nMay 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Ran the second and final session of a CoC scenario which -- so, I ran it as Trail, and because of the differences between Trail and CoC, combined with the particular players and PCs, I did something that, on paper, should break the scenario, but in this case, didn't.

        So, the question was just how far these PCs would go chasing a legend when all of them knew, on some level, pretty much exactly how things would play out. Answer: well past the point of sanity, but not quite past the point of no return. And, in fact, in the closing coda, one of the PCs finally decided to return home, despite her distaste at signing a loyalty oath in just-post-McCarthy-era USA. (That is, the scenario was set 1955-ish.)

        My prep was basically on target; i.e., I used a good 90% of it, didn't flip too much in my notes, and don't think I made things too easy. (Too hard wasn't an issue.)
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n

        \n\nAdam_Dray \n\n\n

        \n
        \n
        \n
        \nAt Camp Nerdly:

        Played Mythender.

        Ran Misspent Youth with Quinn Murphy's Attacking the Sky scenario in Sell Out With Me (coming soon).

        Ran the "walking LARP" version of Witch: The Road to Lindesfarne with Jeffrey Collyer.

        On Roll20:

        Ran two more 2-hour sessions of D&D 5e, my Mirrorrim Megadungeon campaign for City of Brass. We're in our 6th session now. Near TPK last night, but all ended up surviving after all.
        \n
        \n
        \n

        \n
        \n
        \n\nDreamer \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nMay 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Played a couple of scenes for Our Last Best Hope.

        http://solorpggamer.blogspot.com/2017/05/actual-play-our-last-best-hope-killer.html

        I noticed my interest in the game waning after taking on the latest Threat. The pacing mechanic that pushes the game towards Act II did not figure into this last play, and suddenly I'm looking at the prospect of having to go through more Threats than I had planned. The nature of the Threats is sort of window dressing, so they're starting to feel repetitive. I will likely cap the number of Spotlight scenes (per the game's alternate rule), or might hack the progress mechanic to make the event pool grow regardless.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nLisa Padol \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nMay 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n I ran Kerberos Fate: Machinery of Life, and history got (further) changed, involving an advantage a shapeshifting clockwork PC put on an NPC (I don't want to anger the mouse in my pocket because it might eat me).

        Ladon Green got annoyed at one of Dr. Alexander's minions, played by Dr. A's player at that point, which delighted Dorian Gray.

        Dorian: Mr. Green is being threatening -- I want to watch.

        Felicity's brother Amity asked her to explain to him why Ladon got as angry as he did by the minion, Bryce, pointing out how many children were worse off than the kidnapped child they were trying to rescue. Felicity used a complicated analogy involving an engineer of the new fangled horseless carriages (still under construction) who reacted to a flawed carriage as a reason to redesign the entire line, and refunds and fixing the actual broken machine were Not His Problem.

        Amity: Engineers should never be allowed to talk to customers. Oh dear -- did I just try to become an engineer?

        Dr. A had a quiet word with Ladon about how perhaps threatening his minion might not have been desirable and perhaps Ladon might consider possible fallout before doing it again.

        Ladon: Perhaps I will.

        Dr. Alexander: You're a very interesting specimen, Mr. Green.

        I... don't think this was a threat, merely an observation. I think.

        They found a dead man who was indeed an agent they had been searching for. A month or so dead, yes, but preserved in a cold room.

        Dr. Alexander: I am going to bring him back to life!

        GM: I'm the only one who didn't see this coming, aren't I?

        Dr. A: What?? You give me a corpse!

        Next time: A polo match where Felicity shape changes to pretend to be Dorian and Dr. A and Ladon may or may not drug the horses...
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nJeff_B_Slater \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nMay 2017 \n edited May 2017
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n We played Preserverant at Story Games SLC. The game definitely has a lot of mechanics and procedural elements for story game. The challenge scenes we're not as drawn out narratively or as interesting as I would've liked. The social scenes were also lacking; I was the only one who rolled dice to generate a prompt for my social scenes, and I would have liked to see the other players give the mechanic a try. The players also agreed on tone but this lasted all of fifteen minutes. I'm going to split the groups up by tone because players who have been trying to get a more serious, dark game have been frustrated by those introducing a lot of silly, whimsical story elements. So we'll see how dividing the groups up by tone works. I would like to try Preserverant again; I don't think we got everything out of it we could. I wish I had a good AP video to watch of the game; especially, one that featured the creator. If anybody knows of a good one and could send me a link I would really appreciate it :-) cheers :-)
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nCaroline_Hobbs \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nMay 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n We had a couple late-comers to our Story Games Olympia meet-up last night, so I split off from the Microscope game that was getting underway to run Fiasco. We had an awesome time playing the News Channel 6 playset, with some seriously good love-triangle action. We had by far the happiest Fiasco ending I've ever experienced, with all of us rolling high. So we had a very nice buddy montage at the end, with the crew forgiving each other for all the treachery, and getting back to what really matters--quality news, handsome chins, and sweet crimes.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n

        \n\nJason_Morningstar \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nMay 2017 \n edited June 2017
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Caroline I love that!

        We started a game of Grey Ranks, which I haven't played in years. I'm playing Halina, a Communist true believer whose Thing Held Dear is her Faith - in the Communist Party and the Armia Ludowa. That'll go well.

        Also William Nichols' Solar Light and Sail, a space pirate PBTA game in playtest. Yarr!
        \n

        \n\nBen_Robbins \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nJune 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Continuing our Blades in the Dark game by smuggling a package into another shipment where it will slip through customs undetected\u2026 Inception?

        Played Follow at Story Games Seattle and tried to change the world by unlocking the secret of genetically engineered beauty. The science is easy, but the ethical questions are a massive bucket of worms, which we leap and frolic in. As we dig deeper into our characters' motives, the recurring question becomes "Do you think you're beautiful?"
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n

        \n\nchiarina \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nJune 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n We ended our "Fear Itself" introduction adventure in a big, chaotic showdown. It was action time: After a murdered old lady, a burning farm, shot dogs and a conquered ghost, the characters were able to leave the place shattered and heavy wounded.

        Our last unsolved problem: Are the characters still friends?
        \n
        \n
