        \n\nHasimir \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nJune 2017 \n edited June 2017
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Our Urban Shadows campaign keeps going on, and our KUMU map expands accordingly

        Fun times. But I feel kind of uncomfortable with a bunch of game mechanics. Maybe it's just mental adjustment from classic AW to how US handles things
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nfrenzykitty \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nJune 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n I ran a session of my new game KARMA (currently on Indiegogo) with 3 other players (2 of which had never played a RPG before).

        The module we played was GEMINI, which is about a crew of astronauts responding to a distress call from another ship. It turned into a very dark and creepy psychological horror story in deep space - complete with freaky hallucinations and inexplicable visions.

        It was awesome. It was also lovely to see 2 people who have never played a game like this get into it and loving the experience.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nRafu \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nJune 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n I'm far behind on reporting, but last Sunday afternoon we managed to bring our Everway-hack campaign to an ending. A great ending.

        The adventure itself was a mixture of refugee crisis and haunted/faerie woods, with humans as pawns in the competition between local "little gods" and the workable solution hinging on reforming local religion (which of course we did). There was collateral damage, including a beloved NPC being turned into a flower.

        Now, we'd started the session under some pressure to get to an ending, because over the previous two adventures Free's position had become untenable as a sphere-wandering character, having developed duties both as a husband and father in a realm and as a military leader to a whole exiled people elsewhere. But getting to a full resolution required Merry's issue - of sharing a body with the powerful, dangerous Brother and not having enough life-force left to sustain the both of them - to be resolved somehow. Attachment to Merry had gradually grown to be my character Ink's main issue, his aim as a wizard having long been to grow powerful enough to somehow separate Merry and Brother, or otherwise save Merry's life while not sabotaging his original mission (of containing Brother so it won't kill people).

        The twist in this particular session was that, as a side-effect of various powers the enchanted woods had, Barbara arranged for Ink to be able to speak to Brother at last - an actual spoken conversation. While the conversation didn't actually reveal anything we didn't already know as players, it was an emotional turning point, putting great pressure on me, as Ink, to take immediate action to save the Merry-Brother dual being from themselves. Still, my means of doing so hadn't improved from previous sessions - at first I felt stuck, in need of a deus ex machina. In fact, a fresh look at the assets we already had was all was needed.

        Now, I'm really satisfied with the game system I've designed, because as we entered the crisis-resolution segment of the session I still had no idea what to do. It really was the interplay of cards on the table to push me into hard choices and finally inspired me to go for a Gordian solution: Ink magically remade himself into a vessel for Brother, with help from Free (who has a permanent power to free prisoners from their magical constraints) separated Brother and Merry, and absorbed Brother. Then, Ink remained in the faerie woods, where Brother couldn't do any harm - Merry chose to stay with him.

        Nothing of the above was planned before being pulled off, and getting there required me, as Ink, to make some really hard choices: choosing to retain my knowledge of magic over retaining my freedom and choosing to save Merry's life over saving Onyx's (the recurring NPC who'd become Ink's lover). This was especially agonizing, and I cried for Onyx a bit.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nCaesar Slaad \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nJune 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Trifecta week again:

        Night's Black Agents - In my Dracula Dossier game, during the Coldfall House scenario (previously described), the players said they looked for news reports in the areas, so amongst the other clues, I dropped in a clue about an old man who was found wandering the woods. This might have sounded like a typical "lost elderly man" scenario, but in truth, it was an "Cushing", one of the annotators of the Dracula Dossier and an old MI6 spy involved in a Dracula-related mole hunt. They players find him and find out that his daughter has been mind controlled into injecting him with a strange substance that are costing him his health and lucidity.

        So they kidnap him.

        On the bright side, once they cured him of the serum he was being injected with, he was a trove of clues about the mole hunt. On the down side, now I have to come up with the facts behind the mole hunt. (On the other bright side, after a long string of "what conspiracy related asset are we going to whack this week", it sounds like an authentic mystery the players might be intrigued by again.)

        Mutants & Masterminds - Though I wasn't sure my adventure ideas were fully formed, I decided to "pull the trigger" on an adventure I have been brewing for a few weeks. An villain that has intrigued me was called Dollface from the threat report book, an MCU-Ultron style self-replicating robot. Dollface is less about world domination than she is about play-acting. Though this is rife with possibilities, I wasn't sure what to actually do here. But the first thing that occurred to me here was one I have seen show up a few times in televised media: a wild west simulation (see "Westworld", the Star Trek episode "Specter of the Gun", and the Red Dwarf episode "Gunmen of the Apocalypse".)

        So I constructed a scenario in which the Sheriff in a small rural county appeals to the Big City Supers Team[TM] for help when two deputies disappear in a ghost town, and subsequent investigation reveals what appears to be a ghost town plucked out of time in a barrier that shuts down all advanced tech. Though it is made to look like some weird time displacement phenomenon, it was actually an advanced ruse where Dollface is playing out an old western story to the tune of "Shane", "The Magnificent Seven", and "Pale Rider".

        Overall, it went swimmingly, in no small part because it was not the sort of "villain of the week threatens the city" fare that my players were expecting. They figured out if they played along with the story Dollface was laying out, the could figure out what was going on. They learned a bit more about what Dollface is, and she/it will be back in the future.

        Pathfinder - I'm trying to draw my Razor Coast stuff down so I can return to the main continent where I have been brewing some ideas for the players. In the prior session, the PCs found what they came to the island for, but found out the mage who was supposed to teleport them home is MIA (which is a central mystery of upcoming adventures), so they have to wait for a boat to arrive to take them home.

        So they did some odd jobs, so I decide to pull one of the best backstory bits to the fore before we leave the Razor Coast setting. They get hired to investigate why a lighthouse has went dark, but the first mate of the ship they hired to get them to the island offers the PCs a little extra if they can look for signs of the Razor's Edge, the ship that belonged to the captain lover. The first mate thinks that something smells wrong about the popular story about how Jacob Razor died.

        And of course, he is correct. After the typical dungeon crawl stuff with the lighthouse, the players find the wreck of the Razor's Edge and the ghost of Jacob Razor, and learn of his tragic betrayal.

        The Razor Coast campaign, as written, goes on much longer than this. But I plan on cobbling together a few adventure for our exciting finale next session.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nRafu \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nJune 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Played Seth Ben-Ezra's Showdown for the first time earlier today. It was quite good, though a bit taxing on our creativity.
        We went for an X/1999-inspired occultpunk aesthetic: members of some secret society of (qabbalah-themed) wizards dueling with powerful psychic powers in a modern cityscape. Superheroes by some other name wearing black trenchcoats, doing parkour on high-rise buildings and making windows explode, in other words.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nIchthyarch \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nJune 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \nKingdom for the first time. Cactus flats became Bull Lake, MN during the Dakota War of 1862. But Bull Lake is a made up place. I was Mrs. Noerdstrom, the Mrs. Olsen to Bull Lake's Walnut Grove. Ended the game shouting orders to the posse in the burning doorway of St. Olaf's church.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nLisa Padol \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nJune 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Kerberos II: Machinery of Life, where, as usual, there's the nominal plot, the one I think I'm running, have prepped, and, you know, do run, and then there's what the players have decided is the plot.

        So, I figured, okay, we do a contest to see who wins the polo game, and maybe the bad guys get to kidnap someone. And that did happen, sure.

        But, what I didn't expect was all the effort on cheating spent by the PCs. Our mad boys, Dr. Alexander and Ladon Green, decided to drug the horses.

        Well, that was Ladon's idea. Dr. A found that utterly unaesthetic! Genetically modify the horses so you're not just giving them a temporary boost -- stronger, faster, better, horsier!

        And the philosophical discussion blindsided me.
        And there were shennanigans, as this was no easy thing to arrange.

        Oh, and Dorian Gray snuck into a zenana. Felicity, clockwork heiress, pretending to be Dr. Alexander's assistant Charity, first pretended she was under a curse, turning into a man one day a month, and had lost track of the days. We dubbed that persona Charles / Chaz. She convinced a friend in the zenana to be sympathetic and let her hide until the embarrassing curse passed for the month.

        Then, she switched with Dorian. So, Dorian as Charles / Chaz explained that the curse would last till dawn, while Felicity now transformed to look like Dorian so that the apparently Not A Sports Guy Dorian could crush his opponents in polo.

        Oh, but she was annoyed at the horse drugging / modifying, wanting to win as herself, so she made sure that the other team got one of the two modified horses.

        Yeah, I kinda lost track of not the what, but the why, once or twice. The why had to do with establishing where people were so that folks in disguise wouldn't be suspected of being someone other than whom they pretended to be.

        Anyway, Dorian got kidnapped because he was Obviously a Spy, and his identity will be discovered next session. Oh, and the kidnappers have a very large grudge against Dorian.

        And, Dr. Alexander got kidnapped by a Promethean scientist (why yes, yes I am using Victoriana and Dark Harvest), and as the player can't make that session, NPCs were sent to rescue him, especially as two of them were his "children" (i.e., he built them).

        We have one more session before we go on 6 month hiatus. I have no idea if cliffhangers will get resolved.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nBen_Robbins \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nJune 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        Ichthyarch said:

        Ended the game shouting orders to the posse in the burning doorway of St. Olaf's church.

        \nYou are doing it right.

        Played Wanderlust, a new game still in development, where you explore the days in a protagonist's life leading up to an important journey. Our journey? Travel to the wise hermit and kill him. The hero's would-be beloved left our humble village to seek out the wise man, and then she turned her back on the secular world (and us) and entered the priesthood. Our hero doesn't know what the wise man said to her, but he's going to find out\u2026 and then kill him for it.

        Digging into the "hero"'s past and deciphering the nature of their questionable relationship got extremely interesting. We carefully sidestepped some very obvious stereotypes and got into complicated human stuff.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nCaroline_Hobbs \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nJune 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n We played Shooting The Moon in honor of it being on the Diana Jones Award shortlist. Our Beloved--a daring high schooler trying to win the battle of the bands. Our Suitors--a dorky bass recorder player and a serious cowgirl. The prize? The dedication of a song at the battle of the bands. My suitor won that dedication, by golly. The key to a punk teen's heart is apparently won through flirting in the rain and sick recorder/guitar jam sessions, and sadly not through horse innuendos.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n

        \n
        \n\nJeff_B_Slater \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nJune 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n We played Fiasco. We were going to play Remember Tomorrow, but we had too many people and not enough facilitators. This week we are playing the Shab-al-Hiri Roach and I think we'll be good on facilitators.
        \n

        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nkilocharliekilo \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nJune 2017 \n edited June 2017
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Played Wanderlust with Ben last Thursday and Praxis: Odin's Eye last night.

        The Wanderlust game started off a bit too tropey, but as Ben mentioned above, we fortunately started to step away from the stereotypes the further along we got. We had to unfortunately cut things short, but I think if we'd kept going for one or two more scenes we would have gotten to where I was hoping we would get with the "complicated human stuff."

        Praxis: Odin's Eye was with a new group of folks I'd never played with before. It's got a set scenario: your starship detects a distress beacon on and alien planet and is sent to investigate. We had a brutal first few scenes, starting with a crash landing and following up with two or three scenes with our crew getting badly battered. Three of our crew members hunkered down in the ship while two of us decided investigate the beacon on our own. The engineer finally succeeded in fixing one of the key components to the ship, only to cause something else to malfunction in the process. The two crew who tried to investigate rushed back to rescue the rest of the crew were destroyed in a ball of fiery glory, leaving the crew left in darkness on the derelict ship waiting and hoping their rescuers would be there soon.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nAviatrix \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nJune 2017 \n edited June 2017
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n ...well, what I played lo these last several weeks:

        Witch: the Road to Lindisfarne for the monthly "mostly kinda freeform night." I played Sir Hayden; I tried hard not to play another person cynical about religion and in crisis over their faith, but didn't quite get there :-) We let the witch go; she was guilty. Another fine trip to the good monastery.

        Montsegur 1244: This was a surprise run due to smaller than average turnout at the meeting. We had some nice touches in this one, with Pierre Roger assuming a larger role than the last time I played this. My Corba went to the stake with her head held high...until the flames touched her...

        In a Wicked Age for the Manhattan Gamers Guild minicon. Zorba and her sister-priestesses serve Raghil, the beneficent god of travelers (at least on this section of the royal turnpike). In secret, however, she serves Xochil, the evil god of evil. Somehow the prince-now-a-slave Fofo and Stavros the merchant got swept together in a dark tale of backbiting and blood magic.

        Night Witches for the minicon, me as GM. Section 2C is up to their old hijinks at Pashkowskaya station. One of the airwoman had a murky secret: she was really the Grand Duchess Anastasia. Fortunately Yusip the NKVD guard recognized her when she went to steal clothes for the talent show. The new Soviet anthem was sung with gusto, and almost nobody died! Well, except for the gal who killed a NKVD soldier. Didn't end well for her.

        FAE: Uranium Chef An amusing little game of celebrity chefs on a reality show in a space opera setting; does a nice thing with the approaches by having the regular approaches be the "reality" approaches and then having a separate set of "cooking" approaches (Sweet, Savory, etc.)

        Meanwhile prep for the last two sessions of The Unanswered Question, my Tatters of the King in the 1950s game is for once well in hand. I'm working on adapting some Torchbearer mechanics and a random geomorph tile draw game to handle the long, empty, searching dark of the Upper House...
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nAaron_S \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nJune 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n We began a campaign of Patrol, a roleplaying game of the Vietnam War that has some striking similarities with PBtA (moves and clocks). We did character creation, which was enjoyable, if crunchier than I prefer... lots of flipping between three or four disparate sections of the book just to nail down what kind of skills and weapons we had. I will say the game seems lovingly crafted, and has some neat ideas regarding a soldier's psychology. I'll try to report back in a couple of weeks.

        But next week... ORIGINS!!!
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nJune 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Since the last time, I played another session of Monsterhearts (session 4), with a fantastic car crash/chase scene at the edge of a cliff. An innocent high school dork ends up in the hospital, and how ever will they explain what actually happened to the police, when they don't understand it themselves?

        The new harm rules worked quite well once again.

        I put together a one-shot based on Monsterhearts, but very different in style and approach. It is somewhat inspired by The Long Orbit, in that it's a science fiction horror scenario - not high school drama. However, I ditched Skins and teenagers and made it about a sexy pressure-cooker on a farm in the middle of Depression-era Arkansas.

        It went really well; I'll have to write it up properly and publish it sometime. The mechanics were really fun - the players felt the pull of the supernatural as much as the characters did, and all fought over it just as I hoped they would.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n

        \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
        \n

        \n

        \n
        \n\nDreamer \n\n\n
        \n

        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \nPlayed Scene 4 of Our Last Best Hope (solitaire). I dug a bit more into the character's backstories.

        Nice vibes between two characters that keep each other sane. If they survive the mission, and it keeps going like this, maybe there will be a nice friendship; perhaps some sparks even.

        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\n2097 \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nJune 2017 \n edited June 2017
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n

        We\u2019ve played four sessions of Coursair Council, with the most recent session yesterday. (The idea is that the campaign will continue for a long time and I really hope it will.)

        \n
        \n
        What is it\u2026?
        \n

        You know how in many storygames, the \u201cconsequence engine\u201d is a bit handwaved because what people care about in those games is the drama, the decisions etc? For example, you might say \u201cIt\u2019s me, you and Jenny and we\u2019re in a car going way too fast down the highway, sixmonths later\u201d. And you don\u2019t always sweat the details.

        \n

        So, just as an experiment\u2026 we are sweating all the details. Keeping track of every arrow, every gallon of water, every dinar, every spell slot. While still setting scenes and doing drama in a fully story-game way. We\u2019re also doing something else that\u2019s unsual for story games: we\u2019re trying to adhere to, and honor, a published setting, with players studying the world book between sessions and incorporating it into their play, using some language from the setting etc.

        \n
        \n
        What are the rules?
        \n
        We\u2019re using Dramasystem (a.k.a. Hillfolk) for the setup, characters, and scenes. We\u2019re using D&D as a \u201cphysics engine\u201d (as much as \u201cCure Light Wounds\u201d counts as physics\u2026)
        \n
        What parts of Hillfolk are we using?
        \n
        We\u2019re using page 1\u201319 + page 22\u201335 + page 50\u201365. That we\u2019ve removed the procedural system (a system that I actually think is fine for what it is. Obv we don\u2019t need it if we\u2019re using another game (which Hillfolk itself suggests on page 65). The procedural system, I think has two problems: 1. While not bad, it\u2019s so unusual that it\u2019s hard to learn, remember, and use. 2. Conflict-level resolution doesn\u2019t mash well with Hillfolk. We\u2019ve had some cool scenes where violence and emotional drama have been mixed. Swords have been drawn, arrows fired.) isn\u2019t that unexpected but we\u2019ve also removed bennies and the end-of-session voting. We\u2019ve also removed the \u201csetting a theme\u201d thing (p 23 top left) which causes some cards in the precedence order to move around. Instead the DM just has a card that\u2019s shuffled around with everyone else and a random participant (player or DM) starts the session, without themes. We are using challenges, ducking a scene, crashing a scene rules etc and we are using the token economy. We reset it after every second session because we\u2019re a large group and we do drop in drop out. (We tried the count 15 scenes thing and it didn\u2019t work. With a large group the tokens get so spread out.)
        \n
        What parts of D&D are we using?
        \n

        The base edition on the player side is 5e, but five out of the ten players are using my own Searcher class. (A \u201cclass\u201d with no ability scores, no nothing. It\u2019s inspired by Searchers of the Unknown and 3:16. It pretty much has a Fighting Ability (called \u201cAttack Bonus\u201d), a Non-Fighting Ability (called \u201cAbility Bonus\u201d), and some HP and some HD and that\u2019s it. It uses Ability Bonus instead of armor class to defend itself. But we also have some players using full 5e classes with feats and multiclassing. We started the campaign at level 5 and over four sessions, a couple of them have gotten 400 xp, that\u2019s it. We\u2019ve defined xp as practical power and made a deliberate choice to not have it grow from dramatic scenes. We do have some xp for gold rules too (in the dungeon, you get the xp from monsters, but if you make money on mercantile ventures or in the domain game, you can get xp from that). We also use plenty of rules from ACKS for various things. Everything from \u201cHow many diamonds are available for purchase in Hawa this month?\u201d to prices of goods in the big coastal cities. I made my own weather rules that sticks pretty closely to 1e WSG (my work on translating the 2e DMG+Golden Voyages rules to state machines was for naught; we threw those rules out because they are so storm prone. We use 2e for boats and sailing and we use many monsters and NPCs from 2e with minimal conversion.

        \n

        We\u2019re not using minis and we\u2019re not using the normal initative system (again, because I want to mix dramatic and procedural \u2014 like how in X-Statix there\u2019s a couple of scenes where they\u2019re fighting enemies while talking about their own drama. That has happened in our game!). We\u2019re using some options from the DMG \u2013 most notably \u201clong rest is 7 days, short rest is 8 hours\u201d and \u201cLingering Injuries\u201d. And the rule from Unearthed Arcana where players make all rolls.

        \n

        We\u2019ve combined inspiration and drama tokens. You can get more than one insp, and spend them as drama tokens. Or, you can hand them all in to give yourself or anyone else advantage or disadvantage.

        \n

        We\u2019ve moved encounter checks player side and made the encounters happen on low numbers. So you can have advantage or disadvantage on them.

        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\n2097 \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nJune 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        What\u2019s the setting?
        \n

        It\u2019s a part of Forgotten Realms called Zakhara (strictly, they\u2019re based on Island of the Firethorns just off the coast of Zakhara) that was marketed under the name \u201cal-Qadim\u201d in the early nineties. It\u2019s a bit of a deep cut. I got the boxes off an auction site. We\u2019re getting super invested in this setting and are always consulting the books as our \u201ccanon\u201d. The pitch I use is \u201cIt\u2019s the A Thousand and One Nights with elves and orcs\u201d.

        \n

        More specifically, in one of the boxes there\u2019s a railroaded adventure where the PCs go up against a Corsair Council of powerful NPCs. In my game, instead, some of the PCs are on that council. In the end, only two out of the ten chose to be full council members (so we have the six \u201ccanon\u201d NPC members + two PC members) because it\u2019s often really interesting to play outsiders. Some are working to join the council, some are trying to bring down the council. Some PCs are working for Qudra, some for Hawa. There\u2019s a lot of CvC.

        \n
        \n
        What are some deets about the setting?
        \n
        The \u201csalt bond\u201d is a huge part of the game; if you eat together, you have to protect each other for three days. Qudra and Hawa are at a cold war so espionage is also a big part of it. There are also cults and yog-sothothery going on.
        \n
        How is it going?
        \n
        I was concerned that the multiple systems would clash. That they would create a very narrow window of possible outcomes. That setting scenes together would be difficult if travel is difficult. That \u201cplay to lose\u201d is harder when you can die at any time. So far\u2026 it\u2019s been amazing. It\u2019s the most ambitious campaign I\u2019ve ever been a part of. People are so invested.
        \n
        How is the prep adherence?
        \n
        (Since we\u2019ve been talking about D\u2192D and H\u2192H before.) It\u2019s a mix of improvised elements and prepped elements. Trying to use my normal fallback plan, sometimes I only realize later that \u201cOh, I could\u2019ve rolled for that\u201d. For example, yesterday, they met two random smuggling corsairs from another crew. I could\u2019ve rolled randomly among four or so crews that it would made sense that they were down there. Instead, I just chose one that I thought made sense. I realized after the game that rolling could\u2019ve been a possibility. We\u2019re doing a lot of transparency of method so the players know perfectly well how the game is set up.
        \n
        What\u2019s the CA?
        \n
        (James, it\u2019ll only be this one paragraph, OK? Because I know some people are curious.) This is a big lab. And we have some players who are hip to RPG theory so people are sometimes trying to immerse, sometimes trying to stir up drama, sometimes trying to explore a dangerous location. In other words, people change their CA and try different things. It\u2019s not ouija-boarding because the game is setup to be able to do drama fully and to do investment in everyday life fully. Like, following the prayer routine (the party are split between being devout followers of Najm and devout followers of Jisan \u2014 religion is a big part of the game) or working on repairing the boat. Or looking for treasure maps or caring for the prisoners. Or confronting each other about failed romances, sibling rivalries, vying for position to be rubban (a sort of captain) on the zarug (a type of ship). And sometimes it\u2019s play to lose, sometimes it\u2019s play to win.
        \n
        How\u2019s the separation between character knowledge and player knowledge?
        \n
        It\u2019s a mix. For example, the players know that one of the PCs is a full-sworn spy for Qudra, but their characters don\u2019t know that. They have to pretend (this is story game basics). But there are plenty of BIG secrets that the players don\u2019t know either; both things the DM is keeping from them, and that the characters are keeping from each other. Managing this mix well is a big part of the game, it\u2019s a challenge for all of us but it\u2019s also been the biggest source of interesting events to happen in the game.
        \n
        \n

        Thank you for reading, my friends. As usual discussing this in detail is not appropriate in the \u201cWhat did you play this week?\u201d thread so start new threads if you want.

        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nRafu \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nJune 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n

        \n We played Ars Magica and had a funny session with a faerie market. The characters tried to free a human from the chains of faerie by incorporating the attending faeries in a drinking contest (with faerie wine). The notorious drunkard was successful, but later he annoyed everybody with his drunkenness. Now the characters have new problems.

        \n
        \n@Paul_T William Nichol's game in playtest, Solar Wind and Sales. It's still rough around the edges but really fun - characters don't have stats - the ship has stats and your actions and abilities influence them. I hope he develops it further. It is full of really clever flourishes that my group just adored.

        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nJames_Mullen \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nJune 2017 \n edited June 2017
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n At the third Birmingham Indie Games meet-up, we played Christoper Dean's Is It a Plane?, a super-hero game that uses the physical drawing of comic-book panels as a resolution system, sort of like RPG Pictionary.

        We also played Conspiripedia, which revealed that almost every sort of contest/award ceremony in the world (including Crufts, the French Tennis Open and the Eurovision Song Contest) was part of a plot started by the Incan Empire in honour of the constellation of Taurus, using cumulonimbus clouds to spread their mind-control drugs.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n

        I feel weird even posting about it.

      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nLisa Padol \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nJune 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Down a player for Monsterhearts, so we broke out Fall of Magic. Didn't finish, but reached a good pause point.

        So, the first scene, all the PCs were doing their own thing and didn't know they'd become the magus's companions. There was Caspian, the Knight of Stormguard; Piccolo, the Giant of Mistwood; and Harp, the Swineheard of Barley Town. Harp was running after his pig, Bessie, the Legendary Pig of Barley Town.

        Folks declared that Bessie was the magus.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nJune 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Nice, Lisa!

        What a musical troupe you have.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nLisa Padol \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nJune 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        Paul_T said:

        Nice, Lisa!

        What a musical troupe you have.

        \nNo one's broken into song yet, but it could certainly happen!

        Tonight, we played Diaspora. We managed to save Old Terra, which, to our shock, is trying to have an actual, functional government. We thought we might have doomed the cluster outside of Old Terra because of an alien invasion, but discovered that Green Sun has a less lethal version of the plan that old alien tech had for Old Terra, aka hide until the aliens go away by cloaking the entire planet and maintaining radio silence. This is surprisingly workable.

        So, we now have to go to Galliard to save the children of one of the PCs and then find a place to hide from the invasion. Green Sun is ideal if we can get back there without compromising it. Old Terra will work if we can get there, but my PC, the Butcher of Old Terra (it's complicated: He didn't commit the first atrocity, and the second was only him nuking his own castle to try to kill a monster. No one other than gods and monsters were there at the time. And then he became emperor briefly and is now believed dead.) isn't so eager to go back there. He'd originally thought joining a circus would work, but now thinks the group should make movies to entertain all the sentients hiding out during what will become known as The Long Silence if we don't screw up and get everyone killed...
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nAdam_Dray \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nJune 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \nD&D 5e (Mirrorrim megadungeon) last night.

        Highlights:

        After clearing 15-20 rooms...
        "How much of this level have we explored?"
        "Like 15%."
        "Holy crap. This place is huge."
        "This is only level one."

        An ochre jelly crits Diana's half elf fighter 1, who is only on her second expedition into the dungeon (one regular player has reached 3rd level). I roll 23 damage. She has 11 hit points. That is enough to trigger the instant-death rule, meaning no death saves, no "just 0 hit points." It means dead-dead.

        I add my third "tally" mark on the room near the dungeon entrance on the map. Three character deaths in the Ancient City, level one.

        Players have been posting (on a FB group) individual recaps after a session to earn "Heroic Inspiration" (a d6 that can be added to a d20 roll like Bardic Inspiration). Some of these are written in character. The bard wrote hers in verse.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nRafu \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nJune 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Was to a "retro" themed gamers' meet-up last weekend, where I run:\n
        \n
        Sorcerer (3hr slot)
        \n
        "In Utero" convention demo scenario from Sex & Sorcery. The idea was to give everybody a taste of Sorcerer, and I believe I at least managed to pique their interest, even if the "story" itself remained unfinished. In retrospect, I may have spent too much time explaining rules and going through the character sheets, background, etc. On the other hand, I prioritized pointing out the differences from "here's your character sheet" convention one-shot freeform scenarios the players might have been familiar with, and I don't regret my choice.
        \n
        Dungeon crawl (3hr slot)
        \n
        Using The Full-Dark Stone adventure location by @Fuseboy and Tunnels & Trolls 1st Edition (1975) rules. This is a game I regret we didn't manage to finish, because I was definitely having fun - it could easily have gone on for 3 more hours, really. Even unfinished, this was, in fact, my most satisfactory attempt at running a dungeon crawl, ever. I had clear expectations I managed to communicate the players, and they honored them and we all had fun. Exceedingly optimistic predictions re: time management were my only serious mistake (need more practice). There are not just one but two other threads about this game already, so I'll post the details there, eventually.
        \n
        GM-less Everway-hack (3hr slot+a 2nd 3hr slot w/lunch break in the middle)
        \n
        My preciousss. After playing a full home campaign of this, I took it to the meetup to showcase it and earn bragging rights. We played a 4-players one-shot with original pre-gen characters out of the box: Amber, Clarity, Detritus and Serenity. The Realm we ended up in was an island-tower (actually a huge hollow tree) ruled by a mad toymaker, who kidnapped people to remake them into living toys to appease a crazy Wonderland-ish "queen" who was actually a toy he himself had fashioned after his own late mother. Scary. It was a good fantasy adventure one-shot and I feel proud of my work (even if that work amounts to mixtaping half a dozen existing games).
        \nThere could have been a Witch Quest game, as well, but there wasn't. The 4 time-slots I had available (over 2 days) were assigned to games out of my list based on anonymized player-preferences and, apparently, Witch Quest wasn't as popular as the other 3. Next time!
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nkilocharliekilo \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nJune 2017 \n edited June 2017
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Played Praxis: Odin's Eye again last Thursday (I like to make sure I play games twice before pass judgment on them.) We had a lot more romance and a lot more action in this game. We had to cut the game short (we had several very long ensemble scenes), but everyone seemed to enjoy themselves.

        On Monday at the SGS play test I ran Remember the Time a game I'm working on about a group of estranged friends meeting up and recounting stories about "the good ol' days." Players go in and out of the "Present" and "Stories" being told in character by one of the cast members; in Stories the Players play each other's characters at the direction of the current "Storyteller."
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nCaroline_Hobbs \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nJune 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Played The Final Girl for the first time at our local meet-up. We wanted something a little more lighthearted (you know, for a slasher film), and came up with Count Chocolate and the Sugar Mansion. We (a bunch of candy people and one meatloaf) were all mysteriously invited to the house by the dashing Count, and one by one we were picked off. But the Count was just a Red Swedish Fish--the real killer was the house itself!

        One of the things I guess people run up against in Final Girl is that the killer seems to teleport around, but having the killer be the setting really helped us negate that potential problem. The one thing I didn't enjoy was all the failed murders. It felt like the killer failed a lot of times before it succeeded, and that kind of sapped my energy. It was fun to narrate the close calls, but I wish there had been fewer of them.

        Molly Meatloaf was our survivor by the way, and boy howdy does she have a weird idea about candy lifestyles now.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n

      What did you play this week? (2017)

      \n
      \xab1\u202645678910\u202612\xbb

      Comments

        \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nJeff_B_Slater \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nJune 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n We played The Shab-al-Hiri Roachat story Games Salt Lake City. We had some problems getting the rules down; the two facilitators had to absorb or than rather quickly because they didn't have much time to prepare. We also had a bit of trouble interpreting some prompt cards. Two of our players showed up about an hour late and this made prep even more time-consuming and difficult. Plus, we played with about seven, possibly eight people, which I think was just too much. Anyway we only got done with about one Event, and a couple people lost interest and we just called the game at that point. The other facilitator and I, really like the game and want to play it again. This time will get the rules down better, get set up done quicker and not allow people to be excessively late, and make smaller groups so we can get into the game much quicker. Anyway, it's an interesting game and I definitely want to try to again with a smaller group so that things don't get out of hand, are easier to manage, and the time to please cut down. We certainly would've played in small groups if we would've had the rules are better.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\n2097 \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nJune 2017 \n edited June 2017
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n

        We got played by the god damned Corsair Council like a fiddle!

        \n

        When Grima comes knocking you better have answers. A giant eye peering into your window.

        \n

        Jayani and her crew kicks in your door and Ministry\u2019s \u201cBad Blood\u201d starts blasting. After kicking your ass, she drops off a rolled up carpet and says \u201ctake care of this, and we\u2019re square\u201d.

        \n

        Azira, gray-haired, leprosy-scarred\u2026 seeks out her lover from when they were young, Yufar, and begs for a new chance. His liver is made of stone.

        \n

        A teen in way over her head, Ibiala, picks up a sword for the first time and says, without a doubt, \u201cI can do it\u201d.

        \n

        Esari, the goblin musician, was the only one to pack food for the trip to a treasure island.

        \n

        Tarala just wanted to ask Setara a couple of questions. With her bow. And arrow. In fact, forget about the questions, except: where can I buy a canoe in the middle of the night?

        \nSession five of my Dramasystem / D&D hybrid!
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nLisa Padol \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nJune 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Ran another session of Kerberos II: Machinery of Life, where Ladon and Felicity decided to rescue Dorian before exploring the secret mountain pass. This went well, but does mean that the secret mountain pass will have to wait until the game picks up again, as Dorian's player is traveling for the next 6 months and the rest of us figure we'll wait until the player is back.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nDreamer \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nJune 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        Actual Play: Our Last Best Hope - The Killer Asteroid - Act 1 - Scene 4 - Taking on the Threat

        I think this scene came out well. It was fun, in part because I got to engage more with the crunchy bits, and also got to engage with the parser (which output is the closest thing I've felt to roleplaying with someone, especially when the phrases pretty much demand no interpretation, or something close to that.)

        Still using the text parser for dialogue and also now for a "Narrator" who might frame the scene. I'm using the the movie transcript text assigned to MIMIC (the MIMIC 'voice') for the Narrator and NPCs in this scene at least.

        I've still had to occasionally dig deeper into the parsed text for phrases that fit the context, especially when the conversations relate to relationships between characters. Chalk that down to the downside of randomness and the contents of the movie transcripts. A well chosen or constructed text to parse might fix this but I'm committed to the texts I assigned.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nBen_Robbins \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nJune 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \nRemember Tomorrow last week (reskinned for fantasy) and A Thousand Years Under the Sun this week.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\n2097 \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nJune 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \nBen, what was your take on the games?
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nFelan \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nJune 2017 \n edited June 2017
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Solid session of Carolina Death Crawl, which has been sitting unplayed on my shelf since it came out in 2013. Plenty of depravity and gothic spooks - I was definitely channeling Ben Wheatley (especially Kill List and A Field in England) for my contributions. It's a really cool concept and I would love to see more similar card-based games purpose built for particular kinds of stories.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\n2097 \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nJune 2017 \n edited June 2017
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n

        Started my side campaign, 1001 Nights Off.

        \n

        The idea is other characters, perhaps other cities, perhaps other rulesets, same continuity. For when we have smaller player counts. Two\u2013three players + DM. For extra games (we already did the main CC game this week, Thursday).

        \n

        We played Cthulhu Dark. Beggars in Qudra, 1367. (Qudra is the city that\u2019s at war with Hawa in our main campaign.) It suited us very well and my players, one of them had been stoked AF and the other had been very reluctant, they both liked it. I turned Ammot (a weird al-Qadim\u2013monster) part of the life cycle of Dark Young of Shub-Niggurath, and I also had that when the cult (the Hand of the Gray Queen) had made the nest for the DYoSN, they had unearthed Hook Horrors (from the 5e MM) and trained them to do their bidding. So there were a mix of different monsters which I was concerned would dilute the horror but eh the session was good!

        \n

        I wrote the scenario using the random template generators in Silent Legions, pretty much by the book with two tags, but instead of Silent Legions custom pantheon and bestiary, I used the above mentioned D&D monsters + the DYoSN from Trail of Cthulhu \u2014 and the \u201csample investigation\u201d cues in that book I applied to the scenario that Silent Legions had generated (it just happened to fit very well). I generated a random gross dreamscape in donjon.bin.sh which one of the characters constantly got sucked into when he got insight. Every time, the stinking mire was higher and higher and he carved for longer and longer.

        \n

        Then Microscope for the first time. We used Chronicle right away (after a while, I explained \u201cand this and this are the differences compared to vanilla Microscope) and one of the players said\u201dYeah, but I can see why the exp added these, I like these changes\u201c. (Not saying we\u2019re never going to do vanilla, just that we\u2026 really loved Chronicle!)

        \n

        We did the story of the party\u2019s boat from the main campaign from before our nakhuda and rubban Kezim bought our zarug (zarug is a type of boat), the Ummuhm. Apparently it got the name 150 years ago, when it was built to contain a wildly rampant djinn!

        \n

        It was a wild story with fights against sea monsters, enemy fireball blasting sorcerers, and the Ummuhm was at one point shrunken down to tiny size and put into a bottle! The players wanted to continue this one game of Chronicle, they\u2019re like \u201cthere\u2019s so much left to fill in!\u201d We only did two lenses (i.o.w. I, the first legacy, never got to be lens). And, we were so tired. We didn\u2019t do the \u201cthis is going to be the last focus\u201d thing either because we thought we would play longer. But we played so wildly. I was jumping around and laughing as the djinn Zobeida and her (also djinn) husband Hafam. I was playing the scenes like kids would play them!

        \n

        A lot of our scenes were very short. We\u2019re not used yet to not answering the question right away. Our very last scene we kind of got the knack of it. I understood where the player was going\u2026 but it wasn\u2019t explicitly stated.

        \n

        OK, one more thing about Microscope. The advice in Explorer is that the stories often aren\u2019t pretty good as linear stories. They feel good at the table but when you tell it in chronological order, it\u2019s often \u201cyeah, of course\u201d. So since I want to write up our 1001 Nights Off games as \u201ctales\u201d for our campaign site, that has been a riddle for me. But\u2026 it\u2019s Scheherezade-style! I can go tale in a tale! First tell the story about how Dusty \u201cOne-Armed\u201d Karim fled the ship after it being sunk by a fireball spell. Then later tell the story about how he, years prior, added the nickname \u201cOne-Armed\u201d in a fight against gawwar samakat (an already established sea monster in our campaign\u2014we paletted it). Then later tell the story about when the ship was in a bottle, then later tell the story about how the ship even had met the djinn Zobeida in the first place etc etc. I can wrap it up in fiction instead of as if it were an AP report, but I can still get the more interesting order rather than the chronological order. Best of both worlds\u2665

        \n

        We were playing slowly because we had been playing an intense game of Cthulhu Dark, then got candy and were learning Microscope, discussing the rules, and also discussing our main campaign, talking about it and things that were going on in it. (Which\u2026 is one of my underhanded goals with 1001 Nights Off\u2026 to increase the players (including my own) knowledge about the setting, the situation, the genre, the political geography etc).

        \n

        Edit: Oh, yeah, palette thoughts. Our palette was pretty\u2026 \u201cwell, most of these are pretty obvious but we added them just to make sure\u201d-ish. Since we\u2019re playing in a very well defined, established setting, al-Qadim (and, trying to get to know that setting even better is one of the points of 1001 Nights Off). One good addition was gawwar samakat, a sea monster that\u2019s been legendary in one of the PC:s backstory in the main campaign (but who hasn\u2019t shown up in the main campaign yet) through our fanfics about that PC. The fact that it was added made we could discuss beforehand if it would be kosher or not to feature in our Chronicle. Another good addition that another player added was \u201cIn this chronicle, the Ummuhm can\u2019t spelljam, but other spelljammer ships can feature\u201d. Very specific and very clear.

        \n

        Edit again: Instead of the cards, we used an outline program (I have a pretty souped-up org-mode with my own hacks). I type faster than any of our longhands, so I was taking dictation. We weren\u2019t sure about how good the overview was since we\u2019ve never played any other way. It\u2019s the first time I\u2019ve ever used any sort of digital thing while roleplaying. (We\u2019ve played Fiasco from PDF, which works for me because you only do it during setup, tilt & outcome, not while actually doing the scenes.) But we liked this well enough.

        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nkilocharliekilo \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nJune 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \nA Thousand Years Under the Sun on Thursday with a sci-fi skin; our communities were forming within a Dyson sphere encircling a black hole. In general, map building games aren't my jam since I prefer character-driven games, but I wanted to give it a try since it was mentioned in the thread about world set up procedures. It went well, and the ebb and flow of growing and dying of the elements is a nice touch. There's some basic procedural stuff that's left vague by Matthius (mainly regarding how to go about drawing the initial map, so we borrowed The Quiet Year's/Deep Forest's "each person adds an element" bit,) but overall solid and easy to go through.

        I did a terrible job taking a photo (hope you don't mind me sharing it here, Ben), but here you go:


        Click for full-size image.

        I'm running Session 0 for a 15-ish Session 7th Sea campaign this evening.

        @Dreamer, I'm intrigued by your play of Our Last Best Hope; when I played it with some friends a few months it did not go well...I read that rule book several times, but there were still way too many various pieces to keep track of, and there were several times when were sat there going..."Wait? Why are we rolling?" Maybe I'll have to read your play and give it another shot.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nRafu \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nJune 2017 \n edited June 2017
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Played The Devil, John Moulton over the weekend, which we spent at our friends' home in the mountains. It had been on my "try this sometime" list since @NickWedig publicly released it, and our friends who were hosting really liked the elevator pitch, so we chose to play this over a couple other games I'd brought. It was a pretty good game - more of a long one-shot than the "mini-campaign" we were hoping for at first, but a good, satisfactory one-shot.

        4 players, including me as the GM; we drew hands of 6 cards to create characters and I used the full d20 for John Moulton's Way of the Demonic Overlord. There were two betrayal-type secrets between the three PCs: "I'm secretly working to undermine the posse" and "I want to join Devil John not kill him". While some of us really liked creating characters by drawing cards, we found the resulting characters a bit overwrought, with too much backstory at 5 cards each.
        We especially liked the collaborative town-creation method. We played through 2 towns and rolled dice a lot. In the 2nd town, after finding out who the sorcerer was and a first, botched attempt at confronting her, players started hitting their endgames...

        When they went to burn down the sorcerer's poison-making lab (in the abandoned local church), "Jeremiah the Coward" finally showed his true colors and shut his former companions in with the rattlesnakes and raging fire! In the ensuing conflict, Jeremiah's Way of the Bastard ending was triggered and he became a demon.
        Former teenage arsonist "Indian Will" made it out of the burning church carrying the dying "Dead Jack" in his arms and buried him in unhallowed ground, knowing he would eventually rise from the grave come next full moon - then went hunting for Jeremiah the Demon to extract from him the whereabouts of Devil John. "Indian Will" did meet the demon formerly known as Jeremiah, but it had the drop on him and demanded he revealed where Jack was buried, so it could finish the job. In the ensuing confrontation, Will's Way of the Soul ending was triggered and, after struggling free from the demon, he rode back to his home county and confessed his crimes: having atoned for his sins, but keeping the location of "Dead Jack's" body a secret, he eventually died on the gallows.
        In due time, "Dead Jack" rose from the grave. After a second, failed attempt to learn something from the town sorceress - in which he ended up killing her, despite his own scruples against killing - he went on to commit sins which would "recharge" his demonic miracles. In doing so, he confronted a corrupt sheriff, who was actually another of Devil John's many minions, and hit his Way of the Bastard ending. The demon-sheriff told Dead Jack that John Moulton had been watching him and testing him and, together, they rode out into the night on nightmare horses to join the warlock's all-demon posse.
        (John Moulton's Way score was then down to 5 vs an endgame value of 1, no scars)

        We had a lot of fun brainstorming escalations of sin for demonic miracles, though in practice we found it difficult to "calibrate" them. We later reasoned you have to make a price very generic in order for the character to ever get a chance to "pay" it, since players don't frame their own scenes. One of "Indian Will's" demonic miracles - he could start fires through his concentrated gaze - had a price of denying a thirsty man water, but that never came up (despite a player introducing the idea of a poisoned water supply when creating town) and the miracle was never recharged. I guess the problem was with the verb "to deny" - you need something proactive.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nDreamer \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nJune 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        kilocharliekilo said:


        @Dreamer, I'm intrigued by your play of Our Last Best Hope; when I played it with some friends a few months it did not go well...I read that rule book several times, but there were still way too many various pieces to keep track of, and there were several times when were sat there going..."Wait? Why are we rolling?" Maybe I'll have to read your play and give it another shot.

        \nThe game does have a sort of cheat sheet summary at the beginning, but it's not complete. Maybe after I finish this game, I'll create a step by step cheat sheet for myself (I did the same for Shock).

        Watching Mark Truman Diaz facilitate the game on a youtube video helped a lot, especially seeing how he prompted the players to flesh out the fiction around the Threats. I've still managed to mess up by forgetting to add harm, to reduce the size of the threat, give myself story points, etc.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n

        Dreamer said:

        \n
        \n Origins!

        Love in the Time of Sei\xf0 (As always I was the Earl. Nobody wants to be the Earl!)
        A Green and Narrow Bed (My game about grief and revenge, in playtest)
        WINTERHORN (My game about how states abuse power, in playtest)

        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nCaesar Slaad \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nJune 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Ran Mutants & Masterminds again. It's become my favorite regular game.

        This session was a setup for a later game. I am planning on a "24" style session where the world pretty much comes down around the players. But I wanted to introduce one of the architects of this, a trickster-assassin named Deathtrap.

        I decided that the mob called Deathtrap in because they want revenge against Maximillian Mars, an industrialist who turned on them and became a benefactor to the Sentinels, the PC hero group.

        I pictured an array of distraction attacks to keep the players busy while he hatches his plot to kill Mars. He did this via a fake villain who made demands (a la "The Mandarin" in Iron Man 3). I wanted to feature one fight for the players, so I made one of the demands of the fake villain to release a bunch of super criminals, and then have a bunch of booby traps go of.

        But the players thought out of the box and decided that they would try to enlist the aid of Dollface (see my last post), a robot with a penchant for faking IDs. I liked this idea, so I rolled with it. But as a consequence, there were no fight scenes, just challenges and capers.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nDreamer \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nJune 2017 \n edited June 2017
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \nTook on the Threat of the first scene of Act 2.

        On my prior scene, I messed up another rule regarding effects after a roll. I thought only amounts above 5 or above caused effects. We should have taken harm in some rolls, and the threats should have been reduced further in other rolls. In other earlier scenes, when Black dice were added to the event pool, we should have also gotten story points, but I forgot.

        So, the mistakes all kinda balance each other out in a way that did not give me a massive advantage or disadvantage. Still, it's a bit stupid, because I think I played it correctly before. I need a cheat sheet.

        Despite all that, I feel like I'm warming up to the game again. The incentive to have a character die emulates this sort of material pretty good.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nadmanb \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nJune 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \nGodbound - a one-player game I'm playing with my girlfriend. Godbound and DCC pretty much completely turned me around on OSR (from opposite directions!) It does such a good job of describing demigod powers with a clarity and flexibility that fits rulings-not-rules like a glove, and the Dominion system gives the PCs influence over the world like few other games do -- but like a demigod should.

        My biggest problem with Godbound is that I find prepping for it a lot harder than my other games. The vast power of the PCs means they have the ability to solve just about any problem, much like a narrative game, but unlike a narrative game you don't really want to wrap them in a complex web of consequences.

        But it's going well so far. Right now Tola is working her way through a hostile city full of warped cannibal thralls and giant glutton lords, trying to gather information about the curse that ruined them.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nRafu \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nJune 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \nAbnormal Things by @Orion Canning. Our Slovenian seaside village, at the beginning of tourist season, ended up devoured overnight by huge, bloodsucking, multicolored moths - actually a manifestation of the ghosts of abused children. Scary.

        It was a good one-shot game. I've tried a lot of games aiming for this kind of horror film-ish structure, including a couple incarnations of Geiger Counter, but this was better than most of them. Although, to be fair, the three of us were a really well-oiled group, having already played Okult (still my favorite), Archipelago (with a very similar small-town horror setup) and a full Everway-hack campaign together over the last year, amongst other things. Compared with Lovecraftesque (also quite similar), that there was a chance of triumphing over the threat - no matter how slim - motivated us to run headfirst into disaster. We'll never look at a butterfly the same.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nBen_Robbins \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nJune 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        2097 said:

        Ben, what was your take on the games?

        \nThis wasn't my first time with either game. I've played Remember Tomorrow a bunch of times.

        We played Mind of Margaret at Story Games Seattle. Bryce Fletcher (not his real name), body double to Hollywood sensation Hank Miller, *wants* to be a real actor, but there's one problem: he can't act. His ultimate achievement becomes starring in a deconstructionist arthaus film that focuses on the dichotomy of his terrible acting and his place as Miller's shadow. Victory..?

        One of the very cool things about Mind of Margaret is that you can play fairly ordinary events in a way that's still very interesting because we're seeing it from the point of view of the conflicting emotions in the protagonist's head.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n

      • \n
        \n

        \n\nDreamer \n\n\n

        \n\nJune 2017 \n

        \n Still chugging along with my solo game of Our Last Best Hope.

        Act 2 - Spotlight Scene 2
        Act 2 - Taking on the Threat

        The combination of game mechanics and parsing movie transcripts still surprises me.

        \n\nJeff_B_Slater \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nJune 2017 \n edited June 2017
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n We playtested my universal story game, Story, at Story Games SLC this week. It was a very good playtest and I learned a lot; I'm creating the next version of the game based on the feedback, etc. I'm very excited about the process and about refining and perfecting the game.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nJames_Mullen \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nJune 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n I played Troublemakers yesterday, with Jack Reilly playtesting his playset for my game-in-development: Trouble at Chapman Lake had three kids uncovering the existence of lake monsters in their town as they investigated their missing belongings.

        It all ended well with their possessions retrieved from the Giant Turtle that was in hiding as the island in the centre of the town lake and the kids made friends with the younger lake monsters, inducting them into their gang.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\n2097 \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nJune 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n

        CW graphic violence, cultural appropriation

        \n

        1001 Nights Off! We did Chronicle again. The consensus was (and I was pretty neutral on this) that the crew that started the last chronicle could continue playing it for a while (I was feeling pretty happy with it as it was but there are always more stories to tell about that ship. This time we started telling the story about Setara\u2019s jambiya. Plenty of NPCs from the main campaign figured.

        \n

        I was good about not \u201cGM:ing\u201d that part of the game (as per Microscope\u2019s warnings); the ideas the other players had about them really fit in with my view of them.

        \n

        But\u2026 we ran into problem with people trying to game the system to get more of their own \u201ctelling\u201d in.

        \n

        I was the first to be guilty of that. I was legacy and wanted to add a dictated scene but I had no event where it fit or even a period where it really fit. So I thought \u201cMaaaaybe it can be tacked onto this event\u201d [really far fetched]. I wasn\u2019t feeling malicious, I wasn\u2019t thinking \u201chehe I can get away with something\u201d, I was thinking it was fine. But that is how selfish acts are done. \u201cMaaaybe this is fine\u201d.

        \n

        I ended up really regretting that.

        \n

        It created a lot of contradictions and knots and made it hard for us to place other scenes. When it became untenable, we had a talk about it. We did two things to fix it \u2013 we changed it from a dictated scene to an event, and we renamed the period for it to fit. (Yes, so out of place was it that it didn\u2019t even fit in the period!!!)

        \n

        It was changed to \u201cBint digging up the knife from a lonely grave on a Beauty Mark island\u201d and the period\u2019s name was changed from \u201cSetara has the knife\u201d to \u201cSetara gets the knife\u201d.

        \n

        Both of these changes benefited me\u2026 I got more \u201ctelling out of it\u201d. OTOH, it was the cleanest fix. But later another player tried a similar thing. He wanted to start an RP scene.

        \n

        We already had the event \u201cBint hears that the knife once cut of the caliphs fingers\u201d and the scene \u201cBint hears how the knife cut the fingers and summoned efreet from another pirate, hears the directions to find the adventurers that has the knife, but kills the pirate after hearing the directions\u201d.

        \n

        I said \u201cI want to add \u2018Bint chases after the adventures\u2019 as an RP scene\u201d. (Normally he\u2019s good about doing Question, Setup, Required/Banned, but now he said this.)

        \n

        And we were like\u2026 \u201cThat sounds like an event\u201d but he said \u201cBut I want to do it as a scene\u201d and we said \u201cOK, cool, but what event would that be attached to?\u201d and we had this long long frustrating talk about what are scenes, what are events. And we were talking honestly about how we both had been trying to game the system to get more scenes in. (If we were playing with physical cards we might have avoided this argument.)

        \n
        \n

        Another frustrating \u201cgame the system\u201d clash came when I had set a scene and put in: \u201cRequired: Spared adventurer. + At least one member of the Blue Roses\u201d and \u201cBanned: Nahua\u201d. So I was last to pick. First the spared adventurer got picked. Then another player (not the same as the one in the last clash) picked \u201cI\u2019m another member of the Blue Roses, heh heh, so you have to be the member of the Blue Roses\u201d. I mean\u2026 can you do that? I wanted at least one member of the Blue Roses to be present. And as soon as that\u2019s satisfied, the requirement is satisfied\u2026?! And I can pick freely?

        \n

        And that very same scene led to our fourth problem. We knew from playing that the knife was found buried with a body in a lonely grave.

        \n

        And I put the question \u201cWhy did Bint [the captain of the zarug \u201cThe Blue Roses\u201d] spare one adventurer\u2019s life?\u201d, set up \u201cOn the lonely island\u201d, and the character requirements above.

        \n

        And I had the idea, held pretty loosely, that Bint killed all the others but let one adventurer live for longer, I had no idea why (hence RP scene), but that that adventurer was going to be the body in the lonely grave. But, in order to make the idea looser in my mind, I put out \u201cAt least one member of the Blue Roses\u201d instead of \u201cBint\u201d (who was anchor character for the period btw). But when the \u201cSo you have to pick the member of the Blue Roses\u201d trick got pulled, I said \u201cFINE! I\u2019ll pick Bint then. OK? So it\u2019s settled.\u201d And the idea really solidified in my mind.

        \n

        And the player of that adventurer really tried so hard to avoid getting put into that lonely grave. And I was thinking \u201cMAN he\u2019s so stubborn, he\u2019s ruining the scene\u201d. In hindsight, of course I was in the wrong there. He was following the rules. The other player, the \u201canother member\u201d, he was thinking, like me, that \u201coh, so that\u2019s the body in the grave, how satisfying, of course it is\u201d, (To our credit, there was a misunderstanding: the player thought \u201cThe question was \u2018why did you spare?\u2019 so we need to play the scene so that I\u2019m spared\u201d, while the rest of us, including me, the question poser, thought the question was \u201cWhy had this adventurer, who was now about to be killed, been spared up until now?\u201d \u2014 To our anti-credit, he is within his right to misunderstand the question like that, willingly or mistakenly. It\u2019s my duty to pose questions clearly and unambiguously, and to roll with the punches when someone finds a \u201cloophole\u201d especially when they find it by mistake) so we started pushing for the adventurer to be killed anyway etc etc. But before we put it to the vote, the adventurer said \u201cWait. How is killing me answering the question?\u201d and the \u201canother member\u201d saved the day and started asking me, IC as Bint, \u201cOh, captain, by the way\u2026 why did we let her live?\u201d etc etc and we resolved it. And we let it unknown whether or not the adventurer was the body in the lonely grave or not. Phew. Long story over. Sorry.

        \n

        We were good about arguing, about being honest about our own bad behaviour and how we felt about the others\u2019 behavior, and we all said \u201cthis was a really good session overall and let\u2019s play Chronicle again soon\u201d. The topic drifted to cultural appropriation and al-Qadim and I\u2019m glad that we all said \u201cYes, it\u2019s a problem, potentially a big problem\u201d. It was a sign that we\u2019re approaching it with open eyes. (It was a longer discussion but this is but a margin!)\u2665\u2665\u2665 [I know I dropped two bombs here, us struggling with learning the Chronicle rules + politics! But. Don\u2019t. Or, rather: new threads! I promise I\u2019ll show up there.]

        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nchiarina \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nJune 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n We had another session about the question "Do you know the moment you\xb4d better stop?" in one of my Ars Magica groups. The players knew it. They preliminary fixed the problem, but didn\xb4t attack the boss villain (waiting for times, their mages would be more experienced). They are no heroes, but as long as they discuss the different options it\xb4s o.k. for me.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n

      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nOrion Canning \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nJune 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        Rafu said:

        Abnormal Things by @Orion Canning.

        That sounds like an awesome and creepy game, makes me think of the moth-man, and stories with flesh eating bugs that are usually afraid of light. Were the moths attracted to lights? That's even more scary, if you have to be careful not to let them see your flashlight.

        All the games I've played have taken places in America, albeit often strange and remote places in America. I'm curious where you're from and how a Slovenian town might differ from an American one. It's always good to hear from people playing a game I made so thanks a lot for talking about it!

        Rafu said:


        Any links?
