        \n\nJason_Morningstar \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nJune 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Chapters 4 and 6 of Grey Ranks last night, and now I am off to wizard school.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nDreamer \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nJune 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \nOur Last Best Hope - Act 2 - Spotlight Scene 3

        Got a little bit stuck here. Either it's my tiredness or maybe it's a weakness of the transcript or the parser. I think it's how the movie transcripts slant. Scenes where I'm not focusing on personal lives, but rather on the crisis and actions related to it have gone faster and smoother. When the focus is on personal lives and relationships, I've had a harder time finding results I can integrate or riff off.

        Still, it sort of worked out here with the pauses and changes in subject (which provided surprise). Oracle questions also came to the rescue (a last resort for me).
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nAviatrix \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nJune 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \nLovecraftesque Alex is a single mom in a small town, working at the local chemical plant. She's been dreaming of her grandfather, who took her from the former Soviet Union when she was just a little girl. Her son has an imaginary friend who lives in a hole in the basement. So how the heck did he find her grandfather's medal from the Great Patriotic War? And is Mr. Giggles Baba Yaga or some nightmare congery of hairless rats? A fun little whirl through weird fiction.

        Masks of Nyarlathotep Caesar the tabby is one of Bast's generals; he can talk, but only Arthur Chamberlain, who is a clear Cultist first-round draft pick, can hear him. Down in Dhashur the Clive Expedition is clearly up to no good, Omar Shakhti seems to be ready to dark sorcery in order to bring back his long-lost love, and the Black Pharaoh has a conversation with the Investigators in the Bent Pyramid. Can they escape to Kenya with the whole of the Egyptian cult on their tails?

        The Unanswered Question, my Tatters of the King 1950s remix. The Investigators finally reach Bolivia hot on the trail of the Soviet mission to bring the King to Earth. In Oruro, the Diablada has a special guest star in tattered yellow robes; the Stranger tells Temperance she will dance before all this is over; and everyone seems to chant "El Rey" whenever Candace is around. (And none of the other Investigators have noticed she's pregnant.) On the Uyuni Salt Flats, Temperance and the Rev have a final duel; there's a crucifixion involved, and the loss of a dream-companion. Charleston confronts his darkest self over mate, and at Condor Station some Odessa graduates attempt to off the Investigators. Now on to Potosi...or Leng...
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nWilhelm \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nJune 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Vampire the Masquerade. Third play session of our story.

        Paul, I'm thinking of a good way to fill you in as you asked about it.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nJeff_B_Slater \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nJune 2017 \n edited June 2017
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Paul Taliesin, David Berg, Jonathan and I played Inconceivable!, which is a game that Paul Taliesin is designing. It is an interesting game and I will probably post a write up about it and some feedback and ideas regarding the playtest when I get an opportunity. I definitely want to play the game again. The approach Paul is taking to designing the game is unique and campaign they've got going is very interesting.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nJeff_B_Slater \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nJune 2017 \n edited June 2017
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n We just played a game of Follow at Story Games SLC. It was a really cool and interesting game. We were a faction of English spies who were attempting to assassinate a Chinese strong man who had been prompt up by the English crown in exchange for providing the empire with Chinese resources. The Chinese strong man was very vicious and we were acting covertly against the will of our own crown and benefactors in an attempt to assassinate him. The session was frustrating being that we again had trouble getting on the same page regarding tone. This isn't a game issue, it is a recurring issue we have faced regardless of the game we played. A few of us have wanted to play a session with a serious tone, we have stated this in the beginning, and everyone has agreed to a more serious tone, but at some point the story tone goes off track and gets silly and lacks verisimilitude. Tonight we got about halfway through the game and a player who typically likes whimsical games started doing things like just randomly throwing dynamite at people. He just got obsessed with blowing things up, because that's what's fun to him. We have great games a lot of the time, but some of us really want to scratch the itch and have a serious session and it just doesn't seem like we've been able to find a way to do it, even when we've been explicit and forward about what we've wanted and reached agreement and consensus prior to the session. Even when we try to drop polite hints and try to reel someone back in. It seems that one or two people just don't seem capable of playing a serious game. Not a game without humor, just a game in which the dramatic tone isn't broken with absurdities. We don't want a serious game all the time but we do want the ability to have one, so it's been frustrating for a couple of us.

        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nRafu \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nJune 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n@Jeff_B_Slater my suggestion to you is: try to act a stronger host and curate the group of players. I don't suggest you compromise SG SLC by doing so: having an open table in a public space is wonderful. Rather, select a few players who you believe really want a change of tone and invite them to play a game together in a private space, on a different night. Think of that as "the next stage". Scheduling will be the hardest part, but do try.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nJune 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n (For what it's worth, I agree that "picking the right team" is a big part of getting the right tone or creative consensus. I'm always thinking about that when I put together a game, and I think it's really key. However, game design can accomplish a lot of that as well. Jeff, I know you love the game, but from what I've seen of it, Follow does very, very little to help people get on the same page and stay there! Even Fiasco does a lot more to help people get on the same page. It might help to consider the needs of the group and lean on games which give them more of that.)
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nJeff_B_Slater \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nJune 2017 \n edited July 2017
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Thanks for your great suggestions, Rafu and Paul I don't want to derail the tread with my issue, so I sent you message Paul.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nDreamofpeace \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nJuly 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Hi all, I played Monsterhearts 2 - story details are on my gaming blog, hollowsandhobgoblins.wordpress.com. It started as just a one-shot, but everyone got into the story and wanted to continue. The rules for the most part worked fine, but players had a bit of trouble sometimes interacting with NPCs - there's no "manipulate NPC" rule anymore, so you have to either turn them on or shut them down - if you weren't trying to kill them or run away
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\n2097 \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nJuly 2017 \n edited July 2017
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Played Corsair Council, session 6. Least good session so far, yet we all decided to keep the campaign going.

        Standard 2097-style dungeon crawl (which in itself is good), but, slow and plodding due to two out of four players being sleep deprived and also (perhaps tiredness-induced) language barrier. One player constantly asking things that have just been stated. The other mostly spacing out, staring silently before answering.

        We kept to the precendece cards even though it was all dungeon. As a guideline, I used 40 diegetic minutes, 15 extradiegetic minutes, or one major room or dramatic exchange.

        Drama, we had way fewer real drama scenes, maybe three or so (but I've made a point out of not judging the value of proceducal vs dramatic \u2014 the player who's turn it is chooses).

        The problem was the slowness of the procedural. The puzzles were difficult but they dealt with them.

        Oh, and this started our first foray into one of the Yawning Portal dungeons. Looks good so far. As a curious aside, one of the 2e monsters that I've converted from one of the CotGS dungeons showed up in an official 5e version. So unbelievably nerfed. But, lower xp accordingly, so that's fine.

        Overall, I'm happy about the campaign and we already have NO-sessions scheduled this week also.

        Edit: It sounds like I'm putting all the blame on the two tired players (we were four players + 1 DM = total). I should add that my slowness in parsing the wordy room descriptions in the YP book was just as big a problem.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nWilhelm \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nJuly 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n I played PSIRUN. It was very elegant!
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n

        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nBen_Robbins \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nJuly 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \nKingdom at Story Games Seattle.

        When the new Archbishop of the Church of England forbids contracts binding demons to work on Sundays, the senior partner of our firm has an inspirational meeting with one of the founding partners (whose ghost haunts our office). He gets in touch with his inner lawyer, remembers why he started practicing demonic contract law in the first place, then goes all Phoenix Wright \u201cOBJECTION!\u201d and sues the Church in court.

        Which is a beautiful moment of character growth. And then the mob comes for us.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\n2097 \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nJuly 2017 \n edited July 2017
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n1001 Nights Off, this time starting a new subcampaign (as always, in the same timeline / era / continuity as CC) using the Dogs in the Vineyard ruleset.

        Mamluks, w swords instead of guns and tattoos instead of coats. We sort of mixed the roles a bit too much, giving the mamluks farisans abilities to drive off efreet. I ported over a lot of the same concepts; such as them being fresh-faced teens, combined mailmen+religious police etc. They were part of the al-Wajid section.

        For the law we used the very detailed code in the Land of Fate boxset, adhering to the rule that the GM shuts up as the players and their PCs make the calls. We skipped all that 'gender roles' stuff, let's hope the game works anyway. Even with endoqueer relationship problems such as 'just pretending to love someone' or 'wanting to leave someone'. But yeah, there's a lot less to work with The original DitV setting is about patriarchy to a great extent. (I know there are Jedi hacks etc so I don't think it's integral to the game.) Weird, the original AA book presents a patriarchal world but the tone quickly changed in the boxsets that followed (men in niqab, polyandry etc), and I'm grateful for that.

        I'm going to reread the rules after the session because there were some "huh\u2026 not sure how this part works"\u2013moments. How often to roll demonic influence etc.

        And, one player wanted to make an inner conflict about whether or not he could bring himself to execute a killer. Which I thought would've been supercool to play out but I didn't know where I would've gotten the dice? It wasn't initiation, it was mid town.

        Also, we didn't finish the first town. We were too tired, or, I was. Even though we had only played for two and a half hour or a little longer than that.

        We are going to give the game more of a chance with the same characters. And are witholding review until then.

        Ofc, a lot of what DitV presents as new, such an "GM, you are not allowed to have a solution in mind", are standard to us. But some things were new even to us. Like the fact that it's not a mystery/exploration game. The cards are supposed to come out on the table and I tried the best I could with that.

        Edit: just to be clear, we are playing it RAW except for the changed setting. I know for example "rolling for talking / convincing" is anathema in my own designs including CC, but in Cthulhu Dark and esp in DitV, we do use these rules.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nJeff_B_Slater \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nJuly 2017 \n edited October 2017

        \n
        \n
        \n\nJames_Mullen \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nJuly 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n We had Birmingham Indie Games #4 at the Geek Retreat today and I MC'ed a game of Monsterhearts for four players (plus one latecomer who happily played one of the antagonists as an autonomous character).

        The usual twists and turns ensued as we zeroed in on the meat of the plot, which culminated in an epic werewolves vs. androids battle in the school grounds after midnight! I thoroughly enjoyed it and had the pleasure of introducing two new players to the joys of PbtA games, one of whom seemed keen to purchase and run the game himself for some online play on Discord.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nRafu \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nJuly 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Played Clank by Tim C. Koppang while on a train ride on Thursday.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nJuly 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Played Lovecraftesque with a group of five players; we had a fairly delightful spiraling-out-of-control narrative despite differences in style between the players.

        (I'm not convinced we handled the endgame portion correctly, that said. Putting everything together for the finale felt difficult; quite a creative challenge.)

        Having the Watchers are "off-screen helpers" for detail and scenery was helpful.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nAviatrix \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nJuly 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n I was at Dexcon 2017 so I played a lot of games...

        Time Capers, with Kat Miller
        Dogs in the Vineyard, GMed by the amazing Saraphina
        With Great Power GMed by our own Bill White
        The Lady Blackbird, a Lady Blackbird in the Caribbean hack GMed by the sublime Jeff Collyer
        Noir World, facilitated by author John Adamus
        Witch, the Road to Lindisfarne facilitated by myself
        Masks, GMed by our Queen, Kat Miller
        The Watch, GMed by the ever-cool Shane Liebling
        Tales From the Loop GMed by Jeff Collyer
        Montsegur 1244 facilitated by myself
        Psi*Run, chased by Shane Liebling

        There were no bad games in that mix, but for me the standouts were Lady Blackbird and the Watch.

        In the games I facilitated, Witch had a couple of interesting takes: our Armond was very much a middle-manager type illustrating the banality of evil, and our Hayden apparently never went on the crusades because he was busy burning heretics at home. (I played the nun, and wrote an absolution scene for her that I'm pretty happy with.)

        Montsegur had a very interesting mix of primaries, with the Amiel/Faye/Arsende triangle working as the engine of the game. I was pretty satisfied with my weary and disillusioned Pierre-Roger--in the opening prologue, he was rather cold-blooded in telling a wavering Garnier that the inquisitor had to die, but subsequently I played him as destroyed by that murder, his confidence wrecked by that act of murder.

        This was a terrific con, and a great time meeting awesome people and catching up with my friends from previous cons.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\n2097 \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nJuly 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n

        We played the fifth of our 1001 Nights Off, continuing the Dogs in the Vineyard subcampaign.

        \n

        Writing this part ahead of posting the post-play report tonight because I just finished prep for the second town.

        \n

        Using some story cubes, the al-Qadim hierarchy of sin (Fortunes & Fates pp 16-17), and a random NPC generator, and relying on my experience running Sine Nomine style tag-mashups as a guide for what feels \u201cgrabby\u201d, I was done in a few minutes. Also hooked in some existing NPCs from the main CC game. The end result was a much more focused town and one that looks like it\u2019s going to feel a lot more true to our take on al-Qadim.

        \n

        I used the aQ sin hierachy and the NPC generator last time as well, but this time I felt more sure about the process and it went faster and looks better. Just like how the first time I\u2019m walking somewhere new in the city, it feels like it takes ages because I\u2019m unsure \u201cis this the right street\u201d etc; even though I\u2019m constantly walking in the right direction, the minutes fly by and it feels like it takes ages. But the second time walking there I relax, just walk, and it feels a lot faster and straighter. The last town had too much stuff, this might have too little. We\u2019ll see. I feel good about it.

        \n

        Also, after last time, I was like\u2026 \u201cthere\u2019s not going to be much left of this DitV town generator process if I\u2019m going to be so post-poly & endoqueer about the sex stuff\u201d. But now I feel relaxed in thinking that there are many other things that the game can be about. Last time started with skipping prayers, felt a little tame so I cranked it up to public drunkenness, felt even tamer so it got to murder right there in the first town. End result: a pretty messy town with a mix of \u201cthis is what the fuss is about?\u201d with \u201chmm, this might be a bit much for the first town\u201d.

        \n

        OK, the rest of this post was written after the session. We had a great session, more coherent, more believable, very thematic with lots of info on the mamluk\u2019s dutiful branch, lots of CvC, lots of very nearly dying, lots of doubt and angst!

        \n

        The conflict was over some stolen weapons. I was kinda thinking that a more innocent crime would be a great contrast to last time and I think was right. \u201cDo we really kill them for hiring someone to steal weapons?\u201d

        \n
        Trix, would love to hear some more about your Watch game!
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nJason_Morningstar \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nJuly 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n I've been away at New World Magischola, where I played different crusty professors on two consecutive weekends.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nLisa Padol \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nJuly 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n I was at DexCon where I was in:

        Wednesday night's Cthulhu Dark, where I was one of a group of immigrants trying to figure out what had caused our English instructor to go mad

        Thursday afternoon's With Great Power, run by Bill White. It was a blast, but I still don't quite get the system, possibly because I've never played Swords Without Master

        Thursday evening's Call of Cthulhu, an Invictus adventure I'd read, but the GM assured me that this wouldn't matter, and was basically correct. The problem with this sort of thing, for any decent gamer, isn't resisting the temptation to use out of character information. That's easy. It's figuring out when your character would figure it out and not playing to dumb. For various reasons, this is less of a problem in this particular scenario.

        I was the only person signed up for the Thursday-Friday midnight-4am slot, so the GM did the sensible thing and cancelled this slot. This was good because my next game was --

        Friday morning's This Favored Land, run by Bob Dushay

        Friday afternoon's Beyond the Wall, which was a lot of fun, but when you get right down to it, it's the sort of game I'd use Everway to run. Also, it was in Calcutta, which meant we were all shivering from the chill. OTOH, I got to play the Village Bear! Hard to beat that.

        Friday evening's Masks game, run by Kat Miller, with a big bad who was simultaneously sympathetic and impossible to compromise with. She'd be making sense for a few minutes, and then -- Nope. Just nope.

        Friday midnight's Blue Rose, AGE version, with more combat than I'd expected. A lot of fun, though the system feels one step too complicated for me, and I'm not sure which step that is. I really hope it'll get a Fate conversion one of these days.

        Saturday afternoon's Tales from the Loop, where, as one of the other players put it, we saved the 80s from dinosaurs using a walkman.

        Saturday evening's Montsegeur 1244, where, yes, my primary character burned for his beliefs.

        Sunday morning's Agents of the Si-Fan, a valiant, multicultural group fighting against British imperialism in the form of Bulldog Drummond and his men. We played this one pulpy, but utterly straight. Also, I have a lot of fascinating source material to look up, including a movie called (in translation, I'm sure) Ghost Lady.

        Sunday afternoon, we caught Spider-Man: Homecoming, which did not suck.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n

      What did you play this week? (2017)

      \n
      \xab1\u20266789101112\xbb

      Comments

        \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nCaroline_Hobbs \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nJuly 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n It was Go Play NW this weekend, which means I got to play so many awesome games with so many fabulous people!

        I kicked it off with a really great, thoughtful game of Downfall. We saw a family fall apart as their small city-state slowly declined. Lots of sweet father-son sadness.

        Then I got to play the single raunchiest game of Fiasco that has probably been played.

        On Saturday, I played One and Many, a game in playtest about mythic beings shaping the world. It was surreal and beautiful, and I'm very excited for it to finish development!

        The afternoon slot was Breakers, which is a World of Dungeons: Turbo game. We may have gotten an F for loot, but we got at least a C in friendship?

        Then in the evening I facilitated an excellent game of Follow using the Gods playset. We kinda played modern gods trying to hold on to mortals as they spread across the stars, but mostly we just played office politics! It was super fabulous.

        Sunday morning I got to play Sign, a larp based on the development of Nicaraguan sign language. It was really fun and interesting, and if you ever have a chance to play it, you certainly should.

        And then for my final slot, I played My Daughter the Queen of France, one of my absolute favorite games. Shakespeare, once again, does not understand his daughter.

        It was an amazing con!
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\n2097 \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nJuly 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n

        Corsair Council session seven. Second session of the big dungeon crawl (there\u2019s been some light exploration of subterranean water ways in the first five sessions but for the last two full sessions, we\u2019ve been in dungeon mode proper).

        \n

        I loved the session and thought it was better that the last. Talking about it with the players, we\u2019re not so sure. The main points of drama was between NPCs vs the party; a rival crew of pirates that have entered the same dungeon. The dungeon exploration was slower because we break for scenes, but then when we do post-hocs on the scenes (as per Dramasystem) the players are like \u201cOK, I guess that was a no conflict scene\u201d or \u201cOK, I guess that was just a pipe / infodump scene\u201d. It\u2019s like they gear up to do drama but then the other player just gives.

        \n

        And the dungeon part was super finchian and detailed. We spent like twenty minutes on what turned out to be the inside of a secret door. They thought it was a trap they had to disarm. We had some meta talk about that as well, I said that I know a lot of people online disparage DMs that require pixel hunting but they said that they do like it generally and that I should keep it up; it just happened to take up a lot of time this session but that\u2019s a risk that\u2019s worth it to them.

        \n

        We also invited a new player, someone I don\u2019t know and he only knows one other person. I want to have more women in the group now and more people that doesn\u2019t have as much trad experience. But he said, after the session, that he wanted to read Hillfolk as soon as he could (\u201cto see what\u2019s going on\u201d). This guy is very welcome and I appreciate having a new player since so many of our regulars are away fror the summer, let\u2019s see how he works out. large player pool is great since we\u2019re doing drop-in/drop-out.

        \n

        Yeah, I dunno. I loved the session. \u201cBut\u2026\u201d

        And I don\u2019t know what the \u201cbut\u201d is.

        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nCaroline_Hobbs \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nJuly 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \nFollow at Story Games Olympia. We played the Colony, and were religious settlers on a planet where someone else had gotten there first. There were some pretty awesome power plays, compromises, and betrayals throughout. Red/red is so brutal, and yet so satisfying.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n

        \n
        \n
        \n

        \n\nRafu \n\n\n

        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n First playtest of a game I've co-written for Game Chef - using a pseudonym, so I'm not telling you anything more yet. Just that I walked away from the playtest feeling moderately satisfied.

        \n\nWilhelm \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nJuly 2017 \n edited July 2017
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Today the new play by post game left the prep stage and entered the first scene. I am excited.

        It is a small one-on-one game. I'm GM:ing a single player.

        The game is play test of the setting for my new game. Cyber M/77.

        \n\nJason_Morningstar \n\n\n

        \n We finished out Grey Ranks game this week.

        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nBen_Robbins \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nJuly 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n At a little event we call the Go Play NW, I played Paranormal Rescue Squad, Follow, Finding Haven, Geiger Counter, and Dialect.

        At Story Games Seattle I played Microscope and Firebrands.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nRafu \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nJuly 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Last week I played Shooting the Moon for the first time. In a dark fey wonderland reminiscent of Labyrinth (the motion picture) two very different sorts of (ultimately human-made) faerie -- Barbara's nameless tortoise-man and my Paper Prince -- vied for a promise of eternal friendship by Luna, a mortal girl who'd ventured into faerieland, Alice-like, to escape some private pain. It was really good.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nBen_Robbins \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nJuly 2017 \n edited July 2017
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \nFaith at Story Games Seattle. We thought it was a heist game but we wound up in a simulated Soviet town the feds had used to test bioweapons, in North Dakota. Correction: *haunted* simulated Soviet town. A literal ghost town.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n

        \n

        \n\nWilhelm \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nJuly 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n The Cyber M/77 game continues. Yesterday we saw the phrase "fashionable leg warmers" in the game. Good times.

        We've had session zero for a campaign of upcoming Swedish Sci fi RPG Den Yttersta Domen. I'm playing an apostle/missionary for a cult which sees the approaching destruction of a space station as a divine event.
        \n
        \n
        \n

        \n
        \n
        \n\nRafu \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nJuly 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        Rafu said:

        First playtest of a game I've co-written for Game Chef - using a pseudonym, so I'm not telling you anything more yet. Just that I walked away from the playtest feeling moderately satisfied.

        \nWe played part 2 in the aforementioned game (which I might be convinced to talk about if asked insistently enough, now that the peer-review phase is over). This was expected to be the final session but nope - there's going to be one more.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nLisa Padol \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nJuly 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Playtest of Fearful Symmetries for Trail of Cthulhu, where everyone's pulling with equal force in different directions, which is perfect because everyone's on the same page and advocating equally for spotlight time.

        Last night, a run of our amnesia larp, Jamais Vue, which went astonishingly well. I'm not sure it's ever run so well when I was one of the GMs before (it's been run plenty of times, with and without me). Part of this was we had amazing players, and part was because three of us had gm'd it recently and noted where the bumps were and managed to smooth some of them out, and our fourth gm... well, let's just say this wasn't his twentieth rodeo.

        JV is very much a case of "a work of art isn't finished, merely abandoned" -- we've been tweaking it ever since that very first run, lo these many years ago. And, naturally, on the ride back, we had a couple of ideas for next time...
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n

        \n
        \n\nMike_Sands \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nJuly 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \nBlades in the Dark, our crew's second session. Tonight's score was a train robbery (in the station, rather than between cities) of a military shipment. New enemies were made (an Inspector and the rat catchers' guild) and urchins recruited! Lots of fun.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nFelan \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nAugust 2017 \n edited August 2017
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \nThe King is Dead - much like MF0: Firebrands, the format really lends itself to the genre/setting. One player found it hard to grok the restrictions of the system and complained about it, which caused a bit of friction, but everyone still had a good time. I think they felt slighted by outcomes that were not favourable for their character/faction, so next time I'll really foreground that "we're all here to tell a good story together" in my pitch.

        The plot was very convoluted, ending with the usurper house tenuously winning the throne by marriage to the current ruling house, with another war practically inevitable.

        Standout moment was a seemingly suave prince completely squandering his chance at a valuable alliance by being too awkward and hesitant in a love scene.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nLisa Padol \n\n\n

        \n\nAugust 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n

        Paul_T said:

        (Lisa, the LARP run wasn't taking place in Ontario, Canada by any chance, was it?)

        \nNo, in Massachusetts.

        \n
        \n
        \n\n2097 \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nAugust 2017 \n edited August 2017
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n People coming back from summer vacations so we're gearing up for Corsair Council on Friday. But, we're getting a lot of "actually I'm going to quit the game" which bums me out. I read one such message just moments before Dogs in the Vineyard, session three of the subcampaign of our side stories (1001 Nights Off). I didn't put my heart in the session as GM, I was too sad! The session was OK anyway, the players played off each other well. But

        Feeling so bad about gaming right now


        Edit: A lot of people just left for the summer. And, one of them wrote that they're not coming back. And I extrapolated it to mean that a lot of them wouldn't come back. But, now they've written that they will come back & they've given dates. So that's great news.

        I lost a lot of steam as a DM because of the summertime lull. Last year we were playing pretty much daily in the summer.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nRafu \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nAugust 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        2097 said:

        People coming back from summer vacations so we're gearing up for Corsair Council on Friday. But, we're getting a lot of "actually I'm going to quit the game" which bums me out.

        \nThat's surprising to hear, after all we've heard of Corsair Council so far! O_o
        Have you had any chance to get feedback about why these players are quitting? Does it look like their perception of how well the game is doing is at a strong disconnect with yours? Do they not enjoy it as much as you?

        \n\nJason_Morningstar \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nAugust 2017 \n edited August 2017
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Monsterhearts, PSI RUN and Cthulhu Dark

        At Larp Shack: New Voices in Art, Serpent of Ash and Welcome Guests.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nAugust 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n I'm running my ongoing game of lightly-hacked Monsterhearts. Really enjoying the slight creative dissonance between me (as MC) daydreaming some larger and sinister action and events behind the scenes happening, while keeping the actual focus on the small-scale drama between the characters.

        In the last session, for example, the PCs conspired to throw the poor kid who ended up in a wheelchair (as a result of their earlier actions!) for their group effort to cheat on a chemistry test. This poor guy has been forced off the road, crashing his father's luxury vintage car, then Hypnotized into stealing money from his parents to pay for the Infernal's drug supply, and finally now he's become the scapegoat for a situation where the Witch cheated on a Chemistry exam (using unexpected side effects of a Watching hex). Oh, and they tagged him with the Condition "friendless", so he's completely with any support at school.

        Poor guy. Which option do you think the player chose when he Hypnotized him? "His sanity breaks", of course. Man, that kid's life went downhill big time since he became friends with a PC...
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n

        \n\nRafu \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nAugust 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \nThe Leviathan Manifesto, by our resident @James_Mullen -- as a 2-player game.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nJames_Mullen \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nAugust 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        Rafu said:

        The Leviathan Manifesto, by our resident @James_Mullen -- as a 2-player game.

        \nHow did it go with two players?

        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nRafu \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nAugust 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        James_Mullen said:

        Rafu said:

        The Leviathan Manifesto, by our resident @James_Mullen -- as a 2-player game.

        \nHow did it go with two players?

        \nIt did OK. I mean, I can see how it wouldn't have been as creatively demanding were we 3 or 4 players (I also suspect with 5 or more, too many cooks would spoil the pie).

        The only place in the rules where the number of player characters - and by extension players - actually matters is in field interventions, which get easier the more player there are, in that you have as many "extra lives" as there are agents in the field. We only did one such scene, though, with the deck stacked in our favor (the open stack consisted of just one black and two red cards by then) and called it a success after the first card flip - because, why not?

        Further discussion belongs in the game's own thread (linked above). Let's move it there!
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nJames_Mullen \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nAugust 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n So @Rafu played The Leviathan Manifesto with two players and I asked how it went...\n
        Rafu said:


        It did OK. I mean, I can see how it wouldn't have been as creatively demanding were we 3 or 4 players (I also suspect with 5 or more, too many cooks would spoil the pie).

        The only place in the rules where the number of player characters - and by extension players - actually matters is in field interventions, which get easier the more player there are, in that you have as many "extra lives" as there are agents in the field. We only did one such scene, though, with the deck stacked in our favor (the open stack consisted of just one black and two red cards by then) and called it a success after the first card flip - because, why not?

        Further discussion belongs in the game's own thread (linked above). Let's move it there!

        \nI think there is an issue with the game design in that it leaves all progress in the lap of the players: "Did we succeed?", "Sure, why not?" So, does this game need a GM? Or some objective progress mechanic besides the 'Three Kings Countdown'?

        Reading back the game I wrote, I can see the rough patches where I've skated over some parts in order to keep the blog post to a reasonable length, so maybe a revision should be in the pipeline?
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nHopeless_Wanderer \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nAugust 2017 \n edited August 2017
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n I played five games of Love and Darkness with five different groups of EFL students: a solitary 10 year old, four 11 year olds x2 groups, ten 18 year olds x2 groups. I had to alter some of the rules slightly because the complexity was too great for EFL students English level, but the stories they created and the fun they had was great. It really worked out as a great story-telling exercise.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nBen_Robbins \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nAugust 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Played Microscope at Story Games Seattle. During the Palette we got deep into how the rules of magic worked. Almost too detailed, I thought. But because we already understood the laws of magic we barely touched upon it in play. Instead we focused on exploring the power struggles and human drama (and the cataclysmic fallout), which was fantastic.

        Also did a character creation session for our upcoming Uncharted Worlds game. I'm a sucker for click-and-lock character building (q.v. Capes or Danger Patrol).
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n

        Rafu said:

        Rafu said:

        First playtest of a game I've co-written for Game Chef - using a pseudonym, so I'm not telling you anything more yet. Just that I walked away from the playtest feeling moderately satisfied.

        \nWe played part 2 in the aforementioned game (which I might be convinced to talk about if asked insistently enough, now that the peer-review phase is over). This was expected to be the final session but nope - there's going to be one more.
        \nThird and last session of the above, and of course we already tried implementing some of the changes we'd thought up. I'm therefore writing the first major revision, scheduled for testing next weekend.

        \n
        \n\nJeff_Slater \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nAugust 2017 \n edited August 2017
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n We just played my game Penelope's Loom at Story Games SLC. It went fairly well. I learned a lot and will be removing some mechanics and trying to invent other mechanisms to try to achieve certain aims of the game. One thing I'm concerned about is that it is starting to resemble one of the games that inspired it a bit too much. Hopefully, I can improve the game, while at the same time distancing it from the other. I have some ideas and got some good feedback from the group\u2014back to brainstorming mode.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nDavid_Berg \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nAugust 2017 \n edited August 2017
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Just finished a two-shot of Lady Blackbird with one experienced roleplayer, his visiting friend, and two brand new folks. Great times. Two hardcore Firefly fans ran with that as their inspiration. As GM, I just pushed them into situations where the PCs were at least slightly at odds, and let the banter ensue.

        Cyrus and Lady B had a love-hate thing which almost resulted in the lady getting booted off the ship, but Cyrus eventually professed his affections when it became clear that Uriah Flint wanted Lady B for her title, as part of a coup scheme.

        Naomi seemed like she was about to kill Cyrus several times, then completely turned around after he saved her and Lady B from certain death twice.

        Everyone got very bloodthirsty along the way, and poor Snargle just tried to dodge the drama and minimize the loss of life.

        The closing exchange came when Lady Blackbird revealed that she was aware of Flint's scheme, and was simply planning to ride out the coup and dispose of him before he could dispose of her.

        Cyrus's response, in desperation: "I love you."

        Lady Blackbird: "I know."

        Aaaaaaaaand game.

        The two newcomers are excited about playing RPGs more in the future! Woo!
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nJames_Mullen \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nAugust 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n At the Birmingham Indie Games session today, we played Lady Blackbird and Fiasco in the space of about 5 hours: we play fast & hard. The former ended with the title character killing her pirate lover after discovering his infidelity; in the latter, we blew up a funeral parlour and lost a lot of embezzled money in the blast.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nRafu \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nAugust 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \nLast weekend I was at a local convention.

        Together with my dear co-author and friends both old and new, we played version 0.2 of our Game Chef (Italian language) entry, La vita di l\xe0 (roughly, "Life on the other side"). It was a really good game, confirming the adjustments we've made since Game Chef work.

        I also played a game of Ross Cowman's Serpent's Tooth, but a mixture of late hour, general tiredness and scenario choice ("Artificial Life" - fascinating but a bit confusing, maybe requiring some OOC discussion before play, which going right by the book we didn't have) conspired to make it not a good one. We had a hard time really listening to each other and ended up introducing too many loose threads which we couldn't tie up neatly enough.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nchiarina \n\n\n

        \n\nAugust 2017 \n edited August 2017
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Wednesday we had the first session of our "Unto the fourth generation" campaign for Night\xb4s Black Agents. We started 1877 in Constantinople. The group is formed, a first goal is sighted, an expedition is en route.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nAugust 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n The long-form Monsterhearts game reaches a frenzied climax - one PC kills another as the police arrive.

        Meanwhile, I played a test run for Games on Demand. The Games were Fate of the Norns (which was overly crunchy for what we were trying to do - I don't think anyone meaningfully had fun), Fate Accelerated (an Inspectres-like setup, though we hardly really used the rules), and a great session of Lasers & Feelings, wherein our crew saved humanity by seducing the hive queen of the alien dreadnought threatening our existence. (And I got to play a science fiction version of "the Mooch" Scaramucci!)
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nBen_Robbins \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nAugust 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Played Follow and Polaris at Story Games Seattle.

        Also played the first session of Uncharted Worlds. We're shooting for A-Team meets Star Wars, with the characters former Legion soldiers, now on the run and doing trying to do good. While we were setting up the first mission I did a quick sketch of the system they were in to jot down details we were inventing.

        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nJeff_Slater \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nAugust 2017 \n edited September 2017
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n This week at Story Games SLC we played Freeform Universal. Another player wanted to GM and they thought this game would be easy to pick up with the limited amount of time they had. It was the first time for the player GMing and they did a great job. FU isn't a game I would necessarily choose to play but its not a bad option in a time crunch. It's a little too traditional and it has a very bifurcated GM and character split, so it's not the best fit for my tastes. It probably works best as an adventure game, or at least a game where the characters are largely on the same side. Next week we are playtesting a very traditional, strait up Simulationist game designed by @Mongrel_GM; it should be interesting\u2014it should certainly be a treat for any players looking to scratch that traditional RPG itch .
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\n2097 \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nAugust 2017 \n edited August 2017
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n

        Was feeling in a rut. Did a Microscope Chronicle in a new setting, we made up a space opera setting. Super gonzo. But\u2026. it\u2019s always me that turn the story games gonzo, I guess.

        \n

        I added \u201cspells\u201d to the yes palette in a space opera game, and then there was a lot of push back and forth because once the game had started, another player added elements like \u201cany use of spells cause the destruction of the setting because \u2018spell eaters\u2019\u201d etc etc. We were battling each other about the true nature of these spell eaters. Well. My sister was in town so it was great having her participate as well. Microscope Chronicle worked well with four players, I found.

        \n

        Then two days later, we did Corsair Council, session 9. Wow. Two players who had only been in the first two sessions came back. And they brought it. So good. After two sessions of all D&D, no Hillfolk, this time it was the other way around, 100% Hillfolk. And just yes. I like it.

        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nJason_Morningstar \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nAugust 2017 \n edited August 2017
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \nMonsterhearts, then Gen Con. At Gen Con I facilitated Jonathan Walton's great game RESTLESS five times, Love in the Time of Sei\xf0 and Limbo once each, and got in three playtests of my game Welcome Guests. I played Even Torner's Itras By hack Shadow Carnival and Alex Rowland's intense larp Canned.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nColin \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nAugust 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n We had a pretty fun game of Monsterhearts, which mostly involved the AV club witnessing and live-streaming the Queen-turned-Hollow/Head of the Yearbook Committee trying to restrain our nerdy rusulka-style-Ghoul after she ate two police officers.

        Our Hercules/Sasquatch and Medea showed up to try to help. The Hercules/Sasquatch helped. The Medea ended up escellating the situation by stabbing the Queen.

        Most of the group is either in hospital and police custody, or the morgue. An odd first for me. The only exception is the Hercules/Sasquatch, who is being called "Hero Girl" on the local news, which is doing nothing for her issue of everyone having high expectations of her.

        Also, we had a very delicious dessert s'more casserole; food is an important part of our games.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nRafu \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nAugust 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Played a second Leviathan Manifesto case, with some recurring characters from our previous one. This time, we failed to prevent a covert-gang-war shooting. I have this impulse to just keep playing this game to get a better feel of how to hack it.
        \n

        \n\n2097 \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nAugust 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \nCorsair Council 10. So sick of this game\u2026!
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nLisa Padol \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nAugust 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Urrr... so, Gen Con:

        How Much Powerade Can We Carry? (8 bottles between two of us, it turns out. This also turns out to be the correct amount for 4 people from Wednesday through Monday.)

        Vanagard, which is Fate of the Norns light and family friendly and playable in two hours or less. (Also more, but the two hour figure's the important one.)

        Blue Rose AGE, Intrigue in Tanglewood. (Fun, but some jarring in tone I'm still mulling over, as some of this also occurred in Shadows of Tanglewood, which I played at DexCon.)

        Pythos, RWBY, the one game Josh and I both played, even managing to get the PCs we'd hoped for. (He wanted Ruby, while I wanted Nora, which should surprise no one knowing both us and the show.) This was exactly what we expected, and the other two players were great -- we all knew what we'd signed up for.

        Clockwork: Dominion, Inheritance. Another one where we all knew what to do. An oddity in that there were three men and three women and we all played our actual gender. This was not mandated; it just happened. (I tend to play cross gender.) The GM noted that a) the game usually ends in either a big social combat or a big physical combat -- talking or shooting -- and b) this one was clearly going to end in both. And it did, and the twists and turns had us all on the edge of our seats.

        Call of Cthulhu, An Eldritch Thing Happened on the Way to the Forum. Exactly what it sounds like, and all of us were in exactly the right mood. I was Pseudolos! Hero had the best puppy dog eyes and idiotic innocence. He was one of the two survivors -- Pseudolos, Senex, and Hysterium all wound up dead. The other survivor, astonishingly, was Rufus Vestis.

        Games on Demand, A Taste for Murder, at speed, which meant some detail was lost, but we all had our best Awful on for the Cozy setting.

        Clockwork: Dominion, Power. A bit low energy starting out, for reasons, including all of us having the last two days of the convention catch up with us, but hey, I got to play a Science! guy who used robots and taser guns to fight.

        Castle Falkenstein, Babbage Engine. I've missed Castle Falkenstein! This was a blast.

        Dinner Amoeba, aka managing to get together with friends on the West Coast and their friends and eat dinner despite everyone's varied schedules.

        Dweomer by Gaslight, Goblin Market. Yep, I was very 19th century this convention. This started slow, with 2 players. Then three folks wandered in, unsure we could fit them all. We assured them that we had five spots and it was totally not a problem. At that point, we all slipped into groove. Extra takeaway: Do not schedule a one hour game immediately after another game that is in the J. W. Marriott if the one hour game is anywhere other than the J. W. Marriott. Totally worth missing the one hour one for the end of this one, mind, but something to keep in mind for the future.

        Let's Find a Different Game, aka Takeaway 2: Read your ^%(*& tickets, even if you know what they say. I'd come into Gen Con firmly convinced I had a 10 am game on Sunday. It was an 8 am game. I apologized and was assured that it was all right, then found myself a different game.

        Dreamchaser, aka I'm not the only one missing the obvious. This was a lovely 2 hour taste of the game, which was pretty much exactly what I wanted. It was intended to be a 4 hour session, but the other player, the one who'd remembered when his game was, had thought it was a 2 hour game, so had scheduled something for 2 hours after the start time.

        Last Licks in the Dealers' Hall. I was both appalled and relieved to realize that the ARU folks were here and I'd not known. This is why I managed to buy only one new ARU, as well as a unique charm bracelet and a small necklace (or pendant -- not sure which it technically is). And hearing the dealers cheer at 4pm is great.

        Post-Gen Con

        Watching the Eclipse. Well, partial eclipse. No eclipse goggles, so one quick peek through sunglasses while squinting, a glimpse on a turned off cell phone used as a mirror, and amazing sunlight crescents on the ground as the trees became a pinhole camera.

        Visiting People Who Were at the Same Gen Con by Trekking to the Other End of Queens. Yep, folks in from England -- and we were at the same table at the same time -- visiting a mutual friend in Queens which is how I got to meet them in person.

        Monsterhearts 1.5 (i.e., using sneak peek pack rules -- if we do a second season, we'll switch to full 2nd edition). Took us a bit to hit our stride, but we did, and I jotted down a few quotes:

        "How much worse can it get?"
        "Batler." (Batler is our Witch whose attempts to solve things with hexes... make it all so... interesting.)

        Gang member about the Werewolf: If she will just let us open the doors for her -- it's not chivalry! We just don't want her breaking down the doors."

        Queen: But if they're hiding her, you being big and obvious gives them time to move her somewhere else.
        Werewolf: But don't they have to go through a door?

        GM: Take your choice -- knife, pen, paper, whatever.
        Queen: Well the knife is convenient.

        So, the Queen and Witch became their Darkest Self, although the Queen stopped by giving part of her power to someone more... deserving... in... some sense of the word that will no doubt bite everyone in the ass next session. The Witch is still Darkest Self. The Werewolf was, frighteningly, the most reasonable person in the room. The (Unseelie) Fae has made a deal and made out with her Seelie counterpart. What could possibly go wrong?

        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n

        \n Sandra,

        You seem to have gone from "wow, this rocks!" to "I'm sick of this game" in the space of one session. What happened?
        \n

        \n\nRafu \n\n\n

        \n\nAugust 2017 \n

        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        Paul_T said:

        Sandra,

        \nI was wondering too.

      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nJason_Morningstar \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nAugust 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n More Monsterhearts, The Skeletons
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nBill_White \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nAugust 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n I ran a ton of Dungeon World at GenCon over the weekend for Games on Demand. It works great in a two-hour slot. I do it this way:

        (1) Hand out playbooks; help new people fill theirs out; tell them to skip bonds because "we'll do that in play."
        (2) Note the opening tableau ("When play starts, you'll be in the dark and tangled Weirwood struggling toward volcanic Mount Purgato, where a fabulous treasure awaits.")
        (3) Go around the table and have players introduce characters in the context of the opening tableau ("Show us what you're doing, or what you're saying.")
        (4) Each PC then addresses another PC in turn in a way that signals their bond with that character, who replies in a way that signals their bond. Simultaneously, as part of that interchange, the first PC answers one of the story questions I've written out. These are questions like, (a) "What treasure do you seek, and why?" (b) "Who is pursuing it as well, and why haven't you been able to defeat them yet?" (c) "What danger lies between you and the cave mouth that leads to the heart of Mount Purgato." Some groups get this more easily than others, but by the end, everyone has two bonds and I have the outlines of the adventure.

        I let them take XP for creating bonds and for answering story questions. At the end of each scene ("encounter"), I let them take XP for enacting bonds and role-playing alignment, and of course they take XP for failure. Whenever they take XP, instead of taking only 1 point, they gain 1d6 experience points, so leveling up happens pretty rapidly.

        I wind up with enough time to run two big scenes, one in the woods facing the danger and one in the heart of the volcano trying to get the treasure from whatever guards it or is after it.

        It produces some really fast, fun play.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n

      What did you play this week? (2017)

        \n
        \n
        \n\nJeff_Slater \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nAugust 2017 \n edited August 2017
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n We went old school and play-tested Mongrel Ultralight by @Mongrel_GM. It is a 100% traditional, Simulationist RPG\u2014Simulationist is usually a dirty word at Story Games SLC, haha (just kidding, kind of )\u2014but we always play and are interested in Mongrel's designs, who has created an interesting and well designed Story Game called Q&P: Schism. Mongrel's Story Game worked well even on the first playtest; its is already a good game, and I believe it has the potential to be a great game with time and effort. Unfortunately, Mongrel has lost interest in Narrativist games of late and put Q&P: Schism on the shelf :-( but I'm an advocate for it and would love for him to continue play-testing and working on it. The game has great promise.

        Anyway, playing two Simulationist, Binary GM RPGs in a row (i.e. games that strictly divide the roles of the GM and players traditionally) made me realize that I'm just not into them anymore. I just feel that the PCs are more reactive instead of creative and creativly engaged; there's just not as much collaborative creativity in these games. This had nothing to do with the quality of the designs or the GMs running the games; the issue is that the nature of these games simply isn't to my taste. I just don't find them as engaging and I don't feel like they involve the players as much. It's a lot of rolling dice just to see if you can do a task rather than actively creating a story together. I love the fact that in Collaborative GMless Story Games there are different perspective shaping the story. Often I find that having a number of people with the different ideas creates more interesting characters and more interesting story. That by having input from multiple people you get something greater than the sum of its parts. It is interesting to see how our tastes evolve over time. I actually am immersed in my characters less in GMed, Simulationist games then in Collaborative, GMless, Narrativist Games. I don't find that the Simulationist games focus on character depth, personality, and motives as much. I don't find that the stories are as much about the characters emotional drives and desires as much as they are about overcoming tasks. This evaluation is completely based on my tastes; I'm not saying how these games are, I'm saying how they are to me. Anyway, it has cemented that, for me at least, these games actually don't immerse me more in my character\u2014which is usually the reason those who like these type of games prefer them\u2014but actually immerse me less in my character and the story as a whole. It is very interesting how our perspectives and tastes change, because I used to get more immersed in my character playing Simulationist, GMed games and now it is exactly the opposite. It makes me very happy that we have so many options for different tastes and different gamers. I feel so indebted to the indie community, who took games like D&D that I loved as a child, and still like as an adult, and created new games that I am even more passionate about, which will sustain my hobby and keep my interest alive. Here's to the creative bounty; here's to diversity
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n

        \n\nchiarina \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nAugust 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Fate Core in a pulpy, funny Cthulhu setting. Our characters are loser amateur detectives in 90ies New Orleans, run away, try to get rid of dead they didn\xb4t kill, dabble in the understanding of sinister influences, they feel in themselves and first and foremost get one mishap after another.

        We players don\xb4t know each other very well, but nonetheless we log-roll surprisingly well. One of the best groups I was allowed to play in!
        \n

        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Had an interesting time with our CSIS (Canadian government secret agency) MIB-but-like-with-ghosts-instead game.

        Playtesting is weird, but the third session of this was really hoping, and had some cool dramatic moments as the story is coming together

        Incidentally, to those who responded to my thread about trying to find new directions, I feel like that advice is leading me to good places. So thanks again.

        \n\ndavey \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nAugust 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n First game of "follow" for me. Same game as mentioned above .
        Two people were experienced w this particular game. I've played in a baker's dozen or so various story game sessions over the past year and one player was an experienced gm playing her first "story game". I think we came together successfully. The "ReNu (tm) colony survived after landing on the wrong planet and moving in on the turf of another corporate colonization effort. We survived a plague transmitted by gnats that turned out to be avian spores of giant birds that reminded me of the buffalo of the American plains. Not sure how it happened but we seem to have evoked small pox and intentional buffalo extinction with a twist. I probably would have experienced it on a deeper level had I focused more on my characters needs and emotional connections... it was fun though.
        Cheers,
        Davey.
        \n

        \n
        \n
        \n\nJames_Mullen \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nAugust 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n I ran my Raising Damien setting for Primetime Adventures again (which originally came into existence as a result of this post here on the forums.)

        The anti-christ was being held at a facility in Colorado that presented itself as a PTSD treatment & research centre. This turned out to be very important later when Paul Ryan showed up and found out too much about the facility, falling under Damien's influence. Some magical shenanigans later and Ryan was an amnesiac who was in the best place to receive the care he needed: the downside was that President Trump promised to keep a close eye on the facility from now on and might even have some more 'patients' he wanted to send here.

        Interestingly, Damien himself got very few scenes and was more of a motivator for action than an independent character, which is just as well as it's strain playing a possibly-malevolent 8 year old for long whilst keeping his true nature ambiguous.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nColin \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nAugust 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Had a very good session of Monsterhearts last night. Our Ghoul woke up from being dead mid-autopsy, and our Dark Power individually put her organs back into her while they chatted about the costs our Ghoul would have to pay for returning this second time.

        Meanwhile, our Hercules/Sasquatch mourned her dead friend, but is receiving thanks from all over, and scholarship offerings, for "intervening and saving lives" while the Ghoul was on rampage. One life our Hercules couldn't save was that of her sometime-boyfriend's mother, who had the misfortune to be a first responder. The whole thing is being blamed on tainted fentanyl in the media. The Hercules is getting universal praise while feeling broken up about the whole thing.

        Elsewhere, our Queen-turned-Hollow was given an ultimatum by her cult: They may be a murderous cult, but they aren't that kind of murderous cult, like the Ghoul is; murdering people and eating them is gauche. Q-t-H chose to break up with her cult.

        Finally, our Medea, out on bail, led the charge to strip the Queen-turned-Hollow of his cult's power source, and broke into his house to loot the place.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n

      • \n

        \n\narmyofmeat \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nAugust 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n My group played a game of Follow for the first time. As per the suggestions, we chose a Heist and had a merry romp stealing an cruel and lecherous Duke's prized stud dog from his keep during a Carnivale-type festival. It was a fun twist to see the relatively-well-executed plan fail at the end through a betrayal of one of the gang valuing becoming a legendary thief more than actually finishing the job.
        \n

        armyofmeat said:

        It was a fun twist to see the relatively-well-executed plan fail at the end through a betrayal of one of the gang valuing becoming a legendary thief more than actually finishing the job.

        \nSweeeeet!

        Fantastic game of Mind of Margaret at Story Games Seattle. Teen angst over band practice, going to the right college, and asking your crush to the dance. So good.

        \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nSeptember 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n A short game of The King is Dead today. Overall quite a fun time - the game is surprisingly good at creating a narrative, and accomplishes a rare goal of a successful story game which requires very little player skill to play successfully. We had some point of confusion, though; I'll post about those elsewhere.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nRafu \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nSeptember 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Quite a lot last week...

        We played Follow combining the 2-player variant rules (as usual) with the epic quest rules (a brilliant, nice little addition). Barbara ended up keeping the same main character throughout the whole epic quest, while I switched: this turned out really nice, as there was this well-known touchstone/viewpoint character we both sympathized with and I loved to provoke, who was featured in about half the scenes and really grew complex and 3-dimensional over the 9 acts: "Connor" (aka Project 9817), human-mimicking AI in an actual human body and long-time "running man" living a rough life on the street.
        Unsurprisingly (what is it about the maths of this game, that looks 50/50 but then we have a history of just being successful once out of 3-4 quests? do we just have terrible luck?) our movement for the equality of all sentients in a classically cyberpunk near-future failed tragically... It started out as a successful rebellion of AIs and synths against the company that had created us, but as (through the heroic sacrifice of my first main character "Woodstock", a sentient mainframe) we had occupied the lab compound it turned into a siege, which failed when one of the sentient computers evaluated our odds as hopeless and chose to betray us "for our own good" opening the doors to the company troubleshooters (read: private army). Having got some media attention, we still went on to be an activist civil-rights movement of AIs, other non-human sentients and human allies, but my new main character ("the Hobbs anomaly", a sentient computer virus purporting to be the first naturally occurring sentient life-form native to the Internet) took such brash actions (from a human point of view) that it quickly turned into the villain of the piece, basically threatening humankind with worldwide terror as a publicity stunt. It ended with Connor voluntarily turning himself in to the company so that they could use his (contaminated) brain to research the Hobbs anomaly - which was close to the absolute worst possible ending for Connor - hoping to save the world from it. It was tense.

        We also tried out one of the Italian language Game Chef entries (La casa altrove by Francesco Zani) and we dragged two curious bystanders we'd never met before into a game of Ben Lehman's SKEW (always a great introductory RPG for oh-so-many reasons).
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nJason_Morningstar \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nSeptember 2017 \n edited September 2017
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Tabletop:
        The Warren

        Larps:
        Critical Path
        Sarabande
        Inheritance
        Winterhorn
        Muovikuppi
        Welcome Guests
        A Baby Fell From The Sky
