        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nColin \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nSeptember 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n I ran the fourth playtest sitting for a game I'm working on, about the relationships between members of a team.

        The session itself had good drama, but I think I've lost sight of my original primary goal (being that I never want anyone to have to break character mid-scene), while in persuit of neat mechanics. Having realized that, I'm working on course-correcting and cutting some neat-but-unnecessary mechanics.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nBen_Robbins \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nSeptember 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \nLovecraftesque at Story Games Seattle
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nRafu \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nSeptember 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        Colin said:

        (being that I never want anyone to have to break character mid-scene)

        \nSounds like larp to me!

        Wait... I realize the above might sound dismissive to some. What I meant was: there are a huge number of "chamber" (or small-scale) larp scenarios - including from the Jeepform and the American Freeform traditions, Golden Cobra, or in the upcoming book Crescendo Giocoso - which are organized in scenes but where, unlike most tabletop story-games, players are expected never to break character during a scene. I believe that to be a big deal, technically, and have come to believe it's the main design difference between larp and tabletop role-playing (physical acting or standing up versus sitting at a table being just a minor detail in comparison).
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nRafu \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nSeptember 2017 \n edited September 2017
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n I think I forgot mentioning playing Lovecraftesque, too, some time over the last 3 weeks. We played without cards out of necessity, but I keep finding I prefer this variant (though I only played with cards once, to be fair): it makes for a simple, even "classic" game, easy to teach. One ought to be able to commit all the actual rules to memory, or fashion a single business-card sized play aid and not need anything else.

        This week and last, we played through a third Leviathan Manifesto case and have started a fourth. This game by @James_Mullen is found here and was minimally discussed here. But I've introduced a hack of my own now, to make "personal scenes" a thing. We've considered moving our main characters to another game - probably Remember Tomorrow - to continue their story there, but we've started the fourth case because, so far, the hack is doing what we wish it would.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nWilhelm \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nSeptember 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Another session of Den Yttersta Domen.

        The PCs never were a party, but it became obvious in the last session with seven scenes and only in one of them did two PCs speak. But that scene involved my PC, and to me it was the best scene of the session, mostly thanks to the other player who did an amazing job.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nMongrel_GM \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nSeptember 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Fiasco, because in the Salt Lake group that's the go-to game, and some new folks came.

        6 people, and for a little while 7 at the table. Back to the Old House. Not many of us had a clue what the movie inspiration was, so we went with the words on the page as guidance. Spies, a wrongfully accused fugitive, OCD FBI, drugged and barely coherent teen, clues conveyed in dreams, podcasts of a crazy conspiracy theory (which turned out to be true?--energy vortex propagation by Russia, in this case in the house).

        The murder of the teen's parents wasn't tied in very well, not till late, and motive never expounded on at all because the bullets started flying.

        The end felt rushed and threads could have been woven together so much better. Anyone else have the problem of hurried and unfocused finishes to games? How best to create smart/complete integration by game end?

        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nRafu \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nSeptember 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        Mongrel_GM said:

        The end felt rushed and threads could have been woven together so much better. Anyone else have the problem of hurried and unfocused finishes to games? How best to create smart/complete integration by game end?

        \nYeah, that's a common problem around here as well. I'd say those one-shots where the ending isn't even a bit rushed and all loose ties come together in the end stand out as lucky, exceptionally successful examples. I've had a lot of such "paragon" games, but still they are a minority of all the games I've played.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nJames_Mullen \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nSeptember 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        Rafu said:



        This week and last, we played through a third Leviathan Manifesto case and have started a fourth. This game by @James_Mullen is found here and was minimally discussed here. But I've introduced a hack of my own now, to make "personal scenes" a thing. We've considered moving our main characters to another game - probably Remember Tomorrow - to continue their story there, but we've started the fourth case because, so far, the hack is doing what we wish it would.

        \nThanks Rafu: i'm very happy you've gotten some mileage out of this game. Also, Remember Tomorrow is an excellent choice to move the characters forward to. :-)

        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nColin \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nSeptember 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        Sounds like larp to me!

        Wait... I realize the above might sound dismissive to some. What I meant was: there are a huge number of "chamber" (or small-scale) larp scenarios - including from the Jeepform and the American Freeform traditions, Golden Cobra, or in the upcoming book Crescendo Giocoso - which are organized in scenes but where, unlike most tabletop story-games, players are expected never to break character during a scene. I believe that to be a big deal, technically, and have come to believe it's the main design difference between larp and tabletop role-playing (physical acting or standing up versus sitting at a table being just a minor detail in comparison).
        \n@Rafu , definitely no dismissive intent was taken by me. And I definitely see what you're saying.

        The distinction between the two is thinner and thinner for me, in a lot of ways, though I'd like more chances to LARP in those styles; the main forms around here are Vampire, which is not my particular jam.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nRafu \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nSeptember 2017 \n edited September 2017
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Fourth episode in our Leviathan Manifesto game (the second we've played using both of my hacks). Now we're definitely going to port the campaign to Remember Tomorrow, but not because of any dissatisfaction with @James_Mullen 's game... It's just that our main characters are in way over their heads and it makes no sense for them to be observing others and solving mysteries right now - they have to take extreme measures to preserve their clandestine surveillance operation and their lives!
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nJames_Mullen \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nSeptember 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        Rafu said:

        ...our main characters are in way over their heads and it makes no sense for them to be observing others and solving mysteries right now - they have to take extreme measures to preserve their clandestine surveillance operation and their lives!

        \nI love how this game has evolved: it's always my dream to see this kind of organic change coming from players and I'm quite flabbergasted that one of my games has initiated this! Thanks again: hearing about this is doing a little to help me through a very difficult time.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nchiarina \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nSeptember 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Ars Magica.

        Our characters approached a town, depopulated by an epidemic. They found some late victims, had to defend themselves against robbers, explored a nearly extincted covenant and allied themselves with one last Maga, that took refuge with some fighters in the caves under the building.

        Very traditional but entertaining game.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nRafu \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nSeptember 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Setup/chargen session for a new Sorcerer game. Space SF setting with horror/fantasy elements, optional rules from Sorcerer & Sword enabled. I'm going to GM, and the three of us have played Sorcerer together before (which is why we are now experimenting with alternate settings).
        The setting concept - mostly of my making - is far future with space travel, after humankind's diaspora among the stars. The twist is, SF clich\xe9s such as faster-than-light travel, beam weapons, teleporting, downloading and copying a human mind - anything which would be impossible according to 21st century science - do exist, as extraordinary one-of-a-kind occurrences, due to sorceries. Sorcerers in this universe are seen as scientific geniuses and elite technicians who make the impossible possible. Their existence is acknowledged, but there are few; interstellar travel and communication depend on them, but still they don't run things, probably because they're the weirdest of the weird.
        In our pre-game discussion we managed to arrive at a sensible, actionable understanding of Humanity in this setting ("sympathy for others + belonging as a member of our species") from the exceedingly navel-gazy philosophical starting point I had provided (something about understanding "humanity" as a collective noun, not a singular, solipsism in the loneliness of space and reality as a shared consensus).
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nJason_Morningstar \n\n\n

        \nMonsterhearts 1e, for once not me running. I got to play the Ghost. I was not happy about being dead

        \n\nchiarina \n\n\n

        \n\nSeptember 2017 \n

        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Night\xb4s Black Agents ("Stoker: First Blood"): The characters are members of a 1877 A.D. british expedition, get caught in the crossfire of the russo-turkish war and stumble in a cave with dreadful ghouls. Hard stuff.
        \n

        \n\nBen_Robbins \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nSeptember 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Continuing our "A-Team in Space" Uncharted Worlds game.

        In hindsight this scenario turned out to be "A Tale of Three Bombs." Bombs are built to explode, and our team is not one to stand in the way of destiny. 3-for-3 booms.
        \n

        \n\nJason_Morningstar \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nSeptember 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Just remember to set your Monsterhearts game 15 years in the past! In our case that meant my glum Witch could join the Marines and serve with the 7th Marines/7 RCT in Ar Rutbah during the occupation of Iraq, conveniently close to a place called Shab Al-Hiri, where he learned how to be a Wizard.
        \n
        \n
        \n

        \n
        \n\nRafu \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nSeptember 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Playtest of a friend's game, a lightweight cooperative story-game with a couple quirks and twist which has looooong been in the works. This time it was a SF scenario based (I can't tell how loosely) on the Eclipse Phase setting. We had a new player, too - somebody who'd never played a role-playing game before.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nDannyK \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nSeptember 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Gaming again for the first time in almost a year. Just made a Mage:the Awakening character, what a pain in the butt.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nLisa Padol \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nSeptember 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Monsterhearts 1.5 (i.e., using the Sneak Peek pack), finally hitting the fifth advance for a PC, which means next session will be the last, and we will totally play something else before deciding on whether to do a second season.

        The werewolf happily killed the nurse she'd put in a coma for murdering her wolf mother when the local demon explained that, really, folks were overthinking this whole thing about him needing a sacrifice, and it could be anyone, like that nurse.

        The witch let the demon deal with a small imp. I am not quite sure why, but the witch's player will balance his tendency to play cautiously by making sure his PC does really dumb things for reasons that... okay, I won't say they make sense, but it makes sense that he'd do those things. So, the demon has a string on him. And his parents were overjoyed when he agreed to go to church with them and with someone who might or might not be an angel and basically destroy a grimoire from the local demon worshippers.

        Trouble is, those demon worshippers are the fae's parents. Well, they adopted the fae. And they are so utterly understanding about their child explaining that they're going to marry another fae in a sort of political marriage. The father's even digging out the tuxedo for them. So, the fae is being accepting right back. Sure, their parents killed the biological child to get Really Good Crops, but hey, you know, that was years ago.

        So the fae was NOT pleased that the witch stole the family grimoire, especially as it had the family tree and various marginalia in it, and there was violence (possible angel guy cracked his head against the font when the fae hit him to retrieve the grimoire) and hexing (the fae's father was unable to drive off because of the witch's hex), and much recriminiation and such, eventually ending with an agreement that the fae and their family could have the grimoire, sealed, and not open it without the witch's permission. And the witch grudgingly told the demon that, well, he didn't like the demon, what the demon did or stood for, but... but... he liked the demon's style, you know?

        And the queen, who's basically a Dragon Princess from Seanan McGuire's Incryptid books is trying really hard to make sure everything works out, no one gets hurt -- especially here and hers (and she's had sex with all the PCs except the witch, and with the demon) -- and that the dragons make a profit.

        I think no one is currently in Darkest Self. Everyone except the fae's been there at least once, voluntarily.

        It's all a glorious mess, and I've no idea how things will end. It's really weird deciding the important things on the fly, and sometimes without thinking hard about whether they make perfect sense.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nRafu \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nSeptember 2017 \n
        \n

        \n First session (not counting last week's brainstorming/character creation one) in that Sci-Fi Sorcerer game. More about it here.

        \n
        \n Had the first real session of an online Exalted 3e game set in the 100 Kingdoms which I am running in a Shonen Burning Wheel fashion with a heavy emphasis on challenging intimacies and limit. More here.

        \n\nAsIf \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nSeptember 2017 \n edited September 2017
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n On Sep 17 I ran DayTrippers for my LegendsOfTabletop campaign, episode 3: "A Friend in Need", featuring the return of child actor now D-list celebrity Chip Parsons and the introduction of Reggie Carlisle (a drug-addicted ex-special forces dude - new character and new member in the group). There's a chain of torched vehicles as the PCs make their way through northern California, a return to Suzie's dream world in the Tiny Tyrant, and the terrifying return of the giant baby.
        http://www.legendsoftabletop.com/?p=2980

        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nchiarina \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nSeptember 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Fate Core For Idiots (our own stripped down version of Fate):
        We are playing in a pulpy, cthulhuid New Orleans. Our characters stumble from one catastrophe to the next. The secret service man with the big weapons is getting mad and ponders if all experiences are only illusions. The outdoor-survival guy is nearly dead. The rich shipowners son and starwars fan tries in vain to repair all the things we break and my jazzpianist-amateurdetective ate a black bug and is on the verge to become a sinister, godlike entity. Last session a Nazi U-boat fell from heaven and smashed into a villa we were infiltrating. All the Nazi paraphernalia we left for the police. What we took with us was a chest with old comics of 1944 - old comics that oddly enough told many things we experience now.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nJeff_Slater \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nSeptember 2017 \n edited September 2017
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n I had an amazing session of House of Spiders tonight; it's a multi-session, collabrative, GMless Story Game I'm designing. It's built for short campaigns and has a Game of Thrones vibe. I'm extremely pleased with how it is turning out and with how the new adjustments I made played tonight. I have such a great time playing with close friends, there's never any uncomfortableness, or worry about hurt feelings, and you can be very straightforward with one another. I had blast!
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nRafu \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nSeptember 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n I think I know how you feel. That's great!

        \n\nJason_Morningstar \n\n\n

        \n More Urban Shadows
        \n

        \n
        \n
        \n\nHasimir \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nSeptember 2017 \n edited September 2017
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Played Perseverant for the second time.
        Big disappointment ... for reasons unknown to me
        The first time, a few months ago, we played the beta version 0.9 ... this time the commercial version ... they seem relatively similar, but somehow this time the game did not click.
        Too vague procedures, explained in a redundant way that failed to clarify what to do, how, and when.

        These are the times I wish we would record our live table sessions, as if they were online, just to be able to go back and find out what we did differently :P
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n

      • \n

        \n
        \n
        \n (You could always use a voice recorder or mounted camera! Just get the permission of all the people involved first.)

        \n
        \n
        \n\nLisa Padol \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nSeptember 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Blood Coda for Dracula Dossier / Night's Black Agents. Our single actual secret agent knows zilch about vampires, but bonded with the rock and roll photographer who still wonders who turned Jimi Hendrix into a vampire. They're working with a history professor. The fourth member of the group, as the player decided to continue her tradition of playing badass actresses in Dracula Dossier, is Eartha Kitt.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nchiarina \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nSeptember 2017 \n edited September 2017
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Night\xb4s Black Agents: The Zalozhniye Quartet
        The agents searched for the hungarian journalist Agi Kozorus and saved her in Debrecen Zoo (Hungaria) from getting attacked by two aggressive tigers set free by the russian mafia clan "Lisky Bratva". Third opponent was a Zalozhniy, one of the powerful undead servants of the Lisky Bratva. After the action, the characters found out more about the activities of the Lisky Bratva. Next goal: Take photos in the clans nearby "transfer depot" of sex slaves, send the pictures to the government of Viktor Orban, claim that the responsibles are peoples smugglers and the victims are refugees.
        Well... we will see.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n

      • \n

        \n\nCaroline_Hobbs \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nOctober 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n I ran a very intense game of Downfall at Geek Girl Con. Our flaw: vanity. How it manifested: society ashamed of pregnancy and childbirth to the point where being your mother's biological child was abominable. It was, as I said, intense.
        \n
        \n
        \n

        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nCharlie_X \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nOctober 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n I ran a great game of Masks this week.

        It was part two of a story which had been delayed for ages. We managed to occupy the time between parts with Psi*Run, Noirlandia and Honey Heist, but it was good to get back to Masks.

        The gang were in Limbo, trapped in a nightmare VR machine by The Reformed's old mentor. The group engaged with way more mechanics than they had previously. I'd also written some Love Letters to the characters, presenting them with their darkest timelines.

        The Legacy, Tyr, fought a failed version of himself and used his Moment of Truth to realise he didn't need to be his father or any previous version of himself.

        The Reformed, Steel, managed to inflict enough conditions by calling the villain out on all his crap to cause the mecha/castle/giant version of the villain to crumble. Most of these weren't through combat, although Tyr knocking a tornado into it helped a bit.

        Tyr burnt influence to rescue the Newborn, Apollo. The poor metal boy was knocked through the Limbo portal and back to Halcyon, but he lost part of his body in the process. Apollo ran home, hugged his father and for the first time ever, cried.

        Tyr managed to come round to Apollo's with some beers and opened up about himself, hitting a Team Move.

        It was a pure joy to run and the group did a lot of work. I've been realising that as daft as I like my games, one of my big desires is to *feel* something. This session provided that and was fantastic for it.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n

        \n\nAdam_Dray \n\n\n

        \n\nOctober 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Ran two four-hour sessions of my "Henry Knox and the cannons of Ticonderoga" in spaaaaaaace scenario for Mongoose Traveller (also at TravellerCon).

        Played about 40 minutes of a four-hour session of MegaTraveller where the referee told everyone that, as long as we rolled high on 2d6 (implicit: even before adding stats), we'd probably succeed. In the first 40 minutes, I made two decisions, neither of which mattered much, and then quietly left. Most of the fun of the adventure (three of the players were laughing and having TONS of fun) seemed to focus on shared in-jokes between RL friends.
        \n

        \n\nkelmscott_press \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nOctober 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Using Follow to play a historical scenario about the 1215 siege of Rochester castle worked well. Admittedly, it didn\u2019t work out well for the characters, whose plan to summon aid from London by pressing untrained ravens into service as messenger pigeons somehow went awry.

        Ongoing Masks campaign is mostly good. The game seems to work best when a session is one continuous action scene.

        Played in a Fate urban fantasy one-shot. I think it worked better than when I\u2019ve run Fate in the past; part of the trick with running Fate may be saying \u201cno\u201d to skill and aspect uses that are a stretch.
        \n

        \n
        \n\nAviatrix \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nOctober 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \nMagister Lor as a pick-up game. The evil twin was a bored teenager, resentful of everything; the demon very legalistic and non-violent, but passionate about how her rights had been infringed. (Turns out while she was imprisoned it was the other demons who had gone really bad.)

        Fate Core, a noirish cyberpunk game. My detective was an exiled Brit of Nigerian ancestry. Apparently Brexit got really bad in the end, as noted by my frequent references to the Battle of Brighton.

        Monsterhearts, as the ghost. One of the advantages of playing at home is that when your in-his-darkest-self Ghost tries to communicate with the Mortal in the drama club room, you can jump up and play "Creep"on your piano.

        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\ndavey \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nOctober 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Something Something Firebrands. The somethings are because I can't remember what it was called. It's a vincent baker gmless game. Kinda different... lots of choosing from lists of events. I was skeptical at first, but it got going and I think we enjoyed eachothers ideas. Interesting design in which several scenes end up with players choosing a winner of the scene. Points are tallied and there is a winner at the end. We didn't bother with this... Not a game I will seek out again, but I did really enjoy creating a story with some good people. Plus I appreciated the novelty of the design.
        \n
        \n
        \n

        \n\nWilhelm \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nOctober 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n After a break we got back to our game of Den yttersta domen. My PC died the last time we played before the break (shoot in the back by a guard at a border crossing), being the apostle of a religious movement that death had great impact on most people in the area. No matter if they believed in Adilett's teachings they were affected by them.

        To continue playing I got to pick one of the GM's NPCs as my new PC. After some deliberation I took the Cardinal's wife.

        Another of the players plays the Cardinal's lover, which will lead to interesting conflicts I think.

        The other player started out as a smuggler, but with the death of my old PC he advanced to be the leader of the sect that my old PC had been preaching to. Thus he is also the enemy of the Cardinal.

        It was a short session, we only had the time for one scene per player.

        So for my scene we did a bit about the Cardinal coming home from a hard day at work. And my PC's thoughts and actions then.

        Good stuff.
        \n

        \n Microscope.
        Just one scene.
        Lots of world building.
        Wondering what the most exhaustively articulated game of microscope is???
        Since the game has the fractal kind of potential for infinite depth and exploration, I wouldn't be surprised if there weren't now or will someday come to exist vast epic worlds rivaling or surpassing Tolkiens and known only to the 4 or so players who created it! I love the idea of that at least. I mean for someone else to do it;).

        \n\nJason_Lutes \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nOctober 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Session 4 of our Blades in the Dark campaign. The players are cultists attempting to implement the will of their dark god Azarax by bringing the entirety of Doskvol to heel through the tenet "control through suffering." Last week they took over a sex cult, this week they burglarized the manor house of a retired professor of spectrology. I am loving the way the system spins out a web of narrative possibility, but have not quite gotten comfortable with the way resistance rolls work.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n

        \n\nJason_Morningstar \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nOctober 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \nWelcome Guests
        The Regulars
        Itinerants
        Here is My Power Button
        The Association for the Advancement of the Rights of Fairy Tale Creatures
        White Death
        Night Witches
        Winterhorn

        (Big Bad Con)
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nAdam_Dray \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nOctober 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n I played Fiasco "Suburbia" at our local bar meetup. There were three of us veterans and one person totally new to RPGs. We gently guided him through Fiasco setup and at the end of that, he voiced his concern that he wasn't at the right skill level for the game. He was getting a little confused by the four characters and their relationships, which I didn't think were very complicated.

        We started play and, first scene (not focused on him), asked him to play an "extra." He understood the concept, but immediately balked and asked to bow out of the game, as it was too hard for him, but asked to stay and watch. We agreed, but had to "reset" (brand new set of characters and stuff, still in Suburbia). He left about 3/4 through our game.

        Since it was Fiasco in a 6-hour game night, we played again after, pulling in a few other people. Five total. This time, it was "The Ice." All of us had played Fiasco before.

        Game play started out normal and great, and slowly the weird and supernatural dial started going up. We'd set up this promising non-science-related thing between my character and another. We were both oil entrepreneurs competing over a million-dollar drill bit in a boxcar. One other player was my competitor's assistant. The other two played spouses who were in Antarctica to protect a penguin preserve.

        Then it started getting really weird. There was a flashback to a deal made to secure drilling rights plus an unlimited supply of penguin blood. My character and one of the nature preserve people got locked in a boxcar full of bags of penguin blood and some kind of giant blood-drinking goose monster. I felt like it was really off the rails. We finished Act 1 and called it when a few of the others said they needed to go home, but a few seemed to stick around at the bar and talk after, so I think they just weren't enjoying the game.

        I'm not sure if the weirdness was a product of "I'm bored, so I'll inject weirdness because I don't care" or if the weirdness caused them to not care, or both. It was a bar, so alcohol might have contributed.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nJason_Morningstar \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nOctober 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n What a Fiasco, Adam!
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nBen_Robbins \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nOctober 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Played Downfall twice at Story Games Seattle, once Thursday and once Saturday. We get people new to gaming all the time but last week was a veritable flood of new-gamer goodness.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nLisa Padol \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nOctober 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Ran what was to have been the final Monsterhearts 1.5 session, but which, at 11pm, we agreed was Part One of the final Monsterhearts 1.5 session. Then, walked over the Queensborough Bridge and the rest of the way home, clutching Josh's hand as I got vertigo. Didn't stop walking, though.

        Josh is using two of the Growing Up moves, and we're all slowly figuring out how that changes things. His Queen, Viridian the Dragon Princess, told Margot, the raised-by-wolves-not-literal-wolf Werewolf that she was not a wolf, and the player was trying to figure out how to justify taking the experience point she wanted while staying true to the character. I pointed out how she could have Margot accept this in a way that would make things Oh So Much Worse (hey, you know how you murdered the school nurse who'd killed your wolf mother? You couldn't have done this as only a wolf. You know how you're protecting your pack by holding grudges, like Viridian said, because they can't do that?), and she's chewing on that, happy with the suggesting, and playing a Melting Down Margonoke who handed in an essay where she wrote "Wolf" for half the words and attempted to analyze the story in the other half.

        Me: Anyone have any idea what you're reading in English Class?

        Witch's Player: The Most Dangerous Game.

        (Brief pause as we explain what it's about to those who didn't know.)

        Werewolf's Player: ... More than half the words will be "wolf", then, because there are places where "wolf" makes sense.

        Oh, and the Werewolf has no guile or subtlety and totally copped to having killed the nurse, first to the other PCs who a) were not surprised and b) were not about to turn her in, and then to her adoptive parents, who, I think, want to institutionalize her at this point -- she hauled off and hit the mother when the mother echoed the Queen's words unaware, saying, "Honey, you are not a wolf", and then hit the father when he tried to intervene, and later, beat up a whole bunch of students who were persecuting the Witch because his parents decided to have a town meeting and tell people about the demon, which went about as well as the Witch predicted. He's planning to banish the demon one way or another, and if he needs a human sacrifice for that, well, he reckons he qualifies. I've thought of a couple of things I might or might not do to complicate that -- and might or might not do if he uses another tactic.

        The Fae is planning their wedding to their opposite number, has accepted a favor from the demon, and is probably going to break up with their girlfriend who got magically drugged into being forgiving (because the Fae was annoyed the girlfriend was holding grudges about seeing the Fae kissing her adoptive sister) and I have been doing everything I can to make being forgiving go horribly wrong. Currently, she's been told enough and seen enough that she is convinced the wedding is not what the Fae wants (which is what the Fae told her) and that the Fae is likely to be killed and that she needs to take action to protect the Fae.

        And somewhere in there, a rescue mission that folks were theoretically planning for a couple of sessions finally happened, almost an afterthought. Almost -- it plus the Fae's wedding are intended to solve a problem, and may well do so, as there are plenty of other problems.

        So, ideally, I'd like to end with things resolved or things gloriously horribly unresolved. And I have no idea what will happen, and apart from that one idea vis the Witch, haven't done any prepwork, and the only prepwork I will do will be jotting down any other ideas that pop into my head so I don't forget them.

        I've run one game where I couldn't prep before -- Dreamhounds of Paris, playtesting it -- and it went astonishingly well. This one -- well, I don't think it sucks. The players are enjoying it. It's going better, I think, than when I ran Sorcerer, I think in 2005, as I know a whole lot more. I'm enjoying not being able to prep much, having no idea where things will go even more than usual. I do think I could use sharper skills at keeping things from dragging, at making sure folks get into scenes and get to do cool stuff, at giving the consequences a bit more bite. And I know that some of what's in the game falls into Stuff I Do A Lot, because when I reach for something to start the stone soup or to add to it, I reach for what I know.

        But, it's working. There may be a catch in the engine here and there; the tank may run dry on occasion. But, all of the parts work, and I'm getting a feel for how they shape a whole.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nkelmscott_press \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nOctober 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Finished the Masks campaign. I still have mixed feelings about Masks, but the last couple of sessions worked very nicely.

        My Life With Master: We were the minions of a steampunk mill owner, who wanted to turn his workforce into clockwork automata controlled by human brains in jars. The scenes were a lot of fun, though the resolution mechanic seems unnecessarily fiddly.

        Downfall: You know your anarcho-capitalist arcology is collapsing when your hero's daughter has changed jobs from "downsizing consultant" to "space marine" and is gunning down dissidents with a turbo-laser. I\u2019m a confirmed Downfall fan now.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nMike_Sands \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nOctober 2017 \n edited October 2017
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n I ran a playtest of Devil & the Deep, my naval adventure game. We had a lot of fun with two brothers on the ship - the older, a rather happy go lucky midshipman who had repeatedly failed his lieutenant's examination and the younger, a dedicated lieutenant and now instructed by their father to keep an eye on the elder...
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nThe_Bearded_Belgian \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nOctober 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n This week I played some RISUS with some ten year old kids. It was hilarious. I posted a writeup in the actual play category.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nMongrel_GM \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nOctober 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Mouseguard after creating characters 2 weeks ago.

        I see the strength of instincts & beliefs (if you want the approach of predefined personality) but I'm not seeing it as revolutionary.

        I'm thinking I just have an aversion to dice pool mechanics, especially when the "team roll" is so obviously the way to succeed.

        GM is new to the system and getting a feel for it.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nCaesar Slaad \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nOctober 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n It was theoretically a "trifecta week" where I run Th-Fr-Sat.

        Thursday, I'm alternating Starfinder with Night's Black Agents. It was a SF night. I was feeling a little under the weather, and people were missing, so I called it a night after helping the players update their characters (not many players have the books.)

        Friday was Mutants & Masterminds day with a small group. I wanted to run something horror-themed since Halloween is night. I ran the Cthulhu-esque adventure "Sleeping Gods Lie" from Lucien Soulban's excellent Supernatural Handbook. When the players saw signs of Deep Ones, they asked "does Lovecraft exist in this world?" I quickly decided he did, but his tales were more folklore than fiction.

        Saturday was my Pathfinder Scarred Lands game. It was a fighty game, but I try to put in one roleplaying encounter per session, so I had them stumble on a kobold slave who they had freed when they took out some serpentfolk guards. This led to the questions "are kobolds evil in this game?" (Again, that meta-knowledge discussion, albeit with a different group.) I turned with question back to a setting-based one. The characters know that kobolds who dwell in catacombs under cities have a reputation of being vicious ambushers, but this kobold seemed pretty harmless and decidedly Dobby-like.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nAsIf \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nOctober 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n My DayTrippers campaign with Legends of Tabletop continued with Episode 4: "Into the Red". Our heroes' investigation of a conspiracy to steal dreams is interrupted by the accidental drug addiction of a TV star and an emergency mission to rescue a fellow DayTripper with less than 6 hours left in her return window...
        http://daytrippersrpg.com/forums/actual-plays/legends-tabletop-ap-4-red

        \n
        \n
        \n

        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nchiarina \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nOctober 2017 \n edited October 2017
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Fate Core, Crazy New Orleans Losers in Pulp Cthulhu World.
        My (male) amateur detective once ate a beetle... a dark sinister looking scarabaeus. It grew in his body and we found out, that this made him to be the Chosen, the one that would be sacrificed at the next solar eclipse by dark cultists to summon the utterly Evil from another plane... Well... the next solar eclipse will be in two days. Last session, in the middle of the night we forced a gynaecologist at the point of the pistol to execute an emergency C-Section. She had to slit open the belly of my detective and to remove the beetle. After the intervention the poor woman was a mental wreck. After all, my detective survived.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n

      • \n

        Shadowmoor (boffer larp!)

        \n
        \n
        \n\nThe_Bearded_Belgian \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nOctober 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n I just played another round of the little game I designed for my classroom lessons about teamwork, where the 7 year olds play carebears that have to solve a problem. This time, Norbert the Beaver was stuck on the roof of the tower he built on his dam and he didn't dare to get back down. Also, his ladder fell into the water below. Went well. Need to refine a little bit about the little system, but I was satisfied, and I could do silly voices and act out NPC's, which was rewarded by giggles.

        So the verdict is 4,5/5 rainbows and a shower of sparkles.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n

        \n\nBen_Robbins \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nOctober 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Great game of Microscope Union at Story Games Seattle. Lots of really good family drama.

        Over the weekend did a playtest of someone else's game. Our setting was "I owe my soul to the company store" but on Venus. It's still unannounced, so I'll say no more.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n

        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nJames_Mullen \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nOctober 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n We played Kingdom at the MKRPG, set in a late nineteenth century village not unlike Bournville: the factory owner built a working village to house his staff and their families but also to provide for their educational, social and spiritual needs.

        Moral issues came to the fore throughout and our crossroads, "Will the village appoint it's own police force?" came to pass, with workers enforcing the law and meting out stringent punishments for even small transgressions.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n

        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n After a long, summer lull, got back into my once or twice a week D&D 5e dungeon crawl set in Mirrorrim: The City of Brass. Always looking for one or two more players for two-hour weeknight sessions, no commitment necessary (drop in, drop out). Hit me up if you're on Facebook.
        \n

      What did you play this week? (2017)

        \n
        \n
        \n\nScottM \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nOctober 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Ran Tomb of Annihilation at the game store on Monday (now 5 weeks in, good jungle adventure, they'll hit Firefinger next week). Tuesday we continued Skull and Shackles; it's a bit of a drag (low level and Pathfinder, but good friends). Wednesday was a great game of Dread! (Hiking the Grand Canyon, guide attacked. Very cool.)
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nCaesar Slaad \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nOctober 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n I wrapped up my Dracula Dossier campaign for Night's Black Agents this week. There is so much more I could have done with the book, but circumstances and workload meant it was time to bring it to a tidy end.

        My players aren't near to espionage/thriller fans that I am, so I think things went fairly well considering. As mentioned in an earlier post, I ran the Dracula's Mill captstone with things given an alien bent. I ran some of the flavor bits the DD facebook group helped me with here, and it worked beautifully.

        I also dreamed up a nice classic espionage feel cut-scene for a character that was gone last time. MORGAN was getting some special meteoric iron ammo from a contact that Hound had compromised. Instead of taking MORGAN down, Hound warned MORGAN about HENLEY, the PC that CD had compromised (who I swapped in for the pilot of the helo above the falls).

        My favorite bit was after they took CD down, one agent (ALI) plugged into the 4-dimensional alien computer and was staying behind to redirect the telluric currents to give the other agents a better chance of escaping. But there was some worry that if he stayed plugged into it, he would become the next vampire lord. BERNARD, the ex-SAS character, was worried about this, so his player used In the Nick of Time to plant a mini-charge on ALI. I told him he needed to make a filch test. He didn't have filch, so he recruited CHAKROUN for the task.

        CHAKROUN's player noted the trust on the sheet and decided she trusts ALI more than BERNARD, and sabotaged the filch test.

        So that's where it ended, with a little classical ambiguity and double-dealing in the ending.

        I hoped to get deeper into the book. But I figure that DD is one of those campaigns like Masks of Nyarlothotep that you can visit again and again.

        The bit with CHAKROUN and ALI served to emphasize that I find some sort of character personality mechanic baked into the game to be helpful. There are some I don't like, and some players tell me that they don't need the system to tell them how to role-play. But many player benefit in having just a little push to improve the role-playing experience.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nMike_Sands \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nOctober 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n A great minicon yesterday ConFusion in Wellington, NZ (returning after being defunct for a few years).

        I ran playtests of my games-in-development Heavy Metal \xc6ons and Devil & the Deep which both went well, in the sense of "people had fun" and "lots of good material for improving them" and then finished off with a great game of Fall of Magic (which continues to provide novelty even though it seems like the story should always follow similar paths).
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nChumofChance \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nOctober 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n I've been running a solo Eclipse Phase campaign for my wife for a few months now, and she runs a 5e Eberron solo game for me. It's a lot of fun, and is really inspiring me to begin my current project of designing a two-player narrative-based game system and setting.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n

        Endgame, from Larps From the Factory

        \n\nHasimir \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nOctober 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Started last week a new campaign of FateLess.
        It's meant to be just a short 3 sessions demo, but the material we came up with shows a lot of promise
        The setting is Spain in the Pirate era with just a sprinkle of supernatural Ghosts and a bunch of high level Secret Societies thrown in for good measure.
        It's shaping up fantastically like.
        \n

        \n
        \n\nBen_Robbins \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nNovember 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n I'm a week behind, but: continued Uncharted Worlds, our first session switching GMs. The new GM did a clever thing where the entire game was actually about us investigating the backstory of his character, who was under arrest and mostly not present. I was skeptical because of old school "GM NPC" prejudice but it turned out very cool.

        And played another fantastic game of Microscope Union at Story Games Seattle. Even hotter than the last one. Family relationships are just molten gold.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nThe_Bearded_Belgian \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nNovember 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Started up a How to Host your Dungeon game yesterday and went through the Primordial Age, carried out the Age of Civilization where I opted for two civs and rolled Dwarf and "Make up your own", so I ended up with some sort of Dragonblooded race. In playing it turned out to be a difference between the two that the dwarves were mainly interested in mechanics and practical stuff, while the dragonblooded were more of a philosophical and magic using race. Also, they partly builded on the surface and made a mountain range happen. Anyway, the dwarves dug to deep and I got to do the Great disaster, and set up the factions of the age of monsters. Depending on the story developing I might share coming stories here in an AP. As well as the maps.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nUrsus_Spelaeus \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nNovember 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n I played House of Reeds the other day.
        We put together a family of British clock-makers/missionaries/opium-dealers living in Southern China some time in the 17th century.
        I had watched Suspiria, and Valerie and her Week of Wonders recently, so I was coming into it with those, plus Hammer horror and Alice in Wonderland, and well as my experiences as an English teacher in China, as influences.
        We played via Discord. One of the other players is an old friend of mine living in Taiwan. He was coming into the game with more Call of Cthulhu influence. The guy who suggested the game lives in America right now (somewhere in the midwest, I think?) I'm not sure what his influences were.

        It was fun, but I do have criticisms of the game. We couldn't maintain consistent characterization, and the whole narrative drifted into incoherence. Too many chefs, I guess.

        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nLisa Padol \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nNovember 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Just got back from Metatopia, where I played:

        Person on a Panel
        Person in a Focus Group
        El Jefe in Pasion de las Pasiones (Note to self: I need to figure out how to do a FAST ramp up playing nasty PCs)
        A snooty nobleman troubleshooter in Gumthews who decided to outargue a demon
        A tinker / explosives expert in Chromeshoe
        A vigilante by night and river dredger by day in Barely Legal Transgender Certified Public Accountants
        Person on a Panel
        A divorced stagehand, mother, and witch in Atomic Witch
        The Princess of Bacon in The Excellents (A nutritious breakfast is Important!)
        The muscle in Awesome 8s ("I checked my hammer -- it's a wedding!")
        The Patient in Project Wingspan (where the author's doing a good job of cutting away everything that isn't the game, handed half of us player rules and the other half gming rules)
        A combination of two PCs, echoes in the PCs' heads, and a GM in Lovecraft Rules
        Part of the GM Chorus in Immortal Beloved
        Person in a Focus Group
        Person on a Panel

        And we went to see Thor: Ragnarok, so Person in a Very Comfy Movie Seat.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n

        \n\nJason_Morningstar \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nNovember 2017 \n edited November 2017
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Metatopia so:
        The Itinerants (GM)
        Welcome Guests (25 year old man child and cannibal)
        Guest Suite (Guest Services friend of Glenn)
        Battenburgh (Feral youngest child)
        Retrievers (Remorseful ex-assassin)
        Red Carnations on a Black Grave (Jean, butcher's assistant and decent communard)
        Disaster Reporting in Absurdistan (Danish fixer)
        Homunculus (The Golden Cobra winner) (The friend from work)

        I was also part of four panels
        \n

        \n
        \n

        \n
        \n\nDavid_Berg \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nNovember 2017 \n edited November 2017
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Metatopia!
        Degrees of Difficulty (hammer-wielding kid -- combat system test)
        Imperiums (D&D5 campaign guide rules analysis -- neat animist magic system)
        Shadow Strike card game (cute ninja quick-play last-standing)
        Love Each Other (a sexual mystic -- queer love vs post-apocalyptic fear)
        The City (Maxwell Pierce, the expediter -- retired spies hunting leads to a crime)
        Timepeekers (Ilio, the problem kid -- kids peeking into their futures for skills)
        This wasn't any sort of plan, these were just the games that needed playtesters when I showed up.
        I also went to Joshua Newman's panel on Shock and an excellent panel on Instructional Design.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nJames_Mullen \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nNovember 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \nCthulhu Dark: set among the workers at a Devon stone quarry in the 1830s, a cave-in lead to the discovery of some new type of stone deep in the Earth. The PCs, and others, suffer a series of horrifying visions and go down the mine to find the true source of the stone... none of them returned the same.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nHopeless_Wanderer \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nNovember 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Played a short session of my Shenmo Danger Patrol playset with some students.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n

        \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nNovember 2017 \n edited November 2017
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Started a two-session game of Dog Eat Dog last night. It's my first time playing/facilitating, so we're feeling our way through the game and trying out some of the dynamics in play. A remarkable game!
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nHopeless_Wanderer \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nNovember 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Also played Amateurs at Work (a 200 Word Challenge RPG) and started another 200 word story game called the The Voyage of the Pursuivant Challenger.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nHopeless_Wanderer \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nNovember 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Many of the 200 word RPGs work great as forum games, which is how we're playing.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nJeff_Slater \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nNovember 2017 \n edited November 2017
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n We played Dog Eat Dog last night. I\u2019m very impressed with the game\u2019s design. I think it will take the place of one of my top 3 favorite GMless, Collaborative Story Games. I highly recommend it; it is one of those less known gems that is up there with the best designs in the collaborative, GMless space.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nNovember 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n I agree, Jeff. I'm very impressed by how much (constructive) pressure it puts on the players with so few moving parts. (I'm often frustrated by how loosey-goosey some GMless games get in practice, but that's not the case here. Although, somewhat notably, Dog Eat Dog isn't really entirely GMless, I would argue.)

        I think it's a little early to judge the game, having only barely started to play, but I share your enthusiasm and look forward to our next session!
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nJason_Morningstar \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nNovember 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Dog Eat Dog is one of my favorite games. I think it is genius.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nLisa Padol \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nNovember 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Wrapped the season of Monsterhearts 1.5, and it was pointed out that this is precisely a year after we started -- first and last sessions were both held the day after Election Day in the US. General consensus is that it was fun, though I regret not knowing the Witch was one xp away from an advance as I had an obvious opportunity to offer xp. When I asked how to do better next time, the two things that came up were:

        1. Run with the full 2.0 rules. I'm fine with this -- they weren't available to me until close to the end of the season.
        2. We started off with rotating duties for doing a Last Time on... write up, but that slipped towards the end. We should figure out before we start playing who'd doing the write up for that session.

        For a break, Delta Green's Observer Effect and probably finishing up the game we started of Fall of Magic the time one player couldn't make it at the last minute.

        Wrapped Blood Coda for Dracula Dossier. Folks said yes, they do want to do the 1977 lg, and as NBA, not as Fiasco. (Aviatrix would've made up the Fiasco set if we'd gone that route, I think.) This means I need to do a f*ckton of reading and make sure to see Tinker Tailor, preferably with the whole group, just like I was forced, forced, I say, to rewatch The Third Man twice before running The Carmilla Sanction.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n

        \n
        \n A couple of sessions of the newly Kickstarted Untold: Adventures Await, which is kind of a short, light story-game disguised as a boardgame, played using "Rory's Story Cubes" symbol-dice as inspiration. It's fun and occupies a distinctive niche!

        \n
        \n\nchiarina \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nNovember 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Thursday we nearly ended "Stoker: First Blood" for Night\xb4s Black Agents.

        Today my most exciting group ended our Fate Campaign and decided to start a Hillfolk Campaign. I\xb4m very curious about this. We want to play the Series Pitch "Colony Wars" by Emily Care Boss.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nNovember 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n D&D5E for the first time (and I never even played 4th, so it's been many years for me since I played any "modern" D&D at all!).

        Played with a totally trad group of gamers - another thing I haven't done in a while. The whole "master gm" vibe, a detailed setting and deep backstories, "no metagaming!", drawn out fights and investigation scenes, intense epic "story" style combined with long hours of nothing actually happening...

        It's really like D&D is supposed to be, you know? Dramatic narrations from the GM, a deep mystery that will take months or years to unravel..

        They love the Traits/Bonds/Ideals because of the detail they add to the characters but they never reference them in play and do not award Inspiration for them.

        A totally fascinating experience for me, full of all the good things and all the bad things I remember from playing d&d. Quite a trip down memory lane, in a lot of respects.

        One thing that really struck me was the sheer amount of time spent looking up rules for things. Normally I like to really stay "in the moment" and connect to the people I'm playing with, but here I had to have my head in the Player's Handbook almost constantly to look up spell descriptions, feats, which actions give advantage, whether a certain ability counts against undead, etc.

        The entire combat sequence was maybe 1/2 or 1/3 playing out events and rolling dice and 1/2 or 2/3 flipping through books and looking stuff up.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nkelmscott_press \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nNovember 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \nMagister Lor: this is one of John Harper's Lady Blackbird variants, which perhaps got overshadowed by the subsequent Kickstarter for Blades in the Dark. It has some potential pitfalls: it's *very* PvP, and a lot of important details about the setup are ambiguous. However, we were largely able to steer around these hazards, and had a lot of fun; the Jedi-apprentice-falling-to-the-dark-side premise is engaging, and as ever with Harper, there's a ton of evocative details.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nDreamer \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nNovember 2017 \n edited December 2017
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Started up prep for a solo game of Remember Tomorrow, using a concordance generator to handle as much of the GM part as possible:

        http://solorpggamer.blogspot.com/search/label/Remember Tomorrow

        This is going to be a similar process to the one I used for my previous Our Last Best Hope game, but instead of using some asteroid disaster movie scripts, I've seeded the concordance generator with William Gibson's Neuromancer.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nNovember 2017 \n edited November 2017
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n I've been very curious about Remember Tomorrow for some time. I'll check it out!

        How do your word prompts work - are they randomly drawn from the text of a novel? (Neuromancer, in this case, I believe.) How do you choose the seeds to use?
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nNovember 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n We're continuing what's now looking like a three-session run of Dog Eat Dog. A fascinating game which presents so many interesting pressures on us despite very simple rules; intensely clever.

        One of our characters ended the session with no tokens - a defeated warrior, broken down after being beaten and jailed. His spirit, as much as his body, is wrecked. We will see how he chooses to end his story - likely with fire and fury!

        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nDreamer \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nNovember 2017 \n edited November 2017
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        Paul_T said:

        I've been very curious about Remember Tomorrow for some time. I'll check it out!

        How do your word prompts work - are they randomly drawn from the text of a novel? (Neuromancer, in this case, I believe.) How do you choose the seeds to use?

        \nNot quite randomly, though I do randomize the order of the results. The tool is very similar to a concordance generator ( a glorified text search that takes a keyword and returns all its occurrences in a text along with their context-- i.e., a number of words around them).

        My implementation will do a search on anything starting with those characters, so the keyword "bar", for example, returns these results (for the text fragment that I'm searching in):



        From those results, I look for anything that seems to fit the established fiction well enough (even if it takes a bit of squinting). Sometimes it only takes one phrase to suggest a good GM response. Sometimes I collect various phrases that I feel have potential (I may move them around like a jigsaw puzzle), and then I look at their gestalt to extract a meaningful GM response from them.

        I'm still evolving a method around getting hits from the tool, but the ideal is for me to intervene as little as possible. I try to look for things on the character sheet (or the game text itself) that can be used as a keyword, and hopefully that keyword returns phrases that suggest what the imaginary GM might do. If I exhaust everything in the character sheet (or game text) without any good hits from the tool, I will then brainstorm keywords myself and see if I can get any useful hits that way.

        This hasn't happened yet, but if get absolutely nothing useful from the tool and I can't come up with any keywords, I'll have to fall back on other oracular tools to formulate a GM response (and then try the whole process again when I need another GM response).



        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nNovember 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Great answer, thank you! Seems like a very good oracular technique.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n

        \n\nBen_Robbins \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nNovember 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \nQuiet Year and Microscope at Story Games Seattle.

        The Microscope game turned into a fantastic exploration of humanity, alienness and communication. That awkward moment when your long-separated fellow humans think your alien partner is a pet:



        "Is it\u2026 sentient?"
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n

        \n
        \n\nmadunkieg \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nNovember 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n The End of the World - Zombie Apocalypse.

        It was fun enough for a one-shot, but not exactly groundbreaking in any way. I've played similar games (play yourself at the end of the world) before, but it's been a couple of decades. Hopefully it'll be another two decades before I'm tempted to try this sort of game again.

        I've played better. Heck, I've designed better.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n

        \n
        \n
        \n\nDavid_Berg \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nNovember 2017 \n edited November 2017
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n My supervillain game Within My Clutches!

        Lady Lovely Locks fixed up her centuries-old stalker with a new love interest -- on live TV! Peer pressure kept the new couple together, allowing Ms. Locks to achieve her master plan of dethroning Oprah.

        Magnificent Maggie survived an accidental hail of diamonds to get a date with supernoob Golden Dynamo, where she touched his heart by helping him hone his telekinesis.

        Frank the Furnace screwed with famous hero Shockwave's head to the point where the line between hero and villain was blurred, creating an opening for Frank to claim the same position (instead of being reviled as an ex-hero turned villain). In the meantime, he went broke buying off the informant who could incriminate him, but spent his time on the streets honing his thermal powers to eventually heat the entire earth by a few degrees. Frank never could stand being cold.

        Doctor Mad Maxine successfully got herself out of the supervillain weapons supplier game by alternately feigning incompetence, collaborating with a global intelligence agency, and pissing off badass villain Iron Tyrant. Now she makes really weird toys.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nNovember 2017 \n

        \n
        \n
        \n Within My Clutches! Yeay!
        \n
        \n

        \n\nGragoon \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nNovember 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Played Fiasco with 3 players this week using the London 1593 playset. This was my 3rd time playing Fiasco (1st time with only 3 players). Everytime I play Fiasco, I have a great time at the beginning, when we are setting up the relationships and fleshing out the characters. Maybe we did something wrong, but playing with 3 players I felt like our 3 characters had a similar goal so they were all working nicely together which ended up giving the game a feel closer to Follow than my previous experiences with Fiasco.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n

        \n
        \n\nAdam_Dray \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nNovember 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n I ran Misspent Youth last night at our local "Drinking & Dragons" get-together. I pitched Bill White's Rage & Resentment playset (basically Jane Austen), but only got two interested players while the Blades in the Dark table had six.

        I couldn't run that scenario with just two, so we switched to straight SF and made up an Authority based on religion and fear and forced virtualization of people in an arcology. A third player joined us a little late and we worked him in. Had a blast!
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nWilhelm \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nNovember 2017 \n edited November 2017
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n We played Den Yttersta Domen again. My first PC was martyred four sessions ago, and I picked up the Cardinal's wife NPC as my new PC.

        The martyrdom spurred a religious separative movement, breaking the congregation in two, the separatists seeing my old PC as a saint, or maybe even a prophet.

        Zir teachings not compatible with the main line the growth of the culture causing increased tensions in the community. Also Mercurian mercenaries showed up, joining the separatists, seemingly for their own, political, reasons. Escalating the situation further.

        After a conflict between my PC and her daughter, the daughter ran away and joined the separatists. At the same time the main line decides to finally deal with the separatists, with force.

        Civil war around the corner my PC sneaks into the separatist camp to get her daughter out before the bullets start flying.

        I am successful, but on the way out we encounter the separatist leader (also a PC).

        Things get tense, but he decides that having the Cardinal's wife as an ally on the outside is more valuable than keeping her as a hostage with her daughter.

        As we reach the camp of the Cardinal's army he greets us, surprised to see us coming with the refugees from the separatists. But at the same time overjoyed as he realised the danger were in.

        In the closing moments of the session a separatist sniper fired across the lines, injuring the cardinal. War is coming.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nJeff_Slater \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nNovember 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Some of us from the Story Game Forums played our second session of Dog Eat Dog online. I really like the group; the players are very creative and the sessions are interesting and engaging. I\u2019m very impressed with Dog Eat Dog. It is designed very well and very elegantly. I highly recommend it to those who enjoy collaborative Story Games and have yet to play it. Story Games SLC started our first session of an Apocalypse World 2e game. We have a really great MC running it. We have opened things up a bit to include pretty much any type of indie RPG at SG SLC. Playing with all the indie RPG forms and design-spaces keeps things fresh, and helps to hit all the different tastes and preferences people bring to the table. Tonight I ran an old fashioned dungeon crawl, with some old friends, using The Black Hack. it does a fair job of imitating oldschool D&D. I got some old friends into Story Gaming about six months ago and they have really taken to it. They wanted to try something more traditional so we\u2019re giving TBH a shot. I like my RPGs a little more interactive and collaborative so I think as the campaign goes on I will open things up and bring in some Story Game tricks. I haven\u2019t GMed much, so I\u2019m looking forward to the practice and the challenge.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n

        Fantastic! (And I'm one of the people in the Dog Eat Dog game. Looking forward to wrapping it up this week!)

        Let's chat about GMing sometime, Jeff. Have you tried applying the advice I sent to you about playing The Bureau? (No need to have that conversation in this thread, though.)
