        \n\nAsIf \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nNovember 2017 \n edited December 2017
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \nDayTrippers/Legends of Tabletop AP 5 - "The Rat Pack"
        While exploring the red planet of Arret to rescue fellow DayTripper Joan Marlowe, Chip is seized by Ratmen and dragged before their king. Now Nash and Reggie are tasked with a double rescue, and facing off against two hundred snarling, squabbling Ratmen in The Cave of Blue Flames. Reggie experiments with the Lucid Dreaming skill to tip the odds in their favor.
        http://daytrippersrpg.com/forums/actual-plays/legends-tabletop-ap-5-rat-pack
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nNovember 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n This week it's D&D and Dog Eat Dog.

        An unfortunate moment in the D&D game made me really uncomfortable:

        There's a young teenager at the game, ostensibly learning to play.

        We are having a tense encounter with a Shadow Dragon, which could go sour at any moment. (This Dragon nearly killed one of us before, but we're trying to talk it out of attacking us again.)

        The kid asks, "Is that a young dragon or a mature dragon?"

        The DM replies, "What does your character know about dragons?" (I.e. "Shut up")

        A few moments later, the DM sets up a battlemat and brings out a dragon miniature. It's not all that large a miniature, so the kid says, "Ha! That's definitely a young dragon, looks like!"

        The DM grows angry and says, "That's it! Just because you can't leave well enough alone, it just became an ancient dragon!"

        Awkward silence from everyone.

        It never did come to a fight, so I don't know if he was serious or not. But it left a bad taste in my mouth.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nAviatrix \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nNovember 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n A bunch of stuff but the biggest thing is that I have tried Hangouts Gaming and it is cool. So, in Hangouts:

        Crossroads Carnival, a long-form playtest. Lorelei the Mermaid talks like Marlene Dietrich, seems to be ageless, and is in a love-hate-love relationship with the Geek, literally conjured out of a dying child's fever dream. A game of voluptuous darkness and supernatural chill.

        Fall of Magic: when you take the title of "Hero of Barleytown" I think there is a tendency to play that ironically--Barleytown is one of the most prosaic locations on the map, after all. I decided to take Ellamura a different way, playing someone who thought they became a hero only after they stopped doing Great Deeds. Some nice Obi-Waning of our Raven and I had a lot of fun playing a character dealing with the tragedy of living long enough to see the legends.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nBen_Robbins \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nNovember 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \nHouse of Reeds at Story Games Seattle. When we drew the "move" card the early 1900s country estate of our declining tycoon dynasty was reopened a decade later as an orphanage. But the new generation of children continued the magical (read as: dangerous and perhaps delusion) adventures into the unseen realms beneath, a la Pan's Labyrinth or Narnia.

        And someone literally lost an eye.

        "Goodnight you princes of Maine\u2026 you kings of New England\u2026"
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nGragoon \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nNovember 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \nDownfall at a friends house. The flaw of the Haven was Curiosity. The Haven was a city built up on the clouds where the original settlers built it as they wanted to know what was above. The world fell apart when a whole generation of teenagers jumped down to discover what was below the clouds...

        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n

      • \n

        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Ars Magica. For one adventure the characters are foreigners and meddle in rural politics of medieval Ireland.

      • 51 The Best of Story Games

      \n

      What did you play this week? (2017)

      \n
      \xab1\u20266789101112\xbb

      Comments

        \n
        \n
        \n\nCaesar Slaad \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nNovember 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n I played Masks: A New Generation at Pax Unplugged, as well as running Freeport, City of Adventure.

        It's odd, I was really sort of tepid on Monsterhearts and Dungeon World, but I'm super intrigued by Masks. Perhaps I'm too set in my ways for dungeon fantasy systems and out of the target audience of Monsterhearts.

        In related news, when I decided to pick up Masks at the Magpie booth, my daughter spotted Epyllion. She was interested enough in an RPG to spend her own money on it.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n

      • \n
        \n
        \n

        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n We played Jaiwo 2017 from Cthulhu Dark last night: it was very refreshing to be playing a Cthulhu game in which we weren't white & privileged.

        \n\nDecember 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n I ran "Observer Effect" for Delta Green for my home group to test my pacing as, in theory, I'm running it tomorrow at AnonyCon. (No players listed, as I signed up late, which means I might have zero or I might have many.)
        \n

        \n
        \n\nEmmatheExcrucian \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nDecember 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n My group started our new Chuubo's campaign. I'm the HG. The first session went relatively well. There were some places where I feel like I dropped the ball (because this is also a pseudo experiment regarding improv for me), but my players said it was great, and that everything was perfect, so that's a win. Retrospectively, I'm overall happy.
        My players were so much on point with their RP and it was so nice.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nDreamer \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nDecember 2017 \n edited December 2017
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        Paul_T said:

        Great answer, thank you! Seems like a very good oracular technique.

        \nThanks Paul!

        I keep learning as I go what works best for me and what works less well. For example, I just finished my last introduction scene (in time for the end of Solo Gaming Appreciation Month).

        One of the takeaways is that emulating another player making a long narration (or emulating two players interacting with each other) is more arduous than me controlling one side and the tool driving the other side. When I control one side, it feels much more interactive (probably, kinda obvious to everyone except me!). My input also helps to act as a glue between the automated bits to make it easier for a more coherent whole to emerge.

        TLDR: the automation works more easily in smaller bits.

        The game prep and intro scenes are here if anyone is interested: Remember Tomorrow: The Bartender, The Razor Girl, and The Artiste (Bad pun on The Good, The Bad and The Ugly)
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nJeff_Slater \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nDecember 2017 \n edited December 2017
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n We played a second session of Apocalypse World last night at Story Games SLC. It has been an extremely dark story (positively morally revolting), in almost every sense. I may do a writeup as I have no doubt it would be interesting to some, but it also may be a bit too disturbing for some as well. Tonight we are playing Mongrel Lite, designed by Story Games Forums\u2019 own Mongrel_GM; it is a very Traditional RPG reminiscent of Gurps Lite and is very Simulationist in the Trifold Model sense. The game\u2019s task resolution mechanic is traditional, however it is has a lot of grey area in terms of success gradation, (0%, 20%, 40%, 60%, 80%, and 100%, it gives tremendous amount of subjective and interpretive power to the GM\u2014it\u2019s a bit slippery in that sense\u2014so I hope Mongrel is feeling charitable tonight . I think it will be very effective at quickly separating good GMs, that arbitrate fairly and have a good feel for the social-dynamics and reading the mood of the group, from those GMs that need more work; luckily Mongrel is the first type. I also have an online game of Dog Eat Dog coming up, which I\u2019ve been playing with Story Games Forums\u2019 own Paul_T, David_Berg, and Demiurge, they are a talented group and I really enjoy playing with them. The story has been really creative and interesting so far and DED is an excellent game that I highly recommend. In truth, I\u2019ve been super busy and shouldn\u2019t be playing so much; my first summery of House of Spiders is due for its first studio critique by pretty much the best GMless designer in the business (left unnamed in case that\u2019s his preference), so I\u2019m hoping to get something that isn\u2019t too embarrassing or incomprehensible put together. The game is currently scattered among lose pages of unorganized notes that I\u2019ve yet to compile into a reasonablely coherent document and should have been playtested more thoroughly by this point. On the plus side, I think that it will be beneficial to catch any problems early\u2014to separate the wheat from the chaff\u2014before they get mixed up to the point that they become more difficult to separate. Anyway, I would really recommend playing Dog Eat Dog, if you get the chance. It has a very original and elegant design; it\u2019s very impressive.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nDecember 2017 \n edited December 2017
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Jeff:

        Indeed. I used to play with a group that had a lot of creativity and some great role players... but the disturbing and/or disgusting subject matter eventually made me wonder enough about what kinds of people I was playing with that I decided to leave. It was... strange.

        As for Dog Eat Dog, it may interest you that the designer you are fond of (but do not name) recently said that, of all the games out there, Dog Eat Dog is the game he *wishes* he had written.

        I think it could really use a better book (we struggled with some points which could be improved with some advice or examples, like how to write good rules for the Record), but the design is really inspired and almost shockingly powerful.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nCaesar Slaad \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nDecember 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n None of the material I had prepped for Mutants & Masterminds was developed to my satisfaction, so I suggested my Friday group try something a bit more quick-prep and collaborative while I am fleshing out my M&M material.

        My pitch for Masks fell flat on its face, sadly. But they did seem sufficiently interested in Bulldogs! (fate core edition) that we spun up some characters and I ran them through a tweaked prior-edition adventure, Getting There is Half the Fun.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n

        \n
        \n
        \n\nJason_Morningstar \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nDecember 2017 \n edited December 2017
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \nTension
        Playtest-y thing

        The playtest-y thing was built to answer the question "what if a character was nothing but Marks from Night Witches?" Turns out it works great but relies a lot on player skill.

        Tension is just a beautiful game and I played it with my wife, who isn't a huge gamer.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nMongrel_GM \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nDecember 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Played session 1 of my homebrew rules set, cyberpunk/post-apocalypse setting.

        Used the fish tank mapping technique, then put things on a 13 x 13 grid. Need to make sure the players can get clues as they look for them. My biggest GM temptation is to make it hard to get info, so I try to remind myself frequently TO NOT DO THAT.

        Hoping everyone is enjoying the challenge...
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nLisa Padol \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nDecember 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Played a really cool Fate game at AnonyCon, "In the Court of Ranavalona I", about the real ruler of Madagascar and the intrigue in her kingdom. There were 6 scenes, and in each one, a different player was a semi-GM, as this was the scene focused on their PC's plotting. The final scene was an epic social conflict with the future of Madagascar and each of the PCs at stake, originally with three sides, and ultimately turning into everyone against the title character (also a PC), which is the only reason she didn't triumph. And actual history is amazingly weirder than fiction.

        I also played a Lovecraftian game using PbtA mechanics. This was not tremulus. Instead of Sanity, it had two parts: Beyond as the ever rising score for knowing too much and Hold Fast as the defense against that sort of thing. This works really well for PbtA. Where it differs from core PbtA is that it's designed for taking a pre-existing scenario and running it, something which is -- well, not exactly antithetical to PbtA, but not exactly what I'd recommend. It worked fine here, and I'm very much looking forward to seeing this one developed.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nchiarina \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nDecember 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Night\xb4s Black Agents: We had a disaster session. A big railway accident at the Vienna airport station, hundreds of dead, collapsing walls and ceilings, humans in panic.., and in this chaos our agents fled from superhuman undead, later the chase continued by car with one of the monsters on the roof, past snipers through car jams, offroad parks and a chemical plant. I\xb4m exhausted now!
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n

        \n\nDecember 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Homebrew rules, homebrew/player input setting. PCs far from wealthy to begin with.

        I thought that cyberpunk in a post-apocalyptic setting was a good idea. I may be part of a tiny minority of RPGers who think that is true.

        Going into damage control mode to try to salvage the mini-campaign after an incredibly bad second session.

        \n\nAsIf \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nDecember 2017 \n edited December 2017
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \nDayTrippers/Legends of Tabletop AP 6 - "Detox at Reggie's"
        Back on Home Earth, our heroes must deal with Chip's addiction to Zoomzoom. Unfortunately, his repeated doses of this hyperamphetamine are the only thing keeping him from slipping into Subjective Dissonance Syndrome. Something's gotta give. (PS - NSFW, kids!)
        http://daytrippersrpg.com/forums/actual-plays/legends-tabletop-ap-6-detox-reggies
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n

        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nBen_Robbins \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nDecember 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \nRemember Tomorrow at Story Games Seattle. We started with three players but when the Fiasco game wrapped early, two of those players jumped in and joined us. Which is one of the neat things about Remember Tomorrow, that you can easily bring people in late and just weave in new stories.

        Saturday we played Quiet Year, "Quest for Fire" style. There's commentary at the bottom of the picture. Rough times for the clan who honored their dead\u2026
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nDecember 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Thanks to a couple of my cool gamer friends and the unstoppable Jeff_Slater, I'm getting to play a bunch of one-offs (single playthroughs; they typically take us a handful of 2 or 2 1/2 hour sessions each) and go through old and new indie classics I missed the first time around.

        Last week we finished a really dramatic and tragic game of Dog Eat Dog. Tonight we started A Taste for Murder, which is absolutely delightful. I love the random tables for the weather - of course that would be the one thing this game would make you generate randomly! How appropriate.

        We've already got a lovers' tryst, some theater backdrop paintings being set on fire (for a kiss!), and an American oil tycoon has lost the use of his left arm after getting bitten by a dog.

        Most of all, though, we get to do goofy British accents. A nice relief after the (rather satisfying) dark and sad game of Dog Eat Dog; a nice palate cleanser.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nJeff_Slater \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nDecember 2017 \n edited December 2017
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n We played A Taste for Murder tonight with our online story games forum group, (i.e. Paul, David, Jonathan), a really great group of gamers. Paul gave some details above. ATfM has interesting mechanics and I\u2019m very much wondering how the game will play. I also recently played Mongrel_GM\u2019s RPG, aptly named Mongrel Lite. We are playing a Cyberpunk campaign and we are just starting to get our legs under us and figure out the direction we are taking things. Finally, I played another session of our short Apocalypse World campaign, at Story Games SLC. Zack, who is also a regular of these forums is MCing; he is an absolutely amazingly talented MC, I love playing in his games.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n

      • \n

        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Ran D&D 5e, my Mirrorrim Megadungeon campaign. I'm using Roll20 and pretty maps I made in GIMP and the "Fog of War" tools. Maybe by the next time we play, I'll have the dynamic lighting set up for my dungeon. It's rad.

        \n\nEmmatheExcrucian \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nDecember 2017 \n edited December 2017
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n I played Monsterhearts earlier tonight, and then tomorrow I'm running a session of my group's weekly Chuubo's Marvelous Wish-Granting Engine campaign. The Monsterhearts one-shot I played in was so fucking good, especially for the fact that it was our GM's first time ever GMing, and she'd never even played Monsterhearts before running it. It was easily the most impressive first-time-GMing session I've ever seen in all my years of playing ttrpg and it was just generally a really great session.
        \n

        \n
        \n\nGragoon \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nDecember 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Got to play twice this week!

        Played Follow at the weekly meetup I attend. We have played it several times already, but this is the first time I got to play it with a larger group. I had played it with 3 and 4 players before, but we were 6 this time. I was worried it was not going to be as smooth... and turns out that worry was unfounded. The play worked like a charm. It was a lovely experience.

        Later in the week, I convinced some non-gamer friends to play The Quiet Year. I ended up removing about half the cards to make the game last less than 2 hours, and it worked fine. One of the players got a huge grin when she realized she could let her mind discover whatever she wanted on the map, like she was a kid playing pretend again. It made my day. The drawing on the map was very well received as well.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n

        \n\nAviatrix \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nDecember 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Last week, Dungeon World using the "Frozen South" dungeon starter. As everyone was in a holiday mood, this totally became the quest to reach the lost city where a portal existed to show what anyone in the world had done in the previous year, a halfling who preferred the term "little helper", and a giant who wore a red coat and engaged the party in a live-action game of tafel with the white pieces being polar bears and the black pieces miniature wooly mammoths.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n

        \n
        \n
        \n\nAdam_Dray \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nDecember 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Ran my Mirrorrim megadungeon (D&D 5e) last night on Roll20, using a lot of the Pro-level tools: Advanced Fog of War, Dynamic Lighting, Line of Sight. I already had the map imported. The additional setup for dynamic lighting took about an hour or two to trace the map and figure out the settings.

        This had a pretty big impact on play. I got oohs and ahhs from the players as they moved their tokens around the map and got personalized viewpoints with shadows. At one point, a player lost sight of a piercer because it was behind a stalactite-stalagmite column, out of line-of-sight, and got nervous.

        Otherwise, a normal, fun dungeon romp.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nJason_Morningstar \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nDecember 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \nLBB Traveller
        \n

        • \n

        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nDecember 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n That's very cool, Adam! I'm looking forward to joining in sometime.

        This week I play A Taste for Murder (being discussed over here, if you want details), which has been delightful, and preparing a short run of Apocalypse World with D&D players. If I get a minute, I may post my prep for that here on S-G, as well - it's been an interesting exercise (where do you draw the line between a prepared scenario/adventure - which can't survive playbook choices - and open-ended exploratory AW-by-the-book play, which can flounder if you don't have an active table but want to play on a deadline?).
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nLisa Padol \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nDecember 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        chiarina said:

        Lisa Padol said:

        chiarina said:

        We started a Hillfolk-Campaign and used Emily Care Boss\xb4 "Colony Wars" Series Pitch. It was a promising evening and I\xb4m curious about the future development.

        \nHow many people are in that game?
        \nWe are 5 players + Game Moderator. Why do you ask?
        \nBecause Hillfolk says something about needing 5-8 players, which seemed a bit tricky to arrange on a regular basis. So, I was curious.

        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nchiarina \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nDecember 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n The rules recommend 4-8 players. The net of connections demands some characters to get interesting, I think (and indeed, it is a long time ago I played in a group with more than 6 players).
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n

      • \n

        \n
        \n
        EmmatheExcrucian said:

        I ran Chuubo's Marvelous Wish-Granting Engine today, and I'm going to be playing Masks this weekend.

        \nI want to know how you ran Chuubo's -- and I guarantee you so does Tony Lower-Basch, who's response to learning I played it with someone who wasn't him was "How did he do it?" (Love the game, but definitely looking for "and here's how you run this".)
        \n

        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nGragoon \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nDecember 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Played House of Reeds. We were only 2 players. Found it a bit too taxing on the creative end with only 2 players.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nMongrel_GM \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nDecember 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n 4th session of a homebrew rules set and world (started using @Rickard fish tank technique with 11 starting factions/events).

        The world is ballooning, with about 25 moving parts. That puts us maybe 1/4 into figuring things out, and about 4 more sessions has to get us to a finale or at least a chapter end of some kind.

        Pacing insanity.

        But last night went pretty well I think.

        Need to think of how to introduce info quickly without breaking everything.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nDecember 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Yeah, that's an interesting position to be in. I just started an Apocalypse World game (of uncertain duration), and I will likely be creating a bit of a fish tank-like structure before the second session.

        It's great fun so far. I put together a scenario, which I should probably share at some point - it was a hit with the players.

        Lots of highlights, some sweet and touching, some absolutely disgusting:

        I used Vincent's "mudfish" (from "Hatchet City") in the game, as a food source for the community (a sort of bony eel with fused blades for teeth).

        One of the players asked, "Hey, given how terrible life is here for people, what do they do to distract themselves from their horrible living conditions?"

        The answer came from another player:

        "One person has figured out the trick to extracting a powerful drug from the mudfish. The fish's anal glands produce a toxin; they are removed while the fish is still alive, and then squirted into a person's eyes. It produces a crazy high."
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nMongrel_GM \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nDecember 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Ha ha, sounds disgusting.

        My players have had a run in with a gang called Truffle Hunters. Weeks ago they found a subterranean garden of mushrooms growing on hacked up corpses. Food is scarce so they harvested the whole garden.

        This session they found a newly "dressed" garden: fresh corpses with spores sprinkled on.

        When the Truffle Hunters tried to ambush the team in the sewer tunnels @Jeff_Slater 's character torched them with a flamethrower.

        Grizzly business.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nDecember 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n Fantastic! There's an underground "black fungus" garden in my game too, by some odd coincidence.

        Here's another detail I really dig, coming out of the setup procedure I used to create some of the important NPCs for the game:

        There are very few pregnancies or children in this Apocalypse World.

        The oldest person around - the only one who remembers the Golden Age - has just become pregnant, to much public anticipation.

        I'm seeing parallels to the story of Sarah, in the Bible, which is fascinating to me.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nCaesar Slaad \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nDecember 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n I finally got a chance to run Masks: A New Generation. I convinced the FLGS to start a monthly Indie/Small Press RPG day event. My normal group was out of town for the holiday or otherwise occupied, but I pulled together my daughter, a local player I know who is into indie games, and a young couple who were looking for D&D game and convinced them to give Masks a try.

        I was a little worried that players who were only used to D&D would be taken aback by the different nature of an apocalypse engine game. But actually, they took to it quite well. We ended up with.
        Apate - The Delinquent, played by my daughter, a mutant with Illusion and Emotion control powers.
        Mystic Storm - The Doomed. A genetic experiment with superior physique, body manipulation, and memory control powers. Her nemesis was her father, and she is being hunted by her father's secret project.
        Nighthawk - the Protoge. A clever lad, but his mentor "Dark Eagle" was a bit more Punisher than Batman, who advises him not to overhink problems.
        The Gadgeteer. Essentially a hawkeye type. Excited young hero who made Nighthawl's acquaintance before the group's first mission.

        I ran in intro session that was a cross between Die Hard and the Dr. Who Raknoss Chrismas special. I used the character Nano from the Villainy deck. His father was a retired hero (one of the first powered armor heroes), but now headed up a robotics company that opened up a branch in Halcyon city. The players started at a Christmas ball thrown by Astro Robotics, and was there for the fun when the Santa-and-Elf themed robots turned against the guests.

        The new players like the session enough that they seemed interested in returning next months for a round two.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nJames_Mullen \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nDecember 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n I got to play Troublemakers again, this time taking on the role of a Kook whose Heirloom was an authentic 1980's Walkman that she was convinced also picked up ghostly voices.

        Myself and two other kids (a Daredevil and a Knuckle) got a lift to a realm Fearsome Critters in an ice-cream van driven by Bigfoot; after an arrest and escape, we made it back home again but with no evidence of our big adventure to show the adults.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        • \n
      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n

        \n\nGragoon \n\n\n

        \n\nDecember 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n I got to play Eden. I think I will have to play it again to see if I like it or not. We were too big of a group with too many conflicting ideas.

        \n
        \n\nAdam_Dray \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nDecember 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n I ran two 2-hour sessions for my Mirrorrim Megadungeon campaign (D&D 5e), but this time for "rookie" players. The first two hours on Wednesday, I walked players through character generation including use of the Roll20 character sheet tools. The second two hours on Thursday, we played through a one-off mini-adventure that took them into the desert to explore an ancient temple.
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n

      • \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n\nEmmatheExcrucian \n\n\n
        \n
        \n\nDecember 2017 \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n
        \n I played in a monsterhearts 2 one-shot that one of my girlfriends ran, which was super nice. We got really deep into the abuse themes in ways that we hadn't as deeply last time we played, and it was a lot of fun. Really intense.
        Then tonight I'm running a session of my group's weekly Chuubo's Marvelous Wish-Granting Engine campaign. We're starting the second big story arc, and a bunch of exciting stuff is going to be happening soon, and I'm really looking forward to it.
        \n
        \n
